tropeNotes: [Action Dad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionDad): In *The After Years*, he is one of these to Ceodore.
[All There in the Manual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual): Japanese guides give his full name as Cecil Harvey, which was retained in 3D releases.

[And I Must Scream](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndIMustScream): After he's freed from  (SPOILER) the Mysterious Girl's control  in *The After Years*, we learn that Cecil was aware of what was happening but couldn't do anything to stop it.
[The Atoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAtoner): Mainly for the atrocity he knowingly committed in Mysidia and unknowingly in Mist.

[Battle Couple](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BattleCouple): With his wife, Rosa. He fights and protects her while she heals and supports him. Several times in both games when Cecil tries to order her away from danger, she stays by his side to aid him.

[BFS](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BFS): Hard to tell in the 2D releases, but in the DS release, some of his swords are thicker than his arms and longer than he is tall save for the head. Of course, this is probably due to the [Chibi](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperDeformed) art style, because his official renders show him wielding swords of standard sizes.
[Big Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigGood): He becomes this in *The After Years* game as he marries Rosa and have a son together and they rule over Baron together.
[Big "WHY?!"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigWhy): He lets out an absolutely *anguished* one in the DS version as he realizes he was sent to destroy Mist.
[Black Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackKnight): His initial class is the Dark Knight.

[Black Swords Are Better](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackSwordsAreBetter): As a Dark Knight he can use three dark weapons: the Dark Sword, the Shadowblade and the Deathbringer. The last one has a small chance to kill any non-boss enemy in one-hit, making it a (very brief) [Disc-One Nuke](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscOneNuke). You will definitely notice the difference on your way back to Mysidia when Cecil can't use it anymore.
[Brainwashed and Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy): He's taken control of by the Mysterious Girl in *The After Years* and made a puppet king for her to control Baron with.

[Cain and Abel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CainAndAbel): The noble and good-hearted Abel to the brooding and treacherous Kain, who is jealous of Cecil's life. Kain isn't his biological brother but might as well be since they were raised together and adopted by the King of Baron.  (SPOILER) Also a blood-relative version with Golbez, his actual older brother.
[Can't Drop the Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CantDropTheHero): Cecil is the only character who is playable throughout the game.
[Cast from Hit Points](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CastFromHitPoints): The Darkness ability absorbs HP from Cecil.

[Casting a Shadow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CastingAShadow): His Dark Knight ability, Darkness, or Dark Wave. In the original SNES version, this attack sends waves of dark energy to attack all foes. In the DS version, this amplifies his attack power on a single target.

[Childhood Friend Romance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChildhoodFriendRomance): With Rosa, who he's known since he was a child. By the time the game starts, they've been in a relationship for quite some time. Likewise, Rosa choosing Cecil was what spurred Kain's rivalry.

[The Chosen One](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChosenOne): He is the prophesied Chosen One mentioned in the The Mysidian legend destined to ride the world of all evil because he wields the Mythgraven Blade.

[Classically-Trained Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClassicallyTrainedExtra): His seiyuu is Shizuma Hodoshima, who's not a name to know in anime... Bit of a different story, though, if you're looking to put on a [Shakespeare](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Creator/WilliamShakespeare) production.

[Compressed Hair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CompressedHair): [Once Cecil ditches the Dark Knight armor for good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HelmetsAreHardlyHeroic), his impressive snow white locks are put on full display.

[Conflicting Loyalty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ConflictingLoyalty): At the beginning of the game he knows what he's doing for Baron is wrong, but carries out his orders anyway. He decides to turn against Baron and fight for what he believes is right.

[Cool Sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolSword): His [Sword of Plot Advancement](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SwordOfPlotAdvancement), the Mythgraven Blade. It has runes of an ancient legend inscribed on it, was gifted to him by a spirit of light, and can be reforged into one of his best weapons, Excalibur. There's also his ultimate weapon from the Lunar Ruins, the Lightbringer.

[Dark Is Not Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkIsNotEvil): Played with here, as Dark Knight Cecil is a fair and noble man (although a few lines in the DS version imply he fears his personality is slowly being altered by his dark equipment) and while he did do some evil work for the King of Baron it was with misgiving and he quickly turns against him and attempts to use his dark sword in the service good. However against Golbez's dark army of fiends, monsters and undead the power of Darkness is a very poor match up (since they themselves are empowered by it) and Cecil quickly finds himself hitting a wall in Fabul where his fight against Golbez's forces goes terribly. It's only after he gives up the Dark Knight path and becomes a Paladin that Cecil is truely able to start making headway against the enemy. So in this case Dark is not evil but it's also not a great tool to fight against an enemy also using Darkness.

[Defector from Decadence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefectorFromDecadence): Cecil turned against Baron when he realized the king was going too far in his quest for power, and led a rebellion against him. Turns out that it was just Cagnazzo impersonating the king anyways.

[Discard and Draw](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscardAndDraw): Cecil ditches everything when he abandons the dark sword and becomes a Paladin — even his levels! Fortunately, among the benefits of paladin-hood are much better defensive stats as well as the ability to wear much better armor and weapons, and that's before Cecil starts learning White Magic spells and sees his attack power rocket above what his pinnacle as a Dark Knight was.

[Dude Looks Like a Lady](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DudeLooksLikeALady): But it only became obvious after 1) technology developed to the point that we could clearly see what he looks like, and 2) the series became popular enough for [Yoshitaka Amano](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Creator/YoshitakaAmano)'s artwork for it to be gathered up into artbooks ([as usual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoExportForYou), happening later for the anglophone world than Japan).

[Easily Forgiven](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EasilyForgiven): Averted at first, since he and Kain did accidentally murder Rydia's mother. After Cecil defends her from some Baron guards, she warms up to him and by the time she's all grown up she doesn't blame him at all.

[Experienced Protagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExperiencedProtagonist): At the start of the game Cecil is the commander of the Red Wings and is widely recognized as "the dark knight of Baron"; [this is reflected with him starting at level 10 instead of level 1](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStoryIntegration).

[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy): One in a [Composite Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CompositeCharacter) way, with him as a Dark Knight, looking very much like [Leon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyII), and adapting, and extending the first Dark Knight's character arc, while his look as a Paladin, takes a lot from the [Warrior of Light's](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyI) artwork by Yoshitaka Amano. Cecil's sprite as a Paladin also looks quite much like a lighter version of the Knight [Job](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JobSystem) from *[Final Fantasy III](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyIII)*.

[Four-Star Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FourStarBadass): [Lord Captain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCaptain) of the Red Wings, making him Baron's military commander. The King of Baron strips Cecil of his station at the beginning of the game for questioning orders and [showing concern for the people of Mysidia that he recently besieged](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PunishedForSympathy), and it is unclear if Cecil ever regains his position following his coronation.

tropeName: Get a Hold of Yourself, Man!
tropeNotes: [Get a Hold of Yourself, Man!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GetAholdOfYourselfMan): To Edward, giving him a wallop before telling him to quit crying over his dead fiancee and [Dare to Be Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DareToBeBadass).

[The Good Captain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGoodCaptain): He does try to blame his men for questioning the king, but that was also when he still described himself as a coward. He gets better after his [Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment).
[Good Costume Switch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodCostumeSwitch): Loses the helmet and goes from [black armor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkIsEvil) to [white](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightIsGood).
[The Good King](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGoodKing): In the sequel, he's King of Baron, and is loved around the world for being a great and noble war hero as well as an effective king.
[Hair Color Dissonance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HairColorDissonance): Purple? White? Blond? [Yes?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MathematiciansAnswer)
[Half-Human Hybrid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HalfHumanHybrid): His mom was a human named Cecilia, his dad was  (SPOILER) a Lunarian named Kluya.

[Happily Married](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HappilyMarried): Come the end of the original game, he marries Rosa and takes her as his queen. Seventeen years later, their devotion and love is as strong as ever.
[Heavy Equipment Class](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeavyEquipmentClass): Capable with a high number of swords and axes along with access to Heavy Armor.

[Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn): Much earlier than most [Punch Clock Villains](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PunchClockVillain), after performing the second evil act under orders from his king.
[Helmets Are Hardly Heroic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HelmetsAreHardlyHeroic): Played straight when he transitions from a dark helm as a Dark Knight to a nice headband as a Paladin.
[The Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHero): He grows into the role after abandoning Baron for its atrocities.

[Heroes Prefer Swords](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroesPreferSwords): Just like most *[Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/FinalFantasy)* heroes, he specializes in swords. Though he can also use bows and axes, all of Cecil's best weapons are swords.

[Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD): Suffers from this in *The After Years* due to  (SPOILER) the Mysterious Girl's prolonged control of him. Although you can use him during his BSOD, his stats are absolutely pathetic and he's a blubbering, incoherent mess. It's not until he sees his dark side [either kill his brother Golbez or about to kill Ceodore](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RelativeButton) [that he snaps](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouKilledMyFather) [out of it](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PapaWolf) and [returns to being the ass-kicker we all know](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HesBack) .
[Hero with Bad Publicity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroWithBadPublicity): By the time he returns to Mysidia, he is understandably scorned by everyone he comes across for his attack on the city.

[He Who Fights Monsters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeWhoFightsMonsters): [Warned of this several times](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscussedTrope) before renouncing the dark sword. Both the King of Fabul and Elder of Mysidia tell Cecil he cannot hope to defeat Golbez if he relies upon the power he gained following the path of the Dark Knight, and the latter clearly spells out that, in hunting monsters, Cecil runs risk of becoming one himself should he continue to let his soul be tainted by darkness.
[Honorary Uncle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HonoraryUncle): Yang asks him to be Ursula's godfather during her birth.

[How Do I Shot Web?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HowDoIShotWeb): After the Paladin transformation, he's reset to Level 1, with the damage capability he had at the beginning of the game. (Fortunately, he gains levels extremely quickly.) His holy-element Mythgraven Blade/Sword of Legend helps him be effective while he's re-leveling on the way down Mt. Ordeals.

[Ideal Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IdealHero): Grows into it along with becoming a Paladin. He's a noble, upstanding man who only draws his sword when needed and fights to uphold morality and honor the world over.

[Just Following Orders](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JustFollowingOrders): His reasons for taking the crystal from Mysidia. Much of the first act of the game is questioning this mindset and eventually abandoning it.
[Knight in Shining Armor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightInShiningArmor): As a Paladin, naturally (and hands down at that), but it's also implied that he was this as a Dark Knight.

[Lawful Stupid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LawfulStupid): Subverting this trope is actually a plot point for him, as he worries that [he's becoming a tool of Baron without any morality in the beginning of the game](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ToBeLawfulOrGood). The decision to subvert this is also what causes him to turn against his homeland.

[Left-Handed Mirror](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeftHandedMirror): Well, Right Handed Mirror
    - To Kain. Both are orphans raised by the King, both rose high in the Baronian ranks, both vow to fight against Baron. But right-handed Cecil stays the course and becomes a Paladin, while left-handed Kain ends up [Brainwashed and Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy) and working for Golbez. - To Golbez. They turn out to have very similar pasts, and it is only through luck that Cecil did not end up in Golbez's villainous role.
[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): ["The Red Wings."](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rZkQPTuVBl0)

[The Load](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLoad): Unusual for the main character, he becomes this on the way up Mt. Ordeals — his Dark Knight swords and abilities heal undead, and over ninety percent of the encounters there are undead. He ends up focusing on healing while Palom and Porom use their abilities to win fights. In fact, he's better off fighting the undead with his bare hands since dark swords only hit for 1 damage point.

[Magic Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicKnight): Ends up as one of these, primarily of the [Combat Medic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatMedic) variety. He's got White Magic and sword skills in tandem, but his magic isn't anywhere near as powerful as Rosa's. The 3D versions are better about this trope by giving him Protect, Shell, and Raise, so his magic is much more effective.

[Multi-Melee Master](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MultiMeleeMaster): Once he becomes a Paladin Cecil gets a surprisingly wide equipment draw, not just swords, but also daggers, staves, axes and the bow and arrow. However this mostly will be overlooked because swords are his best weapons in almost all situations. This does come in handy in the Lodestone Cave/Magnetic Cavern however, as the magnetic field will make it so using a sword will paralyze him. In this case giving Cecil a staff or bow is the only way he'll be able to put up any fight.

tropeName: My God, What Have I Done?
tropeNotes:
[My God, What Have I Done?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGodWhatHaveIDone):
    - His reaction to attacking the Mysidians and inadvertently burning down Mist and killing Rydia's mother. - Has the same reaction in *The After Years* (SPOILER) when he remembers everything he's done under the Mysterious Girl's control, but especially when he realizes he's given Edward a Carnelian Signet (aka Bomb Ring), the very same thing that he inadvertently destroyed Mist with 17 years prior .

[Not Allowed to Grow Old](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotAllowedToGrowOld): Cecil is pushing age forty by the sequel, but looks little older than he did in the original game. This may have something to do with  (SPOILER) the longevity of the Lunarian race if his father and uncle are any indication .

[Offered the Crown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OfferedTheCrown): At the end of the original game, as the King of Baron had no biological heirs or blood relatives at the time of his death, leaving Cecil, his adopted son, as the only legitimate successor remaining in the kingdom. It helps somewhat that the King already [gave his blessing to Cecil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeUpMySword) after testing his strength  (SPOILER) (and Rydia's) in the guise of Odin .
QUOTE **King of Baron:** "[You've grown as strong as you are valiant, Cecil.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SoProudOfYou) The future of Baron—no, the world itself—rests in good hands. I pray that I might help protect that world with you."

[Official Couple](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OfficialCouple): Cecil and Rosa are established as a romantic couple from the very beginning of the original game. They marry at the end, and the sequel games all have them still as devoted to each other as ever.

[The Paladin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePaladin): The climax of his [Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment) is when he becomes one, after his ascent up Mt. Ordeals to shed himself of his darkness.
[Papa Wolf](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PapaWolf): One of the factors that broke Cecil out of his [Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD) is  (SPOILER) when his dark side attacked Ceodore .

[Punch-Clock Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PunchClockVillain): He's never evil, but he does assault a sovereign nation without provocation and steal their national treasure because his king orders him to. He then becomes a delivery boy for an object that kills almost all of the summoners for similar reasons, [at which point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelRealization) he quits his position.

[Purple Prose](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PurpleProse): The DS version had him dabble in some of this during his angsty moment with Rosa. [After that, he starts speaking much more normally, oddly enough.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigLippedAlligatorMoment)

[Sibling Yin-Yang](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SiblingYinYang): With  (SPOILER) Golbez . Like Porom, Cecil is quiet, polite and dutiful, whereas  (SPOILER) Golbez  is considerably less so, to the point of being as boastful and arrogant as Palom.

tropeName: So Long, and Thanks for All the Gear
tropeNotes: [So Long, and Thanks for All the Gear](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SoLongAndThanksForAllTheGear): Pulls off the rare feat of doing this despite being A) the main character and B) not leaving the party — when the Dark Knight class is removed, all of the gear Cecil was wearing disappears. Nobody else can equip it, but you can get extra cash by removing it and selling it when you get back to a town. Averted in the *Pixel Remaster*, though, as his class change to Paladin has all his dark equipment automatically removed from his body and ended up in the inventory, which makes the potential of selling it much easier.

[The Stoic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStoic): Something lost in many of the English translations, though Cecil struggles greatly with expressing himself and opening up to others. He overcomes it to a certain extent for the sequels.

[Sudden Principled Stand](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuddenPrincipledStand): Having already spent his time up to that point agonizing over his sacking of Mysidia and having reservations about where Baron's rapid militarization is leading the kingdom, Cecil's [unwitting](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingPawn) hand in the destruction of Mist is the absolute last straw for him, marking the point where Cecil openly denounces his king and begins to fight back against Baron. Especially pronounced is his reaction when Kain reminds Cecil that King Baron [ordered the execution of every single villager](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeaveNoSurvivors), [Rydia included](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WouldHurtAChild).
QUOTE **Kain:** "You'd betray your king?"

QUOTE **Cecil:** "Betray him? Any man who'd wish for this is no king of mine."

QUOTE **Kain:** ["Heh. I thought you might say that."](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SecretTestOfCharacter)
[Sword of Plot Advancement](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SwordOfPlotAdvancement): The Mythgraven Blade, received on Mt. Ordeals to signify his class change to Paladin.

[Taking the Bullet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakingTheBullet): His Cover ability allows him to step in for whoever he designates to protect. If he doesn't actively pick a target, he'll also automatically step in to take blows for anyone currently at critical health.

[Tomato in the Mirror](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TomatoInTheMirror): Cecil never really knew his father, so the fact that his father was actually a Lunarian took him by as much surprise at it did everyone else.

[Trauma Conga Line](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TraumaCongaLine): Cecil has a crisis of conscience after being ordered to commit an immoral act for the King of Baron. Then he gets demoted for questioning the king and manipulated into carrying out another immoral act, which results in the destruction of an innocent village and the apparent death of his best friend Kain.

[Unwitting Pawn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingPawn): At the beginning of *IV*, Cecil is tricked by Cagnazzo, disguised as the King of Baron, into stealing the Water Crystal from Mysidia and destroying Mist.
[Warrior Prince](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WarriorPrince): Although he does not officially bear the title of Prince, he is King Baron's ward and heir.

tropeName: When All You Have Is a Hammer…
tropeNotes: [When All You Have Is a Hammer…](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhenAllYouHaveIsAHammer): [Enforced](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnforcedTrope) in the first US localization, which removed the Darkness ability from Cecil's Dark Knight menu, meaning all he could do was swing his sword or use items.

[Wouldn't Hurt a Child](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WouldntHurtAChild): The idea of having to kill a young Rydia is where Cecil draws the line and officially betrays Baron, kickstarting his [Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment).

[You Killed My Father](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouKilledMyFather):  (SPOILER) In this case, "You Killed My Brother." One of the factors that Cecil broke out of his [Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD) is when his dark side succeeds in killing Golbez in his stead if Rosa and Ceodore aren't present in battle.
[All Love Is Unrequited](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllLoveIsUnrequited): He loves Rosa, but she doesn't return his affections.
[All There in the Manual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual): Japanese guides give his full name as Cain Highwind, which was retained in 3D releases.

[Always Someone Better](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlwaysSomeoneBetter): Feels this way about Cecil. Supplementary materials establish it isn't just him getting Rosa over Kain that fuels Kain's jealousy, but Cecil has also had a more successful career, being made captain of the Red Wings while the Dragoon Corps are fading from power, and the king favored Cecil over Kain while they were growing up.

[Ascended Glitch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedGlitch): A bug in the original Japanese release of *FFIV* causes Kain to repeat the last move another character makes when he equips a certain weapon in the final battle. Apparently, more than one person on the dev team thought this was awesome and in [the next game](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyV), created a job class based on it: the Mime.
[The Atoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAtoner): He decides he cannot return to Baron with his soul still stained by the evil he did under Golbez's control.
[Badass Cape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassCape): As the Hooded Man.
[Barbarian Long Hair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BarbarianLongHair): Seventeen years later, he still rocks his mane.
[Big Brother Mentor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBrotherMentor): [To Ceodore](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IntergenerationalFriendship) in the sequel.

[Boring, but Practical](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BoringButPractical): Compared to the other party members who get magic spells or other fantastical abilities, Kain's special ability is to simply jump and leave the battlefield for a little while and deal increased damage upon his return. However, because Jump renders Kain effectively invincible, it can be properly timed to avoid heavy hitting attacks or status ailments cast on the party. His battle against Lunar Bahamut relies on this specific tactic. In some versions Kain can jump and avoid Golbez's initial attack that knocks out every party member except Cecil as well. Jump isn't flashy but if used correctly it can turn the tide of any fight in the game.

[Brainwashed and Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy): The main reason for his [Heel–Face Revolving Door](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceRevolvingDoor) trope. Over the course of the game's various remakes, his out-and-out brainwashing has been phased out in favour of [More than Mind Control](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoreThanMindControl); especially in the DS version.

[Breakout Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakoutCharacter): His popularity in the fanbase meant that Kain gets the most screentime of any other character in *IV* in later works, save for Cecil and Golbez, [The Protagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheProtagonist) and the [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad). Kain is a central character in *The After Years* and plays a major role in the story, and he was made playable in *Dissidia 012* where he also plays a major role. [Tetsuya Nomura](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Creator/TetsuyaNomura) is a self-admitted Kain fanboy and tried really hard to get him in the first *Dissidia*, at one point even considering featuring him as *IV's* representative villain instead of Golbez. In other crossover titles, if there is a third character from *IV* besides Cecil and Golbez, it's probably going to be Kain (or Rydia).

[Cain and Abel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CainAndAbel): The Cain to Cecil's Abel (his name is literally "Kain"), he's brooding, troubled, and jealous of Cecil getting more glory and Rosa's affections. The *Advance* version even names his [Infinity +1 Sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InfinityPlusOneSword) "Abel's Lance," and he receives it when he refuses the temptation to kill Cecil.

[The Captain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCaptain): Leads the Dragoon Corps, which are tasked with defending Baron Castle in the wake of the rising prominence of the Red Wings. [Kain does not like this one bit.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheResenter)  (SPOILER) In *The After Years*, once Kain returns to Baron in the epilogue, he is instead given command of the Red Wings.
[Childhood Friend Romance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChildhoodFriendRomance): He formed a [Two Guys and a Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TwoGuysAndAGirl) trio with Cecil and Rosa when they were small.
[Combat Medic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatMedic): In *The After Years*, when he becomes a Holy Dragoon, he gains some white magic spells. Although he leans more of the combat than medic.
[Compressed Hair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CompressedHair): As the epilogue, *The After Years*, and *Dissidia 012* show, Kain's helmet is quite spacious when it comes to his surprisingly long hair.
[The Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon): He's Golbez's right-hand man when controlled.

[Dragon Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DragonKnight): [Not the first](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyII), but easily the most famous and recognizable of the entire series.  (SPOILER) *The After Years* sees Kain become a **[Holy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrestigeClass)** Dragoon, his equivalent to Cecil's [Paladin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePaladin) class.

[Dragon Rider](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DragonRider): He *is* a Dragoon, although the only mention of his pet [wyvern](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurWyvernsAreDifferent) is in [supplemental materials](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual).

[Easy Levels, Hard Bosses](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EasyLevelsHardBosses): While the other characters' Lunar Trials involves completing various tasks, Kain's is instead a murder mystery that requires little input from the player. The only way to fail here is to give the wrong answer to a choice given at the very end. Contrast the true challenge of the Trial: a [Duel Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DuelBoss) with Lunar *Bahamut*, which can be devastating unless the player knows how to time Kain's Jump with Bahamut's countdown to Mega Flare (or has Lunar Curtains to spare).
[Enemy Without](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemyWithout): Dark Kain in *IV Advance*  (SPOILER) and Kain? in *The After Years* , born from the darkness in Kain's heart.
[Good Costume Switch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodCostumeSwitch): When he  (SPOILER) becomes a Holy Dragoon , his armor turns blue and white.

[Green-Eyed Monster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreenEyedMonster): Kain hints back in the destruction of Mist about his jealousy of Cecil over Rosa, although Cecil is ignorant of it (and how strong it is) until [it's used to put Kain under Golbez's control](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FaceHeelTurn).

tropeName: Hair of Gold, Heart of Gold
tropeNotes: [Hair of Gold, Heart of Gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HairOfGoldHeartOfGold): It takes a while for him to get there. His [shoulder-length](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LongHairedPrettyBoy) blond hair comes into play when he becomes *truly* noble in his heart, turning into a Holy Dragoon.
[Heavy Equipment Class](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeavyEquipmentClass): Proficient with spears, axes, some swords and heavy armor.

[Heel–Face Revolving Door](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceRevolvingDoor): The most common perception of him, though in truth he only is brainwashed twice, and he notably fights off another attempt at brainwashing without even letting the struggle show on his face. Some versions of the game reduce the number from two to one, with Golbez intentionally allowing him to briefly rejoin Cecil to steal the last Dark Crystal but never *really* giving up his control over Kain. Still, he is the only character to have three separate stints as a party member (albeit his first stint is basically a glorified tutorial run).

[Heroes Prefer Swords](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroesPreferSwords): Averted, as while Kain is a capable swordsman and can equip all but the Paladin exclusive Holy Swords he is best sticking to spears as swords do not do additional damage with the Jump command.  (SPOILER) Though this comes in handy when he's trying to hide his identity in the After Years as he does use swords exclusively as the Hooded Man until he becomes a Holy Dragoon and gets his ability to use spears back. Although he CAN now use Holy Swords as a Holy Dragon, he's still best sticking with spears to get the most out of his jumping.

[His Own Worst Enemy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HisOwnWorstEnemy): Kain's guilt over [his vices of jealousy and envy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreenEyedMonster), as well as what they led him to do over the course of the original game, [spurs the Dragoon to live a life of isolation atop Mt. Ordeals](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UsedToBeMoreSocial), feeling he's unworthy to face his friends until he's properly atoned. Had it not been for the actions of  (SPOILER) his [Enemy Without](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemyWithout)  in *The After Years*, there's a good chance Kain might not have come down from the mountainside at all.

[Hopeless Suitor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HopelessSuitor): He's in love with Rosa, but she only has eyes for Cecil. It's implied that [she never even realized Kain felt that way about her](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObliviousToLove) until he admits it directly atop the Tower of Zot.
[Hunk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hunk): By Japanese standards, he looks manlier than Cecil.

[In a Single Bound](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InASingleBound): [Jump](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathFromAbove), a powerful physical attack causes Kain to leap so high into the air that it takes a few turns for him to come down.

[Inconsistent Spelling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InconsistentSpelling): Was written as "Cain" in the Japanese manual, but the SNES translation changed it to "Kain." For some reason it stuck ever since (as least in English regions).

[Inconvenient Attraction](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InconvenientAttraction): Kain's love of Rosa is kept secret because he doesn't want to make things complicated and he's well aware she's in love with Cecil. Zemus exploits these feelings by controlling his mind with his unrequited love of Rosa as the main catalyst.

tropeName: I Want My Beloved to Be Happy
tropeNotes: [I Want My Beloved to Be Happy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IWantMyBelovedToBeHappy): He hides his feelings for Rosa for her and Cecil to avoid harming his friendship with the two. By the end of the game he's accepted he will never have her.
[Journey to Find Oneself](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JourneyToFindOneself): Departs on one at the end of the game, mirroring [Leon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyII).
[The Lancer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLancer): This is both his class name and his role within the story, serving as Cecil's [Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil) and rival.

[Left-Handed Mirror](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeftHandedMirror): Has a similar backstory to Cecil but different outcomes in the short term. His role as the Lancer is [a reflection](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Pun) of this.
[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): ["The Theme of Suspicion."](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V3tn5nKGvpM)

[Lightning Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightningBruiser): In *The After Years*, he is flat out **the** best party member in the game by pure stats — his HP, Strength, and Stamina are among the best in the game, but unlike a lot of other party members who can say the same, he has Speed rivaling the Eblan Four ninjas, and that's not getting into  (SPOILER) his White Magic which includes Haste, Blink, and Esuna . The only catch is  (SPOILER) you need to keep him at Level 15 as the Hooded Man so he can get the full value of his Holy Dragoon stat growth, but all you lose if you don't is lose out on some max HP, and he's still going to get the Strength and Speed regardless of level .

[Long Haired Prettyboy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LongHairedPrettyboy): He has long blonde hair, and [Depending on the Artist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DependingOnTheArtist) it may dangle out of his helmet or [have it all tucked inside it](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CompressedHair). Not to mention that beneath the helmet [he's gorgeous](http://finalfantasy.wikia.com/wiki/File:Kain_Highwind_%28colour_sketch%2C_2007%29.jpg)◊.

[Love Makes You Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoveMakesYouEvil): His unrequited love for Rosa and jealousy of Cecil were the main reasons he was able to be turned to [The Dark Side](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDarkSide).

[Magic Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicKnight): In *The After Years* (SPOILER) due to his class change to a Holy Dragoon . [Sprites](http://finalfantasy.wikia.com/wiki/File:KainSpell.gif)◊ [Dummied Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DummiedOut) from the original game suggest that Kain would have had this ability all along at one point.

[Magically Inept Fighter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicallyIneptFighter): Never learns magic but makes up for it with high physical stats and the powerful Jump ability. *The After Years* rectifies this upon  (SPOILER) his promotion to Holy Dragoon , though his White Magic is less effective compared to more specialized casters/healers such as Rosa or Porom, much like Cecil.
[Manly Tears](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManlyTears): Teach him Cry in the DS version and try it out.
[Multi-Melee Master](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MultiMeleeMaster): While he primarily uses spears, he can equip axes and certain swords.

[Murder the Hypotenuse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MurderTheHypotenuse): He tries it while serving Golbez. His "Lunar Trial" in the GBA version's bonus dungeon focuses entirely around this concept and Kain overcoming the temptation (or not, which causes a [Nonstandard Game Over](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonstandardGameOver)). In *[The After Years](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyIVTheAfterYears)*,  (SPOILER) his [Enemy Without](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemyWithout) plans to do it, but the real Kain is able to stop him .

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): Starting with the *Dawn of Souls* remake for *[Final Fantasy II](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyII)*, the boy that Ricard Highwind (the series' first Dragoon and bearer of the surname Highwind) adopts is named Kain. [This was brought full circle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RetroactiveLegacy) when remakes of *IV* had Kain mention that the name of his father (who died note  fighting an [evil empire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheEmpire); i.e. Ricard's [Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice) against Emperor Mateus in *II* ) was Ricard, although it's highly unlikely due to age—Kain tells the 17-year-old Ceodore that he was about his age when he heard news of his father's death whereas the Kain seen in *II* is merely a child, never mind [an old (and dubiously canon) Japanese guide](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual) [stating the games to be a century apart.](http://www.sceneryrecalled.com/trans/ff4comp.htm)
[Name of Cain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NameOfCain): The only instance of it for *Final Fantasy* and an iconic example of it.

[Papa Wolf](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PapaWolf): In *The After Years,* he takes a particularly paternal stance towards Ceodore - fitting, given that Kain is essentially the boy's uncle in all but blood.
[The Rival](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheRival): He's Cecil's greatest sparring opponent.
[Rival Turned Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RivalTurnedEvil): Cecil's rival that was turned to evil by Golbez's mind control, enabled by Kain's negative emotions about said rivalry.

[Romantic Runner-Up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RomanticRunnerUp): Despite being a handsome, powerful, noble man in his own right, Cecil is the one who gets Rosa's love because he's just *more* of those things.

[A Sinister Clue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ASinisterClue): [Zig-Zagged.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ZigzaggedTrope) Kain is left-handed (except in the DS version, where laterality was eliminated), and he ends up brainwashed into villainy due to his own envy, but he's not actually a villain when he's acting of his own free will.

[Troubled, but Cute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TroubledButCute): He might be fixated on Rosa, but if he ever *did* decide to move on, [he wouldn't have much trouble finding someone.](http://finalfantasy.wikia.com/wiki/File:Kain_Highwind_%28colour_sketch%2C_2007%29.jpg)◊
[Unrequited Love Lasts Forever](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnrequitedLoveLastsForever): In *The After Years*, he still holds a candle for Rosa, despite not having seen her in *seventeen* years.
[Action Mom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionMom): In *The After Years*, she jumps back into the action alongside her teenage son.

[All There in the Manual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual): Japanese guides give her full name as Rosa Joanna Farrell or Rosa Farrell, which was retained in 3D releases. [Her middle name apparently comes from her mother.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/UsefulNotes/Patronymic)
[Battle Couple](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BattleCouple): With Cecil, though the "battle" part comes a wee bit later.
[Childhood Friend Romance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChildhoodFriendRomance): With Cecil, who she's known since they were kids, along with Kain.
[Combat Medic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatMedic): She's a healer who's also able to deal out reasonable damage with her archery.

[Damsel in Distress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DamselInDistress):
    - The first time she comes down with Desert Fever, requiring Cecil to go searching for some rare medicine. The second time, Golbez invokes it by abducting her and holding her hostage. After this point, she ceases being rescued. - She gets kidnapped again in *The After Years* by (SPOILER) Dark Kain.

[Demoted to Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemotedToExtra): Downplayed in *The After Years*. While she has her moments of prominence, Rosa remains as the only party member from the original final party to not get their own Tale. She also gets this treatment in spin-offs; *[Theatrhythm Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/TheatrhythmFinalFantasy)*, for example, included Cecil, Kain, and Rydia as recruitable party members. *Curtain Call* then added in Edge, with Rosa being included too... as DLC.

[Dude Magnet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DudeMagnet): Cecil and her are already the game's [Official Couple](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OfficialCouple), Kain is secretly pining for her, and Edge briefly hits on her before moving onto Rydia.

[Fairytale Wedding Dress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FairytaleWeddingDress): As per the DS remake, Rosa opts for [a modest silver gown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SimpleYetOpulent) during her wedding ceremony and coronation.

[Generation Xerox](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GenerationXerox): [Invoked](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InvokedTrope). She wished to become a White Mage and fight alongside her lover, much like her mother did. The only difference is that Mrs. Farrell's husband was a Dragoon, and Cecil's a Dark Knight/Paladin. In another vein, her middle name is her mother's name.
[Girlish Pigtails](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GirlishPigtails): A flashback to Rosa's childhood with Cecil and Kain in the DS version shows her with this hairstyle.
[Guys Smash, Girls Shoot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuysSmashGirlsShoot): Her love is a stout warrior that favors swords and axes; she's a back-row caster that specializes in archery.
[Hair Color Dissonance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HairColorDissonance): Sometimes portrayed as more of a strawberry-blonde.

tropeName: Hair of Gold, Heart of Gold
tropeNotes: [Hair of Gold, Heart of Gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HairOfGoldHeartOfGold): She is sweet, kind, and loves Cecil deeply.
[Happily Married](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HappilyMarried): At the end of the game, she and Cecil wed and live happily together.

[The Heart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeart): The party's [moral center](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeart). [The Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHero)'s [love interest](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OfficialCouple). [The Lancer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLancer)'s [unrequited crush](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllLoveIsUnrequited). The [healer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMage). Rosa defines this trope.
[The High Queen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHighQueen): Rosa becomes Cecil's Queen when he's crowned King at the end of the original game.
[Holy Hand Grenade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HolyHandGrenade): Her endgame Holy spell, which attacks enemies with sacred energy.

[Informed Attractiveness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InformedAttractiveness): Downplayed. While certainly beautiful, her reputation as the ultimate beauty seems a slight stretch when the other female party members in the two games are also quite attractive.
[The Ingenue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheIngenue): She's pure of spirit, although she's not naive or stupid.

tropeName: Kicking Ass in All Her Finery
tropeNotes: [Kicking Ass in All Her Finery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickingAssInAllHerFinery): Particularly in *The After Years*, where Rosa trades in the leotard for more formal regalia.

[Lady of War](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyOfWar): She eventually grows into this. She's gentle and graceful, and after getting rescued she serves as the archer to the team when she's not healing allies.

[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): ["The Theme of Love."](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ueCpSVJp7PQ) Doubles as a [Breakaway Pop Hit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakawayPopHit), at least in Japan (where it is taught to music students).

[Leotard of Power](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeotardOfPower): Although the DS remake makes it resemble [Underwear of Power](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnderwearOfPower), since it's an entirely different color from the top.
[Light Is Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightIsGood): She has blonde hair, wears white and gold, and she can attack with Holy Spell.
[Mage Marksman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MageMarksman): Can use a bow in addition her White Magic.
[The Medic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMedic): Rosa is known in story as a master of [Healing Hands](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HealingHands).

[Official Couple](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OfficialCouple): She's in a romantic relationship with Cecil from the very beginning. By the end of the original game, she's married to Cecil and becomes his queen.

[Out of Focus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OutOfFocus): She doesn't get much focus in *The After Years* relative to her importance in the original game, lacking her own chapter and having relatively few lines.
[Pimped-Out Cape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PimpedOutCape): In the remake, her cape has a lace cape over it.

[Pregnant Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PregnantBadass): In the original release of *The After Years*, Ceodore is 17. *The After Years* takes place 17 years after the original game, implying she was possibly already pregnant during the game. There is one scene where she and Cecil are alone in her room and it ends with a fade to black, which many players took as the scene where Ceodore is conceived. *The Complete Collection* re-release de-aged Ceodore to 15, but included the *-Interlude-* chapter where she's playable for part of the chapter and later explicitly states she's pregnant.
[Silk Hiding Steel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SilkHidingSteel): She is physically frail but has an unyielding will.

[Spikes of Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpikesOfVillainy): [Uhh...](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AtpPSyaLgWQ) Well, now we know who the [Warrior of Light](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/DissidiaFinalFantasy) takes fashion advice from.

[Stripperiffic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Stripperiffic): Though nowhere near as much as Rydia. Her outfit has a very low neckline, and she wears sheer tights that show off most of her legs. In *The After Years*, after becoming queen, Rosa switches to wearing a full-length robe with, of all things, shoulder spikes.

[Tamer and Chaster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TamerAndChaster): In the original game, her outfit is [one that shows off her chest and legs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Stripperific), but in *The After Years* she wears a long white robe that covers her chin to toe.
[Team Mom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TeamMom): Rosa assumes this role after being rescued from Golbez.

[Took a Level in Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInBadass): For the first chunk of the game, she's very much the [Damsel in Distress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DamselInDistress). After getting rescued, however, she eventually grows into her own as a full-blooded [Lady of War](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyOfWar).
[White Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMage): Inspired by her mother, who also fell in love with her husband while healing on the battlefield.

[White Magician Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMagicianGirl): In terms of personality and story role, Rosa is one of two candidates for the [Trope Codifier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TropeCodifier).

[World's Most Beautiful Woman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorldsMostBeautifulWoman): Widely known as the most beautiful woman in the kingdom in-game, and in the sequel at age 36, and with a son named Ceodore, she's just as attractive as she was in the original. Though see [Informed Attractiveness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InformedAttractiveness) above.

[Xenafication](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Xenafication): It takes a while, but after shifting away from the [Damsel in Distress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DamselInDistress) role, she officially joins the fight and refuses to stay behind. Her late-game bows can do damage comparable to the frontline fighters like Cecil and Kain, and once she learns her Holy spell, she'll out-damage them.

[Adaptational Attractiveness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalAttractiveness): Rydia's original concept art implied she was virtually a [Wild Child](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WildChild), with a large messy mane of hair and robes made from different materials and haphazardly worn (though it's worth noting that the sprites in the SNES version didn't resemble this *at all*). When the DS release came out, her look was refined into the render shown in her profile here, which makes her a far more conventionally attractive character, which also matched the tone of the SNES sprites a little better (while incorporating their own changes).
[Badass Adorable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassAdorable): If you level her sufficiently, she can one-hit desert creatures with her little Ice Rod.

[Bag of Spilling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BagOfSpilling): In earlier releases, Rydia will forget any of the optional summons that she learned as a child when she returns. [If you're lucky](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RandomlyDrops), you might find them again. And in all versions, she completely (and [permanently](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PermanentlyMissableContent)) loses the ability to use white magic when she gets her [Plot-Relevant Age-Up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlotRelevantAgeUp), for seemingly no reason other than to not intrude on Rosa's niche in the party.

[Big Damn Heroes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigDamnHeroes): One of her iconic scenes is showing up as an adult (supposedly killed by a sea serpent a few weeks earlier at age 7), after everyone is about to die, and [kicking Golbez's ass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LookWhatICanDoNow). This was a guy who took a Meteor spell to the *face* and walked it off.
[Black Magician Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackMagicianGirl): As a child, since she only has access to the Chocobo summon (and possibly Goblin if you find the item).

["Blind Idiot" Translation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlindIdiotTranslation): A common (and likely) rumor is that her name was supposed to be **L**ydia, but she fell victim to [common Japanese-to-English transliteration problems](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Engrish) and subsequent releases kept the name since it's now iconic for her.

[Breakout Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakoutCharacter): Much like Kain, Rydia's popularity has netted her increased prominence after the original game. The Eidolons and Rydia's quest to free them are major subplots in *The After Years*, and the [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad) is an [Evil Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCounterpart) of Rydia. She joins Cecil and Kain in *[Theatrhythm Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/TheatrhythmFinalFantasy)*, and is *IV*'s sole representative in the original release of *[World of Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/WorldOfFinalFantasy)* (with Cecil being added in with the *[Maxima](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UpdatedRerelease)* update).
[Child Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChildMage): It's stated that children tend to be better summoners [because they are pure of heart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChildrenAreInnocent).

[Curtains Match the Window](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CurtainsMatchTheWindow):
    - Debatable: In Nomura's artwork she has [green](http://finalfantasy.wikia.com/wiki/File:IV-rydiaA_sd.png)◊ [eyes,](http://finalfantasy.wikia.com/wiki/File:IV-rydiaC_sd.png)◊ but in her [other](http://finalfantasy.wikia.com/wiki/File:Ffcc-mlaad_costume_mystic.jpg)◊ [appearances](http://finalfantasy.wikia.com/wiki/File:After_Rydia.png)◊ she has blue eyes. - This all stems from the original SNES release, where her child battle sprite had prominent green eyes... and her *adult* sprite has *blue*.

[Cutscene Power to the Max](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CutscenePowerToTheMax): When she's first introduced, she attacks Cecil and Kain by summoning Titan, but in the party she's not able to summon him until much later.
[De-power](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DePower): In *The After Years*, Rydia loses her summoning ability at the start of the game.

[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): She shows signs of this as an adult in the original SNES translation, although that could be chalked up to the localization team's efforts to voice her ["inner child"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LittleMissSnarker) due to the [Plot-Relevant Age-Up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlotRelevantAgeUp). Subsequent rereleases tend to focus on the "childlike innocence" angle in her dialogue.

[Depending on the Artist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DependingOnTheArtist):
    - Rydia's a bit famous for running into this *often*; her exact eye color and the details of her outfit vary between different games, artists and graphical styles. Since the DS release her appearance has mostly stuck, but eye color still shifts around, usually between green and blue, with the occasional dip into grey. - The most notable and oft-remarked-on divergence, though, stands between Kazuko Shibuya's sprites of Rydia as a child and most other depictions (including Yoshitaka Amano's own concept art of her). Across both the original battle sprites (in the SNES and GBA versions) and the *Pixel Remaster*, Shibuya consistently depicts child Rydia as wearing a knee-length blue *dress*, trimmed with golden yellow, with a matching yellow cape-slash-cloak, a pair of sandals with purple-pink lacing (which matches her armbands and hair decoration, thanks to palette limitations) and a somewhat messy bobbed haircut that ends right about at the nape of her neck. The *Pixel Remaster* even takes pains to ensure that the new Rydia field sprite matches the battle sprite precisely, which the origial SNES one could not for complex technical reasons. The DS version of Rydia (and the PSP sprites and other various derivative pieces based off that), meanwhile, depicts child Rydia with much longer hair (going past her shoulders), a yellow *sash*, similar to a sarong, around her waist, fully foot-enclosing slippers, a short green capelet... and a blue-and-green *leotard* for the outfit's centerpiece. While this is technically a little closer to Yoshitaka Amano's original concept art, it has, for obvious reasons, been somewhat contentious as an aesthetic choice for a seven-year-old ever since it debuted.

[Determinator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Determinator): After she forgives and joins up with Cecil, she refuses to show angst over any setbacks the party encounters- even becoming [The Heart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeart) to pull everyone back together after Rosa is captured. The one time she breaks is when it looks like Edge is about to throw his life away while the very-recent [Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice) actions of Yang and Cid are still fresh on everyone's minds. The DS version exemplifies this during the party thoughts after she learns Fire where everyone is thinking about how hard that must have been for her, while her own thoughts are about how she's going to make her mother proud.
[Discard and Draw](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscardAndDraw): Sacrifices her meager White Magic during her time in the Feymarch so that she can utilize her Black Magic to its fullest extent.

[Disney Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DisneyDeath): She falls off the ship after Leviathan attacks, but shows up again alive and well, [and much more older too.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlotRelevantAgeUp)

[Easily Forgiven](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EasilyForgiven): Forgiveness *from* Rydia was surprisingly fast for Cecil. Neither game addresses if she forgives Kain, but Rydia gives a [Hand Wave](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HandWave) on her return that it's been years for her and she knows there are bigger things to deal with before she starts doling out blame for what happened at Mist.
[Elemental Powers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElementalPowers): Courtesy of her summons, she has an Eidolon for every element in the game.

[Elite Tweak](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EliteTweak): Whyt, an Eidolon exclusive to the DS version of the game  <sup>* </sup>  even the PC and mobile versions don't have him . By playing mini-games, Whyt's stats can be increased, and he can be customized to use Augment Abilities available to the current party.
[Fountain of Youth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FountainOfYouth): In her post-game trial in the GBA/PSP version, she reverts back to her child appearance.

[Gameplay and Story Segregation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStorySegregation): In some versions of the game, with impractical amounts of [Level Grinding](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LevelGrinding), Rydia can eventually learn the third-level Fire spell before the cutscene where she gets over her fear of fire (which left her unable to learn the first-level Fire spell up to that point).

tropeName: Get A Hold Of Yourself Man
tropeNotes: [Get A Hold Of Yourself Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GetAHoldOfYourselfMan): Infamous for delivering one of these speeches to Edward in the aftermath of the bombing of Damcyan, due to the fact that he was a grown man and she was still prepubescent.

[Glass Cannon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GlassCannon): Capable of hitting the damage cap by the game's end, and easily the best damage-dealer after she rejoins the party. However, she can barely take a few hits before she goes down.
[Happily Adopted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HappilyAdopted): Growing up in the Feymarch, she seems to regard the Eidolon king and queen as her new parents. The feeling's mutual.

[The Heart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeart): She takes the deaths (and ["deaths"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DisneyDeath)) of teammates the hardest, despite not knowing them for nearly as long as the rest of the party did. Her breaking down in sobs over their loss is what motivates Edge to swallow his pride and accept the party's help.

[I Choose to Stay](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IChooseToStay): The ending for the original game implies Rydia chose to stay in the Feymarch and live with Asura and Leviathan. *The After Years* zig-zags this a bit — Asura and Leviathan send her back to live in Mist because she's still a human, and despite growing up in the Feymarch (and despite genuinely loving her back), they believe it's best for her to be with her own kind.
[Implausible Hair Colour](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImplausibleHairColour): Rydia stands out from pretty much every other cast member in the original game for her bright green locks.

[Interspecies Adoption](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InterspeciesAdoption): After Rydia is taken in by Leviathan and Asura, [they come to see each other as family](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HappilyAdopted).  (SPOILER) Rydia going on to adopt Cuore in turn is an ambiguous example, as the Maenads are [Artificial Humans](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArtificialHuman) made in Rydia's likeness.
[Lady of Black Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyOfBlackMagic): As an adult, she's [one of the most iconic examples](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TropeCodifier).

[Last of His Kind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastOfHisKind): Thanks to Cecil and Kain, she's the last summoner. Though going back to Mist and talking to the survivors shows that Rydia is just the last woman.  (SPOILER) *The After Years* has her adopting a Maenad and training her to be a summoner.
[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): ["Rydia's Theme."](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cGntfMa4GiU)
[Leotard of Power](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeotardOfPower): Both as a child and an adult. She wears a skirt or sash over it.
[Little Miss Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LittleMissBadass): When she first joins the party as a child.

[Magikarp Power](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagikarpPower): Downplayed but present. When she joins the party she's Level 1 with no spells, only enough MP to summon Chocobo once, and only 30 HP so she's easily killed. Once she starts gaining levels, she'll learn Blizzard, Thunder, Cure, and her pitiful stats will start growing. By the time you get to Damcyan, she's probably at least on-par with Cecil for competence. After her [Plot-Relevant Age-Up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlotRelevantAgeUp), she becomes the magical powerhouse of the game, with better stats than the other maxed-out Black Mages (Tellah and Fusoya) and several times more MP.  <sup>note </sup>  In the versions where he's playable in the endgame, Palom can match her in power, but he's the *only* one.

[Ms. Fanservice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MsFanservice): One of the earliest examples in the series. Given the only female characters to predate her were [Princess Sarah](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyI), [Maria, Leila, Princess Hilda](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyII), [Princess Sara, and Aria](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyIII), Rydia could almost be the [Ur-Example](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UrExample) if not for Maria.
[Navel-Deep Neckline](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NavelDeepNeckline): Though not as much as some, her outfit leaves the skin between her breasts bared.
[Parental Abandonment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalAbandonment): Her mother is inadvertently killed due to Cecil and Kain's actions and her father is never mentioned.

[Parental Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalSubstitute): By the epilogue of *The After Years*, Rydia serves as a mother figure to  (SPOILER) Cuore, the last surviving Maenad,  in the rebuilt Mist, though  (SPOILER) Cuore's familiarity with Edge and eagerness to play with him  suggests Edge also plays a role in raising her.

[Plot-Relevant Age-Up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlotRelevantAgeUp): [Hand Waved](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HandWave) by a [time flow difference](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YearInsideHourOutside) between the regular world and the Feymarch. While only a week or so passed for everyone else, a decade passed for her. This is a conceptually popular target for fan fiction, as the game glosses over it (due to space limitations on the original cart), but seriously, a *decade*. One has to imagine a lot happened for her!

[Random Effect Spell](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RandomEffectSpell): Summoning Asura is a bit of a gamble, as she'll cast either Curaga, Raise, or Protect (Cura in the Easy Type) on the whole party, with no way to influence which effect you receive.

[Randomly Drops](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RandomlyDrops): She has four summons that are randomly dropped at a *very* low probability (1/256) by certain random encounters, so rare that most players will never see them. Goblin is a [Joke Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JokeCharacter) and Mindflayer is only so-so, but either Bomb or Cockatrice can be a [Disc-One Nuke](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscOneNuke) if you get them early enough.
[She Is All Grown Up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SheIsAllGrownUp): Returns to the party about a decade older than when she left. The time skip was *very* kind to her.

[Squishy Wizard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SquishyWizard): Her summons will blast your enemies into oblivion, but Rydia by far has the lowest health of any of the group. If not sufficiently leveled by the time you've reached the [Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss), it's likely he'll have her face down on the floor half the time.

[Stripperiffic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Stripperiffic): As an adult. It's [probably because](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FridgeBrilliance) she was raised by summons, who aren't known for their [modesty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MonsterModesty) (when they're humanoid at all). Even more so in *The After Years*, just this side of [Fran](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyXII) for being as revealing as possible while still wearing enough to be called "clothing." The outfit gets [bowdlerised](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Bowdlerise) in the English version and more closely resembles actual cloth. The original is restored in the PSP version.
[Summon Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SummonMagic): The first named Summoner in *Final Fantasy*.

[Took a Level in Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInBadass):
    - Before Rydia goes to the Feymarch, she's a marginally effective spellcaster and summoner. She returns from the Feymarch as a demon-calling fire-spewing death-machine. Not only does she have a massive arsenal of devastating demons to summon, but she also has access to the best Black Magic spells in the game. - She takes another between the original game and *The After Years* when her stance and posture when invoking a Summon changes from slightly bent over and raising both hands forward in the original to one of power and confidence by standing straight and raising one arm behind her in *The After Years*.

[Vague Age](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VagueAge): The first game doesn't state precisely how long she was in the Feymarch, though it's evident that it's about a decade. But in the seventeen years between then and *The After Years*, she has been living at least some of the time in the Feymarch before Asura banishes her. It's therefore unclear exactly how old she is now, since the only noticeable change to her appearance is her clothes.

[Whip of Dominance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhipOfDominance): The adult Rydia wields a whip as her [weapon of choice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeaponSpecialization), to reinforce her role as a [summoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SummonMagic) who has command over magical beasts. And while she can wield whips to deal physical blows, her usual low physical stats means it's generally the worst offensive option for her in any fight and it's almost always better to just focus on her summon magic instead.

tropeName: Why Did It Have to Be Snakes?
tropeNotes:
[Why Did It Have to Be Snakes?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhyDidItHaveToBeSnakes):
    - Rydia is unable to cast Fire, and is afraid to cast it at first because Cecil and Kain unknowingly destroyed her hometown with Bombs (the monster, not the explosive device). - Her fear of fire carries into her depiction in *World of Final Fantasy* wherein she joins the twins in venturing into the fiery Valley Seven and has a panic attack when a wall of fire erupts in front of the party.

[You Killed My Mother](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouKilledMyMother): When Cecil accidentally confesses that he was responsible for the death of Rydia's mother, she angrily attacks him and refuses to even speak to him until he protects her from some Baron guards.

tropeName: You Kill It, You Bought It
tropeNotes: [You Kill It, You Bought It](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouKillItYouBoughtIt): All of her optional summons are acquired by defeating the monster in battle first, as their code of honor states not to answer the summons of a Summoner who hasn't proven him/herself worthy of controlling them. The Sylphs are an exception, but they volunteer their aid to Rydia out of concern for  (SPOILER) Yang trying to accompany the party despite the life-threatening injuries he received destroying the Tower of Babil's cannon .

[Younger than She Looks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YoungerThanSheLooks): In her *World of Final Fantasy* profile, her age is listed as 16, although her appearance makes Rydia looks more like a woman in her early to mid 20s.

[The Archmage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheArchmage): [At least by human standards.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DownplayedTrope) Sages are rare in the world of *FFIV*, so Tellah's mastery of [both forms of magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheRedMage) makes him kind of a big deal. Still, Tellah has his limits (his attempts to cure  (SPOILER) Palom and Porom  with Esuna fail miserably, for starters, though this is also because  (SPOILER) they willingly turned themselves to stone ), and his advanced age doesn't help matters.

[A Taste of Power](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ATasteOfPower): Once he gets his spells back, he'll have access to almost every spell in the game (balanced by his MP pool never growing past 90), making him invaluable for the next few dungeons. His magic comes in handy in the first dungeon you meet him in, as well. You'll eventually get casters who learn more spells in both Black and White Magic, but it'll take a while before both are in your party and they have the resources to match Tellah's magic versatility.

[Blessed with Suck](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlessedWithSuck): Tellah just learned nearly every spell in the game! Oh, but he only has 90 MP. And sometimes, leveling up will cause a few of his stats to go *down*.

[Cast from Lifespan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CastFromLifespan):  (SPOILER) He dies by casting multiple powerful spells in a row, then follows that up by casting Meteor. Not only do those first set of spells completely drain his MP, but Meteor casts 99 MP to use, and Tellah normally has a maximum of 90 MP. Even if he had enough MP to cast it, Tellah drained all of his reserves first, so he spends what's left of his life to cast the ultimate black magic spell.
[Cool Old Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolOldGuy): That magic of his can be pretty potent, especially after he remembers the spells he forgot.

[Crutch Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrutchCharacter): Of a sort; Tellah can easily solo the dungeon you initially find him in, and it's easy to start relying on him without preparing for his inevitable departure right after. Later, when he regains his memory, Tellah can easily [two shot major boss characters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitKill), provided only you get him there at full MP... which makes it awfully painful when you're suddenly thrust into a [major boss fight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WakeUpCallBoss) after he leaves the second time.

[Dangerous Forbidden Technique](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DangerousForbiddenTechnique): He seeks the ancient power of Meteor, the ultimate magic that was sealed for being too dangerous. Other characters warn him that in his advanced age, casting the spell needs so much energy he's unlikely to survive it. Note that this is only a forbidden technique for Tellah personally because he has lost too much stamina due to age. Black Mages with more vigor, such as the far more youthful Rydia and Palom as well as the longer living Lunarians can use it just fine.

[Death Seeker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathSeeker): He's fully aware that trying to fight Golbez at his age will not end well for him, putting aside that trying to cast Meteor will kill him for the energy needed to power the spell. He doesn't care, [as long as he has his vengeance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RevengeBeforeReason).

[Feeling Their Age](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FeelingTheirAge): Besides the factors listed elsewhere on this page (an inability to naturally increase his MP, stats randomly decreasing when he levels up, [the price for casting Meteor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerAtAPrice) being  (SPOILER) Tellah's life itself ), the DS version makes this more readily evident; Tellah's level up celebration is cut short by [his back popping out of place](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrackOhMyBack).

[Four Is Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FourIsDeath): He's the fourth party member (after Cecil, Kain, and Rydia) to join in the fourth iteration of the franchise. He's practically marked for death from the get-go.  (SPOILER) Despite what several other characters go through, he's the only one who joins the party that dies and cannot be resurrected.

[Gameplay and Story Integration](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStoryIntegration): Storyline-wise, Tellah just doesn't have the strength to use Meteor without killing himself. Gameplay-wise, Tellah isn't able to cast Meteor due to it costing 99 MP, and he only has 90 max. Before casting Meteor against Golbez, Tellah also casts four spells with a total cost of 110 MP. Unless you obtained an obscene amount of MP-boosting items and gave them all to Tellah, he will *always* expend more MP than he has in this cutscene. It's technically possible in some releases to boost Tellah's MP high enough that this shouldn't result in a [Cast from Lifespan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CastFromLifespan) scenario, but you'd have to know what's coming and be actively trying to subvert it. And even then, the cutscene which follows the Meteor cast plays out the same no matter what you do.
[Grumpy Old Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrumpyOldMan): Justified. First his daughter married against his wishes, then she *dies*.
[Inconsistent Spelling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InconsistentSpelling): The Japanese instruction manual gives his name, in English, as "Tella" (which also appeared in other material).

[Killed Off for Real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffForReal): Tellah is the only player character whose death is permanent. For everyone else, [Death is Cheap](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathIsCheap).

[Large Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeHam)
QUOTE "I am ready to face Golbez! I am [DOOM](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoomyDoomsOfDoom) ITSELF!"
[Mis-blamed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MisBlamed): In-universe. For some reason he realises Anna is dying and decides it's all Edward's fault.
[Old Master](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OldMaster): Tellah *did* know almost all the spells in existence, once. He's just forgotten most of them in his old age. He later gets his memory back.
[Papa Wolf](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PapaWolf): Just ask Edward and Golbez how vicious Tellah gets when Anna is harmed.
[Parental Marriage Veto](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalMarriageVeto): Tellah refused to let Anna marry Edward, so they eloped.

[Random Effect Spell](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RandomEffectSpell): Of a sort — before he officially regains his memory, Tellah has access to a command that will randomly cast one spell that's on his final spell list that he can't fully remember. Which one is cast is completely random — anything from a timely Level 3 spell that the boss is weak towards to casting a buff to magic defense against a purely physical enemy. What's interesting is that this random spell is always cast on all enemies or allies, regardless of whether the spell in question is actually a single-target spell or not.

[The Red Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheRedMage): Particularly at first, when all he can remember are the low-level spells for both White and Black Magic schools, and his stats are such that he can tank most of the encounters found when he first joins Cecil. He even primarily wears red. However, subverted later on, as remembering all of his spells, his stats actually decreasing as he levels, and his equipment not keeping up with what foes can do, he fully grows into a [Squishy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SquishyWizard) [Yin-Yang Bomb](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YinYangBomb).
[Revenge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Revenge): He wants to kill Golbez in retaliation for the death of his only daughter, Anna.

[Revenge Before Reason](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RevengeBeforeReason):  (SPOILER) After pelting Golbez with spells that cost far beyond his MP capacity to cast safely, he then blasts Golbez with Meteor, despite the party's pleas for him to stop. It costs Tellah his life from the strain.

[Senseless Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SenselessSacrifice): Played with when he finally confronts Golbez.  (SPOILER) His Meteor spell *fails* to kill him, but it does wound Golbez enough that he loses control of Kain, allowing the party to rescue Rosa before she's killed by a giant blade. Kain in turn tells the party the full extent of Golbez's plans and provides the [MacGuffin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MacGuffin) needed to continue the game.  He fails at doing what he intended to do, but Tellah's actions serve to help win the greater battle nonetheless.
[Squishy Wizard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SquishyWizard): Like the other mages in your party he will die quite quickly in the front row.
[Yin-Yang Bomb](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YinYangBomb): Is a Sage, which means he can cast both high-level White and Black Magic.

[Adaptational Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalBadass): In the original release he was a [Joke Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JokeCharacter) with weak weapons and abilities. Re-releases and the sequel buff both so he can hold his own in battle and is perfectly viable.

[All There in the Manual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual): Japanese guides give his full name as Gilbart Chris von Muir, which was retained in 3D releases. His name and the currency of the game (Gil) are related.
[Badass Cape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassCape): He dons a cape in *The After Years*, signalling his transition from prince to king.

[The Bard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBard): Both his class and what he does. He would disguise himself as a traveling bard to get out of Damcyan and see the world, and passes the time by strumming his harp. In battle, his weapons are harps and he can use the Sing command to various effects.

[Beware the Silly Ones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BewareTheSillyOnes): In *The After Years,* he applies: he'd rather spend his days playing his harp and is generally easy-going compared to the anxious Chancellor and more by the book Harley, but he's also scarily good at playing the political game and is tough enough to travel across a continent alone to save Harley's life.
[Brown Note](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrownNote): He plays a song that severely weakens the Dark Elf.

[Combat Medic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatMedic): With his Salve ability to use healing items on the entire party at once, he can heal just as well as dedicated White Mages, and with his higher-power Harps hits much harder than them. It makes him a bit of a [Money Sink](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoneySink), however, since you need to keep your item stock up for him to actually keep using five items at a time.

[Cowardly Lion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CowardlyLion): Despite his physical weakness, he doesn't leave Cecil's side until injury from the shipwreck forces him to, and even then he endures severe pain to play his lute to help him later.
[Dub Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DubNameChange): Edward's name in the original Japanese version is Gilbert.

[Fragile Speedster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FragileSpeedster): Both in the original and the sequel he's pretty fast, but has mediocre HP. Once he's trained up, however, he becomes a [Lightning Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightningBruiser).

[Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember): His stint with the party is a relatively brief one, lasting only for the very short Antlion Cave, Mt. Hobs, and the gauntlet at Fabul. He also never rejoins your party after he leaves. Averted in the GBA version, in which he does join for the end of the game, as well as the sequel where he's a full party member.
[Harp of Femininity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HarpOfFemininity): Edward the feminine Prince of Damcyan is a master harpist.

[Heartbroken Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeartbrokenBadass): The "badass" part is debatable, but you can bet yer ass that Anna's death hit him *hard*. Her [Rousing Speech](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RousingSpeech) to him did ease his pain a bit, but he's still mourning 17 years later.
[Inconsistent Spelling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InconsistentSpelling): His name in the Japanese manual is "Gilb**e**rt," but this got mangled into Gilb**a**rt later down the line.
