[Instrument of Murder](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InstrumentOfMurder): His harps act as a projectile, with musical notes instead of arrows. They have infinite ammo, unlike arrows (which have to be restocked), and can inflict status ailments for no MP cost.

[Item Amplifier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItemAmplifier): Salve. Outside of the US/AUS version (which embarrassingly nerfed him even further), he can combine healing items to treat multiple characters in a single turn. He is a competent healer, but he will burn through his inventory at an alarming rate.

[King Incognito](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KingIncognito): Before the fall of Damcyan, he was rumored to regularly go out in disguise and perform for people.  (SPOILER) He did this to woo Anna, and Tellah had no idea that the bard who had wooed away his daughter was the crown prince of the kingdom until she told him on her deathbed.
[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): ["The Melody of Lute."](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pm4UfqG2gGw)

[Lethal Joke Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LethalJokeCharacter): Edward's abilities aren't as straight-forward as other party members and his weapon of choice is embarrassing, but if you know how to use his strengths he can be very effective.

[Lightning Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightningBruiser): What he ultimately becomes after his [Magikarp Power](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagikarpPower) kicks in in the games where he can get into higher levels. He may not get the best attack stat, but his speed is through the roof, so while characters like [Cecil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MightyGlacier) are hitting for a large amount of damage, Edward is hitting for less but sometimes lapping them in amounts of turns, and if his equipped weapon happens to be advantageous against the enemy in question, well...
[The Lost Lenore](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLostLenore): The death of his beloved Anna weighs heavily on him for a long time. His character arc involves him coming to terms with her loss.
[Magic Music](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicMusic): He can cast buffs and status effects with his music.
[Magikarp Power](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagikarpPower): After Level 70, his stats *skyrocket*. This is only really applicable in the GBA version, though.

[Musical Assassin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MusicalAssassin): Well, none of his songs actually inflict damage, but they can turn things into toads for easier disposals by the others. He also uses harps as weapons.

[Nerves of Steel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NervesOfSteel): Eventually grows some *balls of steel* in *The After Years*, where he is a far cry from his old cowardly and weak self, demonstrating that he became quite cunning (outwitting  (SPOILER) possessed  Cecil) and able to hold his own in battle.

[No Sympathy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoSympathy): On the receiving end of this following the massacre at Damacyan Castle by the Red Wings. Mere seconds after Edward mourns Anna's demise, Rydia and Cecil verbally tear him a new one for wanting to remain by his beloved's side because he was too much of a coward to protect her, with Cecil going so far as to [smack some sense into Ed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GetAHoldOfYourselfMan). On one hand, [they're not exactly wrong](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassHasAPoint): Edward is the crown prince and needs to be strong for the sake of his country, so grieving can come later, especially when the party needs to keep moving to alert the other kingdoms of Baron's foul play. On the other hand, when Rydia experienced the death of a loved one, she was so overcome with emotion that she summoned Titan [in a fit of anger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnstoppableRage) to bulldoze Cecil and Kain yet finds the sight of a grown man crying for his dead lover to be pathetic and selfish. (On the other *other* hand, Rydia is only a child of seven at the time, and learning to see the world from the perspective of her newfound allies is part of her character arc.)

[Older Than They Look](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OlderThanTheyLook): In *The After Years*, [he still retains](http://finalfantasy.wikia.com/wiki/File:EdwardPSPTAYRender.png)◊ his [Bishōnen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Bishonen) appearance, even though he's *41 years old*.

[Quirky Bard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/QuirkyBard): [Trope Namer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TropeNamers) [back when the trope was named after Tellah's infamous insult](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Administrivia/RenamedTropes).

[Sheltered Aristocrat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShelteredAristocrat): Edward isn't fond of court life or the politics he is expected to perform as Prince either, but he grows into his position as a [The Good King](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGoodKing) by *The After Years*.

[Spirit Advisor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpiritAdvisor): In the form of none other than his departed love. After successfully curing Rosa's desert fever with a sand pearl, Edward goes outside that night to grieve Anna with a lament played on his harp. He is promptly ambushed by a Sahagin, only to be visited by Anna's ghost. [Before she fully moves on to the afterlife](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButNowIMustGo), Anna asks Edward to be brave without her and believe in himself, telling him, ["You are stronger than you know."](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouAreBetterThanYouThinkYouAre) Along with Tellah, Anna continues to keep watch over her lover post-mortem, even continuing into *The After Years*.

[Support Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SupportPartyMember): Before getting powerful weapons nothing he can do will actually hurt the enemies that much, but he can help the party a great deal with Bardsong and Salve.

tropeName: This Looks Like a Job for Aquaman
tropeNotes: [This Looks Like a Job for Aquaman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThisLooksLikeAJobForAquaman): In the original SNES game, Edward's musical talents are fairly useless most of the time, especially against bosses. But there is one part of the game where his musical skill saves the entire party, ironically after he's no longer in it. This happens when he uses a harp to disable the magnetic field in the Dark Elf's cave.

[Took a Level in Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInBadass): The original versions of the game notwithstanding, both the GBA and DS remakes, as well as *The After Years*, have seen Edward discard his [Joke Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JokeCharacter) status quite triumphantly. In the case of the latter, [it's more evident in the story](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NervesOfSteel), but the Spoony Bard has come quite far.
[Wandering Minstrel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WanderingMinstrel): It was during his travels that he met Anna.
[Action Dad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionDad): In *The After Years*. He may have a teenage daughter but he is still perfectly capable of kicking ass, in tandem with her to boot.
[All There in the Manual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual): Japanese guides give his full name as Yang Fang Leiden, which was retained in 3D releases.
[Bare-Fisted Monk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BareFistedMonk): He can also add claws for status or elemental damage.
[Dual Wielding](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DualWielding): Yang uses hand claws in each hand.

[Disney Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DisneyDeath): Probably the mother of all examples.  (SPOILER) When he is re-encountered unconscious in the Sylph Cave, the lead Sylph tells you that he was found at the mouth of the cave, which means that he a) survived an explosion that was meant to destroy a castle; b) somehow broke through a collapsed wall that none of your party could budge; c) fought his way through several levels of a monster-infested tower and finally d) *swam across a sea of molten lava* to collapse at the cave entrance. Alternatively, the explosion blew him halfway across the underworld, and he survived the landing.  Either way, Yang's survival is one of the most ridiculous occurrences of the trope in the franchise.
[Easy Amnesia](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EasyAmnesia): Briefly suffers this after Leviathan's appearance and works as a Baron troop. He gets his memory back after the party beats him up a bit.

[Establishing Character Moment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EstablishingCharacterMoment): The party first meets Yang when he's surrounded and outnumbered by monsters. He casually dispatches most of them on his own before the party steps in to help him beat their leader.
[Happily Married](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HappilyMarried): To his wife Sheila, who is apparently as badass as he is.
[Hard Head](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HardHead): His reaction to getting smacked by the [Frying Pan of Love](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FryingPanOfDoom) is to groggily wonder if it's time to train.
[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): The [theme music for Fabul](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M6F1wYD5cSY) doubles as his.

[Magically Inept Fighter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicallyIneptFighter): Throughout the original game and *The After Years*, Yang is, along with Cid, the only character to have no magical attacks or magically-derived techniques. And even Cid gets some weapons infused with spells. However, when it comes to physical combat, Yang is an absolute beast.

[Papa Wolf](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PapaWolf): He clearly loves his daughter and doesn't want to see her get hurt. His resulting overprotectiveness can come off a little as [Stay in the Kitchen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StayInTheKitchen), however...

[Real Men Wear Pink](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RealMenWearPink): His above-shown CGI render shows that his pants have pink polka dots... which have smiley faces drawn inside. He's also the [Bare-Fisted Monk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BareFistedMonk) of the group who, in a team of mages and weapon users, can kick as much ass with his bare fists.

[Royals Who Actually Do Something](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalsWhoActuallyDoSomething): In *The After Years*, he's King of Fabul and not only joins the fight again, but is known to still be actively involved in the training of the other Fabul monks.
[Silver Fox](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SilverFox): Not many people can still pull off a [Shirtless Scene](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShirtlessScene) past the age of fifty.
[Stay in the Kitchen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StayInTheKitchen): Always tells Ursula to stay behind while he's off fighting or exploring in *The After Years*. She never listens.
[Walking Shirtless Scene](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingShirtlessScene): He does get a sash in the sequel but that still only covers about half of his impressive chest.
[Warrior Monk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WarriorMonk): Fabul is a kingdom full of warrior monks, and he's the best.

[Wolverine Claws](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WolverineClaws): His weapon is various claws he wears on his hands, adding status or elemental properties to his attacks. Yang is notable, however, in that unlike later Monks, he doesn't *need* a weapon. His claws give him stat boosts, but the raw attack power is all Yang's, so he can go barehanded and deal just as much damage as with his claws on.

[Ambidextrous Sprite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbidextrousSprite): In the original game, he and his sister notably averted it - their world map sprites have ponytails/topknots, and Palom's always leans towards his left.

[Ascended Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedExtra): In *The After Years*. While a lot of party members have individual Tales, Palom arguably has the most fleshed-out role outside the final five party members of the original game, not only getting his own Tale, but Porom's Tale contains two flashbacks expanding on his growing maturity over the time skip and his quest to become a Sage during it.
[Badass Adorable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassAdorable): Look at that cute button nose.

[Black Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackMage): In *The After Years*, he's the strongest Black Magic user of the cast with the highest MP and Intelligence of them, surpassing  (SPOILER) *Golbez*, a Lunarian .
[Black Magician Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackMagicianGirl): [Gender Flipped](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GenderFlip), but otherwise played straight.
[Bratty Half-Pint](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrattyHalfPint): He's always cracking wise and disrespecting his elders.

tropeName: But for Me, It Was Tuesday
tropeNotes: [But for Me, It Was Tuesday](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButForMeItWasTuesday): In *The After Years*, he barely remembers boasting to a young girl in FFIV's ending. Said young girl, Leonora, has to remind him when he reunites with her 17 years later and doesn't recognize her.

[Butt-Monkey](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButtMonkey): He's often subjected to Porom's head bonks. *The After Years* then adds in a [Band](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombinationAttack), [Palom in the Sky](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrievousHarmWithABody), where he's thrown into the enemy army and electrocuted repeatedly.

[Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment): The Elder wants to force Palom to do this in *The After Years*. He thinks that teaching magic can grant Palom some maturity. In fact, Palom does learn that he's not cut out to be a sage due to training Leonora.
[Child Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChildMage): A powerful Black Mage at the age of *five*.

[Color-Coded Characters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColorCodedCharacters): Wears green with an orange cape to Porom's orange with a green cape. In *The After Years*, Palom has traded it in for a blue robe, contrasting Porom's new pink outfit.

[Combination Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombinationAttack): Before anyone else was using Bands, Palom and Porom had Twincasting as their signature move, setting off a small number of hard-hitting attacks after a sizable delay. In *The After Years*, Twincasting is reprogrammed as a Band during the twins' flashback. They actually lose the Band as they grow up and apart, but regain it during the final chapter, stronger than ever.
[Coordinated Clothes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoordinatedClothes): With Porom. They've grown out of this by the time of *The After Years*, but still share a fondness for stripes and gemstones.
[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): Grows into a very dry and sarcastic wit in *The After Years*.

[The Dividual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDividual): With Porom. At the beginning of *The After Years*, it seems that he and Porom might be growing apart, but they've reconciled by the end of the game and seem content to spend the rest of their lives as a unit.

[Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember): Palom and Porom don't last long, staying with the party for only two dungeons (Mt. Ordeals and then the Sewers-Castle Baron). They never rejoin either,  (SPOILER)  even after they're cured of their petrification. Averted in the GBA version, where they join along with all of the other guest party members (sans Tellah) near the end of the game . They're both permanent party members in the sequel, however.

[Half-Identical Twins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HalfIdenticalTwins): He and Porom are palette swaps of each other in the non-DS games; the DS version takes this one step further, and depicts them as having identical facial features. The heavy resemblence is emphasized by the fact that they dress alike. [While the twins have developed different styles by the time that ''The After Years'' rolls around](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TwinDesynch), they still have very similar facial features and statures, so they never escape this trope completely.
[Hand Behind Head](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HandBehindHead): [Done to display](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterTics) his cocky nature and youthful spirit.

[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice):  (SPOILER) The twins petrify themselves to save the party from a trap. [However, it turns out that their master was able to restore them to life.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnexplainedRecovery) He does the same trick in *The After Years* to try to keep the Crystal from the Mysterious Girl, but Leonora isn't having it and restores him, then berates him for being so quick to show off by attempting it.

[Insufferable Genius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InsufferableGenius): Palom in *The After Years* has let his [Bratty Half-Pint](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrattyHalfPint) tendencies mature into this, trading his hilarious boasts for a constant air of superiority. He's not going around declaring himself Mysidia's greatest Black Mage anymore, he just acts like it, and while it's entirely true, he's no less infuriating for it.

tropeName: Jerk with a Heart of Gold
tropeNotes: [Jerk with a Heart of Gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkWithAHeartOfGold): He constantly gives lip to everyone and is in a sour mood a good portion of the time, but a lot of it has a kindness behind it, such as when he tells a ship captain who's supplicating himself to Palom to cease with the sucking up, as the captain is decades older and shouldn't be lowering himself. He also is very loyal to Cecil in *The After Years*, refusing to believe Cecil would ignite another war for the crystals without something being very wrong with him.

[KidAnova](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KidAnova): In the original game. It comes back to haunt him in *The After Years*, when Luca is pining for him and Leonora is aware of his reputation and doesn't care for his attitude much. "Palom In the Sky" is likely their revenge for his ways as a kid.

[Left-Handed Mirror](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeftHandedMirror): He wields rods in his left hand, contrasting Porom being right-handed and using staves. In the original game, they each had ponytails/topknots, and these were similarly mirrored for them both (Palom's on his left, Porom's on her right).
[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): ["Palom and Porom."](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Sg8YfNVS8gc), shared with his twin sister.
[Love Triangle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoveTriangle): Gets in one with Luca and Leonora in *The After Years*, much to his chagrin.

[Mentor Archetype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MentorArchetype): In *The After Years*. And a surprisingly good one. How many other *Final Fantasy* characters have explained so clearly to anyone how mages work, and used that knowledge to tutor a novice on how to use a new school of magic?

[Misaimed Fandom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MisaimedFandom): In-universe. He idolizes Tellah and wants to be a Sage just like him, but he doesn't really understand what that means beyond "master both White and Black Magic." Porom has to explain to him that it isn't just mastery of magic that makes you a Sage; it's using your magic to help the people of the world, and Tellah traveled the world for decades to earn the title before he settled in Kaipo. Palom takes the news heavily but decides to keep going, though in the present there's hints he's realized he's not as cut out for it as he thought.

[The Mole](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMole): The twins reveal, when Cecil finishes his trial at Mt. Ordeals, that they weren't sent to help him; they were sent to spy on him, because the Mysidians wanted to find out what he was up to and didn't believe that Cecil had made, from their standpoint, a [Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn). When it's clear that he has, they come clean and start to genuinely help.
[Polar Opposite Twins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PolarOppositeTwins): Porom is the more rational twin while Palom is the impulsive one.
[Red Oni, Blue Oni](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedOniBlueOni): The Red to Porom's Blue. In *The After Years* he literally wears blue to further the point.
[Status Buff](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StatusBuff): His Bluff ability can power his own spells further.
[Taken for Granite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakenForGranite):  (SPOILER) The twins turn themselves to stone to save the rest of the party.
[Theme Twin Naming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThemeTwinNaming): With Porom, obviously.
[The Unfavorite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfavorite): A mild example. The people of Mysidia openly voice their frustration with him and preference for Porom, but it does't seem to faze him.
[Wonder Twin Powers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WonderTwinPowers): Shares the Twincast ability with Porom which grants access to some quite powerful spells.

[Ambidextrous Sprite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbidextrousSprite): In the original game, she and her brother notably averted it — their world map sprites have ponytails/topknots, and Porom's always leans towards her right.
[Badass Adorable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassAdorable): Sugar and spice and everything nice, unlike her brother.
[Beneath the Mask](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeneathTheMask): As an adult, Porom is concerned that she lacks Palom's drive and fears that one day, he will leave her and she'll be alone.
[Child Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChildMage): Like her brother, she's only five.
[Cloudcuckoolander's Minder](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CloudcuckoolandersMinder): She's reluctantly accepted the burden of being the sensible twin between her and Palom.

[Color-Coded Characters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColorCodedCharacters): Wears orange with an green cape to Palom's green with an orange cape. In *The After Years*, [she wears pink to Palom's blue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PinkGirlBlueBoy).
[Combination Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombinationAttack): Twincast.
[Coordinated Clothes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoordinatedClothes): With Palom. They've grown out of this by the time of *The After Years*, but still share a fondness for stripes and gemstones.

[Crocodile Tears](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrocodileTears): As a child, she weaponizes her tears against enemies, which either inflicts Confuse all enemies (SNES, GBA, PSP) or reduces their defense and magic defense (DS). It's replaced with Rosa's Pray ability in *The After Years*, however.

[The Dividual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDividual): With Palom. At the beginning of *The After Years*, it seems that she and Palom might be growing apart, but they've reconciled by the end of the game and seem content to spend the rest of their lives as a unit.

[Dope Slap](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DopeSlap): Regularly smacks Palom in the back of the head when he acts up. (SPOILER) And once to prevent Palom from [revealing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheReveal) that they were sent to spy on Cecil.
    - Note that "acting up" includes [wooing Leonora and Luca](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KidAnova). In the case of the latter (in the DS version), Porom clonks her brother extra hard and further humiliates him by dragging Palom *by his hair*.

[Every Proper Lady Should Curtsy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryProperLadyShouldCurtsy): While introducing herself to Cecil in the DS remake. As with many things, the differences in temperament between the twins are easily distinguishable.

[Gameplay and Story Segregation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStorySegregation): In *The After Years*, she saves Rydia and her companions from Titan's attack by casting the Float spell on them, she doesn't learn the spell until level 40 and by that time she'll more than likely be in her mid-to-late twenties.

[Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember): Palom and Porom don't last long, staying with the party for only two dungeons (Mt. Ordeals and then the Sewers-Castle Baron). They never rejoin either,  (SPOILER)  even after they're cured of their petrification. Averted in the GBA version, where they join along with all of the other guest party members (sans Tellah) near the end of the game . They're both permanent party members in the sequel, however.

[Half-Identical Twins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HalfIdenticalTwins): She and Palom are palette swaps of each other in the non-DS games; the DS version takes this one step further, and depicts them as having identical facial features. The heavy resemblence is emphasized by the fact that they dress alike. [While the twins have developed different styles by the time that ''The After Years'' rolls around](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TwinDesynch), they still have very similar facial features and statures, so they never escape this trope completely.
[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice): As with Palom,  (SPOILER) she petrifies herself to save the party from Cagnazzo's trap. Later, she is back to normal .
[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): ["Palom and Porom."](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Sg8YfNVS8gc), shared with her twin brother.
[Little Miss Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LittleMissBadass): A White Mage, but not many kindergartners could survive a mountain full of zombies.
[The Mole](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMole): Same as Palom, she was spying on Cecil for the Mysidian Elder, to make sure his [Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn) was genuine.

[My Beloved Smother](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyBelovedSmother): In *The After Years.* Her efforts to mentor Palom frequently cross the line from 'helpful' to 'overbearing and intrusive,' which eventually prompts Palom to push her away.
[Polar Opposite Twins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PolarOppositeTwins): In magic and personality. Palom uses Black Magic and is an arrogant loudmouth, Porom uses White Magic and is humble and polite.

[Promotion to Parent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PromotionToParent): Since they're orphans, Porom tries to guide and correct Palom in the same way a mother would. He is not very appreciative of her efforts, however.
[Red Oni, Blue Oni](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedOniBlueOni): The Blue to Palom's Red. Her pink outfit in *The After Years* really drives the trope home.
[Rose-Haired Sweetie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoseHairedSweetie): In *The After Years*, she inexplicably has changed hair color from brown to light pink, but it fits her sweet and mature personality.

[She Is All Grown Up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SheIsAllGrownUp): She's gotten very beautiful by the time *The After Years* rolls around. Cid even commented Porom could give [Rydia](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MsFanservice) a run for her money, which she denies, saying she could never reach Rydia's level.

[Stripperific](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Stripperific): Porom in *The After Years* wears a nearly see-through outfit and [no real hint of underwear under it](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VaporWear). [In Japan, this is to represent her purity,](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ValuesDissonance) Her outfit was modified to be less see-through for the American release, but it's still quite gratuitous.
[Taken for Granite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakenForGranite):  (SPOILER) The twins turn themselves to stone to save the rest of the party.
[Theme Twin Naming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThemeTwinNaming): With Palom, obviously.

[Twin Desynch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TwinDesynch): By *The After Years*, Palom essentially looks like an adult version of his childhood self, while Porom has dyed her hair pink and completely changed her style, as noted above.

[White Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMage): Similar to Palom, Porom has the best Spirit and MP in *The After Years*, making her the best White Mage, though without Leonora's Black Magic and Rosa's archery skills to give her offensive potential other than the game's strongest Holy. She also has no means of restoring her own MP due to lacking Osmose or Miracle, so while she is the strongest, she has the worst staying power.

[Wise Beyond Their Years](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WiseBeyondTheirYears): She's precocious enough that the Elder decides to use her and her brother as spies on the man who viciously attacked their town.
[Wonder Twin Powers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WonderTwinPowers): Her Twincast ability with Palom allows them to combine their powers to cast powerful spells.

[Action Dad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionDad): He has a daughter of adult age in the first game, but doesn't let it slow him down. In *The After Years*, he has a grandson, Mid, but still fights just as hard.

[All There in the Manual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual): Japanese guides give his full name as Cid Pollendina, which was retained in 3D releases. He was also said to be the creator of the airships based on his findings on ancient ruins (possibly Lunarian), but this was eliminated in the DS version.
[Boisterous Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BoisterousBruiser): He's loud, hammy, and enjoys life to the fullest.

[Cool Old Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolOldGuy): Especially in *The After Years*, when he's 71 years old and actually has a grandson. Still doesn't stop him from grabbing his hammer and jumping back into the fight.

[Determinator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Determinator): When he gets roused to do something, he doesn't back down until the job is done. He storms Castle Baron by himself over the abuse of its air force's power, and he only stops because Cecil took care of the problem first.  (SPOILER)  Later, his response to two nurses trying to stop him from upgrading an airship to help Cecil? *Press-ganging the nurses* into helping him finish the job.

[Enemy Scan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemyScan): Cid has the ability to do this without magic, which outside of the 0 MP cost is functionally identical to the Libra spell. In the 3D versions and *The After Years*, it targets all enemies, making it a bit more useful.
[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy): He is the ["Cid"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LegacyCharacter) of the game.

[Gadgeteer Genius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GadgeteerGenius): Almost anyone named "Cid" in a *[Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/FinalFantasy)* game will be good with tools to some extent. This guy is no exception.
[Genius Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeniusBruiser): He's a genius when it comes to airships, building and designing them for a living, and can easily beat things to death with his hammer.
[Gonk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Gonk): Especially when compared to most of the male party members, who are outright [Bishōnen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Bishonen).
[Heavy Equipment Class](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeavyEquipmentClass): Can use the same heavy armor as Cecil and Kain with hammers and axes for offensive options.
[Legacy Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LegacyCharacter): On a meta level. He's *Final Fantasy IV*'s version of the recurring character Cid and the first playable Cid in the series.
[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): ["Hey, Cid!"](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ehx1vUvSqgI)
[Magically Inept Fighter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicallyIneptFighter): He swings a mean hammer but has no magical aptitude.
[Mighty Glacier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MightyGlacier): He's really powerful, stronger and tougher than any other character by sheer stats, but not that handy on the speed front.

[Out of Focus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OutOfFocus): He doesn't get much focus in *The After Years* relative to other characters, lacking his own chapter and having few lines... though it's not quite as notable as Rosa, since his role in the original story wasn't as big, either.
[Parental Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalSubstitute): The PS1 version had some lines of dialogue that imply he sees himself as one for Rosa.
[Shipper on Deck](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShipperOnDeck): Likes to tease Edge about his crush on Rydia. Not to mention how much he ships [Cecil x Rosa](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OfficialCouple).

[Taking You with Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakingYouWithMe): What Cid theoretically attempts to do by jumping off the Enterprise to collapse the hole to the Underworld, causing a cave-in to take out Golbez's forces while Cecil makes an escape. Of course...

[Unexplained Recovery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnexplainedRecovery): Somehow survives detonating a bomb in his hand that manages to collapse a chunk of the earth's crust. While freefalling. [Over spikes and lava. While he was being shot at.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoOneShouldSurviveThat)

tropeName: When All You Have Is a Hammer…
tropeNotes: [When All You Have Is a Hammer…](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhenAllYouHaveIsAHammer): Literally. His special ability? A non-MP-consuming version of the Libra spell. He finally got new moves in later ports/sequels — Upgrade, which makes his hammer attack elemental, and Risk Strike, which is a *more powerful* hammer attack.

[All Love Is Unrequited](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllLoveIsUnrequited):
    - He has feelings for Rydia. She doesn't seem too interested. - Humorously, this almost backfires for him in the remakes during Cecil and Rosa's wedding. Trying to look "cool," Edge decides to pretend he hasn't noticed Rydia when she arrives to greet the newlyweds, only to recant when Rydia goes out of her way to gingerly address *him* as well. - Lampshaded in their Band, Broken Heart, where Edge sends a heart towards Rydia only for her to shoot him with arrows.

[All There in the Manual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual): Japanese guides give his full name as Edward "Edge" Geraldine, which was retained in 3D releases. Not to be confused with the *other* Prince Edward, who was given a different name.

[Badass Cape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassCape): Along with a [Scarf of Asskicking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScarfOfAsskicking). His artwork for *The After Years* implies he's wearing Rubicante's Cloak of Flame, [which can be obtained as equipment for him in the game](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStoryIntegration).
[Bare-Fisted Monk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BareFistedMonk): Not as good as Yang at it, and certainly not as good as using katanas, but Edge is capable of just using his fists effectively.
[Battle Boomerang](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BattleBoomerang): Can use them instead of katanas if you like.

[Casanova Wannabe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CasanovaWannabe): [Despite his reputation as a flirt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InformedAttribute), Edge has horrendous luck with his female traveling companions. Rydia lets him down lightly ([for the most part](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BelligerentSexualTension)) while Rosa, [who is already spoken for](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OfficialCouple), simply doesn't react.

[Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment): Out of all the cast, it's between Edge and Palom for the most noticeable shift in characterization between the original game and *The After Years*. The interval does a lot to cool Edge's temper and make him a wiser and more mature man, if still reckless and informal.

[Dual Wielding](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DualWielding): Edge wields two weapons in battle, usually katanas. For this reason he has more "ultimate" equipment than other characters, since he needs two weapons instead of one.
[Duel Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DuelBoss): The player can opt to duel Rubicante 1-on-1 with Edge in *The After Years*, which nets him the Archfiend's Cloak of Flame in the process.

[Fire, Ice, Lightning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FireIceLightning): His early Ninjutsu spells consist of Flame, Flood (ice-elemental in the 2D games, water-elemental in 3D) and Blitz (lightning-elemental attack).

[Glass Cannon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GlassCannon): He will spend a *lot* of time face-down in the dirt, even when buffed up, but his damage output is almost as good as frontline fighters like Cecil and Kain and he has much higher speed than them. This can be averted by equipping him with the long range Boomerang [(x2)](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DualWielding) and placing him in the back row for double defence and evasion. In *The After Years*, however, his HP is much better, making him more of a [Lightning Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightningBruiser).
[Good Scars, Evil Scars](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodScarsEvilScars): Picks up a vertical one running over his right eye at some point between the original game and *The After Years*.

[Hand Behind Head](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HandBehindHead): A [semi-regular quirk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterTics) of his, done either out of bashfulness or a desire to not emote. One of the most notable instances comes in the sequel when  (SPOILER) he disbands the Eblan Four so that they can live their own lives, [but the group chooses to continue serving him from the shadows](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UndyingLoyalty) . Edge tries to pass it off with a disaffected "Whatever, people," but he clearly appreciates the gesture.

[Highly-Visible Ninja](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HighlyVisibleNinja): You don't find many ninja who dress in pale lilac. Likely this is because Eblan is located in a desert, which both requires different colors to match the landscape and ensures that wearing black will cause you to overheat and die, but that doesn't explain why he keeps wearing the same outfit everywhere else...
[Hot-Blooded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HotBlooded): Very eager to charge at his enemies, and he knows how to use [the Power of Anger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BurningWithAnger), too.
[Ice Magic Is Water](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IceMagicIsWater): Reversed to the trope name in the 2D games. Flood, his Ninjustu Spell, seems like a water attack, but is ice-elemental.

tropeName: Jerk with a Heart of Gold
tropeNotes: [Jerk with a Heart of Gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkWithAHeartOfGold): A brash, egotistical womanizer with a kind heart and a *fiery* sense of justice.
[Katanas Are Just Better](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KatanasAreJustBetter): His favoured weapons are these.

[Late Character Syndrome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LateCharacterSyndrome): Played with as while he doesn't even appear until the game is practically half over and is somewhat underpowered he makes up for it with his extremely varied skillset, strong personality and the fact that in most versions Edge is the only character that joins Cecil that remains with him for the rest of the game. Except in versions where you can change your final party, Edge is with him till the end.

[The Load](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLoad): For a while at least. Edge is massively underlevelled when he joins your party, his weapons are weak, his armor is almost nonexistent, and his one spell is useless against the enemies you initially face.

[Master of All](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterOfAll): Compared to the Elban Four in the After Years Edge is basically this, as he can use all the forms of Ninjitsu while the Four have only mastered one or two skills each and refine their skills around the ones they can use instead. Some of the Bands show that Edge is even capable of using some of their special techniques not part of his regular skill list such as Zangetsu's kite tricks. Makes sense as he's their trainer as well as King and was one of the few master Ninjas of the previous generation not killed during Rubicante's attack, having over a decade to refine his skills since.

[Misplaced Retribution](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MisplacedRetribution): Despite the fact that Dr. Lugae is the person actually responsible for the death of his parents, and Rubicante is shown to be appalled by this act, Edge is still fine with killing Rubicante for it. Justifiable, as Lugae had been already killed by Cecil and his party before they ever met Edge and Rubicante made the mistake of chiding humans for being ruled by their emotions in front of Edge before the shinobi had enough time to properly mourn their deaths, leading to the quote at the top of this section.

[Ninja](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Ninja): His character class, and the tradition that Eblan is known for. Thanks to the kingdom being decimated, Edge is the *last* ninja, and in *The After Years* is trying to rebuild the ranks and make sure the teachings are not lost.

[Only Known by Their Nickname](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlyKnownByTheirNickname): Not too well known in English fandom, but "Edge" is just an alias — his real name is Edward *Geraldine*. [We think most of us would go by Edge in that case.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EmbarrassingLastName) This is also because there is already [another character named Edward](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneSteveLimit).
[Royals Who Actually Do Something](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalsWhoActuallyDoSomething): Helps his people evacuate underground and tries to take on Rubicante himself.

[Self-Made Orphan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SelfMadeOrphan): Subverted.  (SPOILER) When Dr. Lugae turns his parents into fiends, [Edge tries to reach out to them](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IKnowYoureInThereSomewhereFight). [They regain their lucidity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FightingFromTheInside), but knowing it is only a matter of time before they succumb to [their maladies](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlwaysChaoticEvil), the king and queen then decide to *[kill themselves](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSuicide)*. Being the monarchs of a country full of ninja, Edge's parents essentially committed *[seppuku](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Seppuku)*.

[Shooting Superman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShootingSuperman): He really should have known better than to attack the Archfiend of Fire with... fire. Then again, [this turns out to be a viable strategy when the party faces Rubicante for real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ViolationOfCommonSense), so maybe Edge was onto something. It's also never made clear that Edge knew about Rubicante's status as the Autarch of Flames (or even what an elemental lord is).

[Small Name, Big Ego](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmallNameBigEgo): He's skilled, no doubt, but he's far more boastful than warranted. Not to mention he seems to think he's more valuable than Rosa and Rydia when they're ordered off the Lunar Whale.

[Spot the Imposter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpotTheImposter): In *-Interlude-*, Cecil meets up with "Rydia" in the Sealed Cave and has her in his party for some time while they travel through the Tower of Babil. But when the group meets up with Edge, as soon as he sees her he can immediately tell she's a fake.

[Stepford Smiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StepfordSmiler): In the DS remake, specifically the Lunar Subterrane. Edge is as outwardly cocky as ever, but his inner thoughts are more or less *utter terror* about where he is and what they are doing.
[Throwing Your Sword Always Works](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThrowingYourSwordAlwaysWorks): He has the Throw command to hurl weapons at enemies for high damage.
[Too Awesome to Use](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooAwesomeToUse): Thrown unique swords cannot be retrieved and are gone from the game for good. This limits the ability to use this method.
[Undying Loyalty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UndyingLoyalty): Other than Cecil, Edge is the only character who never leaves the party after he joins.
[Unstoppable Rage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnstoppableRage): It gives him the power to create one *epic* "Crowning Moment of Awesome".

[Video Game Stealing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VideoGameStealing):
    - He's the one party member capable of taking items from a still-living foe. As he could steal unlimited items in earlier releases of the game, he also stands out as the best at it — enough patience, and he can get 99 of whatever the foe is holding. - This overlaps with [Impossible](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpossibleTheft) and [Intangible Theft](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IntangibleTheft) when, come the final battle with (SPOILER) Zeromus , it turns out Edge can pilfer [Dark Matter.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_matter) That's right, he can somehow get his hands on a theoretical concept that has yet to be directly observed in the universe. Edge is just *that* good.
[Warrior Prince](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WarriorPrince): As mentioned before, a ninja.

[Wolverine Claws](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WolverineClaws): Generally a poor equipment choice (you very quickly acquire katanas that are better than the best claws shortly after recruiting Edge), but Edge can also use these.

[Worthy Opponent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent): It's hinted in *The After Years* that Edge has begun to make peace with and respect Rubicante if he fights him in the True Moon's Subterrane.

[Wouldn't Hit a Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WouldntHitAGirl):
    - In *The After Years*, Edge whacks Yang awake with Sheila's frying pan, but is hesitant about using Sheila's ladle to whack Ursula awake. He gets Rydia to do it instead. - Averted for the Mysterious Girl. *-Interlude-* has him revealing that the Rydia that Cecil was travelling with was an impostor and doesn't hesitate at all fighting against her.
[11th-Hour Ranger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EleventhHourRanger): Joins the party on the moon, which is quite a ways into the game.

[The Artifact](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheArtifact): When you fight the CPU, he advises you to destroy the Defense Node, as it will heal the CPU. This is good advice in the 2D games, as the Node heals several thousand damage a turn, while the Attack Node's attack is easily managed by Rosa's healing. In the DS version, though, this information is suddenly completely backwards — the Defense Node can't even heal a thousand damage a turn now, but the Attack Node's Laser Barrage deals over 2,000 damage to the entire party, making it the bigger problem.

[Big Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigGood): Fusoya is this along with the Elder of Mysidia. He is a very wise Lunarian who possesses knowledge of magic and the universe far beyond anyone in the game, he even uses his powers and knowledge to help the party on their quest to stop both Golbez and  (SPOILER) Zemus .

[Combination Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombinationAttack): He combines his magic with  (SPOILER) Golbez  to perform Double Meteor. They keep the technique in *The After Years* and diversify it into Double Firaga, Double Thundaga, and Double Blizzaga.

[Cool Old Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolOldGuy): He's one of the oldest characters in the game (and possibly in the franchise), but is still very affable and magnanimous, as well as being a very powerful wizard.

[Crutch Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrutchCharacter): He'll fall down with two strong hits. His faint animation in the DS version literally vaporizes him into his clothes. And even if you do manage to grind enough to gain levels with him, his stat growths are pitiful (and in the DS version, *virtually nonexistent*). On the other hand, he knows all spells in the game, and unlike Tellah, has enough MP to cast Meteor *twice*. This allows him to fill a gap in the party for his brief tenure with Cecil's crew. He also can come in handy in the original version's in the one optional area you can explore with him  (SPOILER) Bahamut's Lair  Since the boss requires you to reflect his attack onto him or get wasted, having two people that can cast Reflect in the party (him and Rosa) makes it even easier to get everyone shielded when it's time compared to coming back later to fight with Kain in the party instead. Not really an issue in the versions of the game where you can select your final party instead though, as you can swap Porom back in as well.
[Good Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodCounterpart): To Zemus.

[Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember): His stint with the party ends extremely quickly; he pretty much only joins for the battle inside the Giant of Babil. There's only one other dungeon he even *can* explore with the party, and it's both short and optional — (SPOILER) Bahamut's Lair . In the Advance version and Complete Collection, where your final party isn't fixed and you can use most of the party members you've had throughout the game, he's one of only two party members you've had (SPOILER) the other being Tellah because he's dead that you can't add back into the final party, as he's required elsewhere due to the plot.
    - This is true in the After Years as well. Although he's permanent for his chapter of the game, he's the only major character that doesn't come back for the final chapter.
[Inconsistent Spelling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InconsistentSpelling): Is it FuSoYa, Fusoya, or Fu-So-Ya?  (SPOILER) KluYa experiences a similar problem.

[Luke, I Am Your Father](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LukeIAmYourFather):  (SPOILER) He explains to Cecil that he is his uncle, since Cecil's father Kluya was his brother. He also reveals that Golbez is Cecil's brother.
[Papa Wolf](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PapaWolf): One of his main motivations is to help his nephews, which forces his hand into personally going into battle alongside one to help free the other.
[Purple Is Powerful](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PurpleIsPowerful): In *The After Years*, he swaps his white robe for a purple one.

[Really 700 Years Old](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReallySevenHundredYearsOld): Fusoya claims he was there when the Lunarians first visited Earth and found the humans too un-evolved to live in harmony with them. Depending on how you take this statement and how he means "evolved," Fusoya could be anywhere from a few centuries to a few *million* years old.
[The Red Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheRedMage): He's apparently another Sage.

[Squishy Wizard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SquishyWizard): Of the three late-game casters, the squishiest — he has less hit points and defensive options than either Rosa or Rydia, neither of whom are known for their durability in the first place.

[Suspiciously Similar Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuspiciouslySimilarSubstitute): Fits the same character mold as Tellah, joining the party with all the spells in the game but with mediocre HP and too low MP to get a lot of usage out of his abilities.

[What Happened to the Mouse?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatHappenedToTheMouse): His fate in *The After Years* is left up in the air. There's a [Sequel Hook](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SequelHook) that allows a chance to explore it, but so far it hasn't been followed up on.

[Yin-Yang Bomb](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YinYangBomb): Even more so than Tellah — not only does he have every White and Black Magic spell in the game (there were a couple of missing of each from Tellah's spell list), but he even has the MP to safely cast Meteor (okay, only once, but still).

[You Shall Not Pass!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouShallNotPass):  (SPOILER) Teleports Golbez to safety in *The After Years*, staying behind to fight Zeromus's revived spirit. [His fate is left](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatHappenedToTheMouse) [unclear](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UncertainDoom), with Golbez vowing to look for Fusoya and the other Lunarians in the ending.

tropeName: And Now for Someone Completely Different
tropeNotes: [And Now for Someone Completely Different](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndNowForSomeoneCompletelyDifferent):  (SPOILER)  He’s briefly playable during his flashback sequence in the remake.

[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain): He's characterized as this in *Dissidia*.  (SPOILER) *The After Years* and his actions in the prequel *Dissidia 012* move him to firm [Anti-Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiHero) territory now that he's acting under his own will in both games.
[The Atoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAtoner): He's hugely remorseful after  (SPOILER) Zemus's control is broken and is willing to die to make up for it .
[Badass Cape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassCape): Golbez's iconic attire demands he always wear a black cape.
[Barbarian Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BarbarianHero): As  (SPOILER) the Man in Black. He even uses a [BFS](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BFS) called the Ebony Blade .

[Barrier Change Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BarrierChangeBoss): As a boss in the 3D version, Golbez uses Barrier Shift to make himself weak to one element and absorb all others. He recasts it every time his weakness is successfully struck.
[Big Brother Instinct](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBrotherInstinct): He's this  (SPOILER) towards Cecil upon being freed from Zemus' control, especially during *The After Years*.

[Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad): He's the game's main antagonist.  (SPOILER) [Actually](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeavy), he's the [Brainwashed and Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy) [Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon).

[Black Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackKnight): Black armor. Black helmet. Black cape. [Black Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackMage). (SPOILER) [Concept art](https://finalfantasy.fandom.com/wiki/File:Man_in_Black.png)◊ for *The After Years* even shows Golbez with a [ginormous](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BFS) [black sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackSwordsAreBetter) strapped to his back, presumably his exclusive Ebony Blade, but he's long since ditched the armor by then.

[Brainwashed and Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy): He's the one who pulls this on Kain  (SPOILER) and is a victim himself. For the great majority of his life he has been Zemus's puppet in destroying humanity.

[Breakout Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakoutVillain): Golbez is the signature villain of *IV* and one of the most iconic villains of the franchise, far eclipsing the *actual* [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad)  (SPOILER) Zemus  in both popularity and prominence. Remakes of the original game, *The After Years*, and *Dissidia*, each devote a lot of time to expanding and growing his character.

[But Now I Must Go](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButNowIMustGo): In the original game's ending  (SPOILER) he leaves with Fusoya to go into slumber . Then *The After Years*  (SPOILER) has him take the Lunar Whale and depart to the moon to search for Fusoya.

[Cutscene Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CutsceneBoss): Nearly all of the times Golbez is engaged in battle play out as a cutscene. The one exception is the second half of the encounter with Golbez at the Dwarven Castle, signified by his leitmotif being replaced by "Battle with the Four Fiends." Then there's the time he and  (SPOILER) Fusoya  join forces to fight  (SPOILER) Zemus on the True Moon , only Golbez himself is pit against a [Cutscene Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CutsceneBoss) for a change.  (SPOILER) One that is killed in a matter of minutes, only to rise up again and brush his attackers to the side [so that the party can face it](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BaitAndSwitchBoss).

[Crutch Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrutchCharacter):  (SPOILER) In *The After Years*. When you first set out to the True Moon, he's just shy of 3,000 HP, probably has at least an extra thousand health on everyone else and has Firaga, Blizzaga, and Thundaga. This, in tandem with Taunt to draw enemy attacks, makes him an excellent meat shield and [Black Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackMage). As well, many monsters on the moon are plain immune to lower-level magic, and Palom and Rydia won't learn those "-aga" spells until Level 41, making Golbez pretty much the *only* offensive spellcaster you have until you level them up another ten-fifteen levels. However, around the level where you're likely to end his scenario, he stops gaining spells and HP until everyone else has caught up and, in the case of spells, he's eventually surpassed by dedicated casters.

[Dark Is Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkIsEvil): He wears black armour and clothes, in addition to being a [Black Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackMage), and is the [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad). (SPOILER)  becomes a case of [Dark Is Not Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkIsNotEvil) after its revealed he's been brainwashed, and becomes [The Atoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAtoner).

[Death Seeker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathSeeker): Implied in *The After Years*.  (SPOILER) Golbez has a nightmare where Cecil kills him, and the Dark Knight accuses him of wanting to die at Cecil's hands to atone for his sinful life. Golbez might succeed in this, sacrificing himself to save Cecil from the Dark Knight, or if he survives, he seems to get over it, telling Cecil he cannot hide anymore and saying he's ready to confront his past.

[Depending on the Artist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DependingOnTheArtist): His armor is either bright blue, dark blue, or black, and the lining of his cape is either blue or red. In the Super NES release, his boss sprite had dark blue armor with a blue cape, but his player character sprite had bright blue armor with a red cape. In his DS render seen above, he has black armor and a blue cape, but his in-game model has black armor with a red cape. His *Dissidia* appearance reconciles these discrepancies by making his default outfit (based on his original concept art) dark blue with a blue cape, and his alternate outfit gives him black armor with a red cape. As *Dissidia* codified a lot of characters' designs, unless a spin-off is purposefully evoking the designs of the original game, Golbez tends to go with the blue armor and blue cape as his usual design now, with bits of black creeping in.
[The Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon):  (SPOILER) Zemus's chief servant on Earth.

[Establishing Character Moment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EstablishingCharacterMoment): After being mentioned a lot beforehand, Golbez makes his on-screen introduction during the siege of Fabul. He reprimands Kain for hesitating to kill Cecil, blasts Edward and Yang back with lightning when they try to stand up to him, and orders Kain to get the Crystal. When Rosa calls out to Kain and Cecil tries to stop her, Golbez takes note he cares for her and takes Rosa with him, leaving Kain to grab the Crystal and follow. And all of this is while evil [Ominous Pipe Organ](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OminousPipeOrgan) music is playing, complete with chords taken directly from [Toccata and Fugue in D minor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Music/ToccataAndFugueInDMinor). This immediately lets players know Golbez is an intimidating and powerful [No-Nonsense Nemesis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoNonsenseNemesis).

[Evil Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCounterpart): To Cecil; they're both Red Wings commanders and are [Black Knights](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackKnight), but Cecil leaves Baron uncomfortable with their methods while Golbez takes control of the kingdom for his own ends.  (SPOILER) In *The After Years*, they use opposing schools of magic, both have abilities that rely on drawing enemy attacks from allies, and Golbez's unique sword, Ebony Blade, draws a parallel to Cecil's Holy swords. In the original game, Cecil even reflects that since they share the same heritage, it could easily have been him that Zemus chose to control instead of Golbez . And also, just look at [their](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightInShiningArmor) [renders](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackKnight).

[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy): Aside from Darth Vader, he also has elements of Garland from the first *[Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyI)* game, being the bad guy clad in heavy armor who controls the Four Fiends and is seeking the power of the Crystals.  (SPOILER) That said, it's the *real* [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad) of the game, Zemus, who transforms into a monster, so this may be a case of [Decomposite Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DecompositeCharacter).
[The Heavy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeavy): He is the primary antagonist for most of the game,  (SPOILER) though a mere pawn of Zemus .

[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice): [Intercepts a](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakingTheBullet) [Black Fang](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitKill) intended for  (SPOILER) Cecil in *The After Years*, and may not survive it if [you don't have the proper party setup](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuideDangIt) .

[Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths): A meta example, remakes of the original game and his appearances in *Dissidia* and *The After Years* have turned him into one of the more complex characters in the *Final Fantasy IV* universe, while in the game's original release he was little more than a generic [Tin Tyrant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TinTyrant) [Evil Overlord](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilOverlord).  (SPOILER) Even after his stint of [Brainwashed and Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy) ended, he didn't show much personality besides hints of [The Atoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAtoner) in the original Super NES release.  *The After Years* takes this further during  (SPOILER) his final moments with his former henchmen, the Elemental Lords. In particular, Scarmiglione notes that even though he was hideous, Golbez looked past that and invited him into his ranks, hinting that even while brainwashed, Golbez still held some goodness in his heart.
[Hunk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hunk): In the sequel, it's revealed that  (SPOILER) Golbez is, in his own way, no less good-looking than his little brother under his own dark armor .
[Inconsistent Spelling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InconsistentSpelling): Japanese materials tend to call him Golbeza. Likely shortened due to character limit.

[Laser-Guided Amnesia](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaserGuidedAmnesia): As a result of  (SPOILER) his contact with Zemus , Golbez lost many of his childhood memories. It is only once  (SPOILER) Fusoya breaks Zemus's hold on Golbez's mind  that he fully remembers who he is.

[Late-Arrival Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LateArrivalSpoiler): Courtesy of *[Dissidia Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/DissidiaFinalFantasy)*, which centers Cecil's storyline on the fact that Golbez is  (SPOILER) Cecil's brother , and *Dissidia 012* casually reveals he's  (SPOILER) the Man in Black in *The After Years* . They used to be plot twists, now it's almost common knowledge thanks to the promotional materials for the games treating it as such.

[Left-Handed Mirror](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeftHandedMirror): To Cecil. Beyond being just the main protagonist and antagonist, (SPOILER) they are siblings and it was only luck of the draw that it wasn't Cecil in Golbez's shoes.
    - (SPOILER) Even more so in *The After Years*, as Golbez' abilities (warrior-level fighting power, [Black Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackMage) spells, a Taunt mechanism that forces enemies to attack him and Pressure, which functions like the Hold spell) are collectively a mirror of Cecil's Paladin powers. And while Cecil is right-handed, Golbez isn't.
[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): ["Golbez, Clad in Darkness."](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1_w2l_B76CU)
[Luke, I Am Your Father](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LukeIAmYourFather): It's revealed that Golbez is  (SPOILER) Cecil's older brother .

[Magic Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicKnight):  (SPOILER) In *The After Years*, he has a huge equipment draw including most of the mage-type robes and rods along with the knight-type swords, shields, and heavy armor. He also learns more [Black Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackMagic) than Cecil, Ceodore, or Kain learn [White Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMagic), including Flare and Meteor, so Golbez is perfectly capable as an attacker or mage. The only disadvantage he has compared to other Black Mages like Rydia and Palom is that he doesn't learn the [Status Effects](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StatusEffects) spells they do.

[The Man Behind the Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheManBehindTheMan): While nominally subordinate to the King of Baron, he is obviously the real force in charge from the moment he's first mentioned.  (SPOILER)  And of course, he himself is being controlled by Zemus.

[Master of None](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterOfNone):  (SPOILER) Golbez is not as effective a physical fighter nor mage as the other, more dedicated characters, but his high HP and his [Taunt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PracticalTaunt) ability make him an effective [tank](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StoneWall) as well making him one of the most versatile characters in the game.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): His original Japanese name "Gorubeeza" is the Japanese transliteration of Golubaeser, also known as the Golubac Fly, a black fly named for a town in Serbia. According to the legends, the flies were born from the body of a decomposing dragon,  (SPOILER) reflecting his fate  and likely tying into Golbez's pet Shadow Dragon. In the DS remake and *The After Years*,  (SPOILER) Zemus  takes the symbolism further by calling him "an insect birthed from womb of dragon's corpse," twisting the Mysidian Legend to refer to the Golubac Fly.
[Mr. Fanservice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MrFanservice):  (SPOILER) He is absolutely *shredded* underneath that armor, and *The After Years* showcases his physique very nicely.

tropeName: My God, What Have I Done?
tropeNotes: [My God, What Have I Done?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGodWhatHaveIDone):  (SPOILER) After he's freed from Zemus' control. Particularly the bit about leaving his baby brother Cecil to die in the wilderness.

[Near-Villain Victory](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NearVillainVictory): Came *very* close to succeeding — his plan went off almost without a hitch. He gathered all eight Crystals and did exactly what he planned to do with them. The party just stopped him as that goal was in progress.

[No-Nonsense Nemesis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoNonsenseNemesis): Golbez avoids many of the typical [Villain Ball](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainBall) traits; he invokes [Why Don't You Just Shoot Him?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhyDontYouJustShootHim) several times, stays focused on his goals and how to best achieve them, repeatedly manipulates the party into helping him, and recognizes threats and makes moves to neutralize them, preferably before they can act against him. He's also not above going about business himself when he has to, avoiding [Orcus on His Throne](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OrcusOnHisThrone). His only real lapse of logic is when he leaves the party alive at Fabul, but even that is defensible.  <sup>note </sup>  They were in the middle of a siege and he had just entered the inner-most chamber of the castle, which was defended by numbers of warrior monks that had done a good job of holding off his forces. Staying for a prolonged fight probably wasn't an appealing option, so once he had the Crystal he retreated.  The sum result of all this is  (SPOILER) his plan succeeds — despite the best efforts of Cecil and his allies, Golbez gets all the Crystals and summons the Giant of Babel.

[Ominous Pipe Organ](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OminousPipeOrgan): His [Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif), "Golbez, Clad in Dark(ness)." Notably, Golbez was the first villain to get his own foreboding theme.
[Practical Taunt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PracticalTaunt): In *The After Years*, he gains the *Taunt* command, which draws aggro onto him.
[Promoted to Playable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PromotedToPlayable):  (SPOILER) In *The After Years*, he's a party member.

tropeName: Red and Black and Evil All Over
tropeNotes: [Red and Black and Evil All Over](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedAndBlackAndEvilAllOver): [Depending on the Artist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DependingOnTheArtist).  (SPOILER) Subverted when he turns out to just be brainwashed.

[Redemption Equals Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedemptionEqualsDeath): (SPOILER) In *The After Years*, Golbez eventually redeems himself, but it may cost him his life depending on the player's actions. The novelization makes his [survival the canon scenario.](https://finalfantasy.fandom.com/wiki/File:TAY_Novel_Art_6_-_The_Creator.jpg)◊

[The Resenter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheResenter): According to the DS remake,  (SPOILER) his mother Cecilia dying from giving birth to Cecil, coupled with the earlier death of their father Kluya, clouded Theodor's mind with anger towards his infant brother, who he was previously excited to welcome into the family. Zemus promptly capitalized on the boy's negative emotions, influencing Theodor to abandon Cecil outside of Baron and become Golbez.

[Shock and Awe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShockAndAwe): His signature attack is shooting lightning from his hands, and when you fight him, he uses Thundaga.  (SPOILER) Once he's [Promoted to Playable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PromotedToPlayable), he retains this spell.
[Shoulders of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShouldersOfDoom): You'll seriously wonder how he walks in those things.
[Sibling Yin-Yang](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SiblingYinYang): Golbez and his brother could not be more different in personality or fighting style.

[A Sinister Clue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ASinisterClue): Like Kain, he's officially left-handed (thus, [preceding](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OlderThanTheyThink) [Sephiroth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVII)), but this tends to most come across as an [Informed Ability](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InformedAbility) due to his status as a mage. Also, his status as such wasn't revealed until *The After Years* (SPOILER) where he's on the side of the good guys . If you hacked him into the party on the original SNES version via the player side version used briefly in one cutscene however it shows he is indeed left handed even back then.
[Spikes of Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpikesOfVillainy): On his shoulders.

[Squishy Wizard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SquishyWizard): A most notable *inversion* on the "[squishy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GlassCannon)" part, which probably comes from his armour. It says a lot about how durable he is gameplay-wise that the team needed *[Meteor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathFromAbove)* to beat him.  (SPOILER) *And even then, it doesn't work!*  He could qualify as a magical [Lightning Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightningBruiser) if he was a bit quicker.

[The Stoic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStoic):  (SPOILER) In *The After Years*, unless the topic of discussion is Cecil, the Crystals, or the Mysterious Girl, don't expect much more than the very occasional off-hand comment. He only softens up—to an extent—when dealing with the Elemental Archfiends, his loyal (former) subordinates. It probably doesn't help that he spent most of his life under Zemus' control, leaving not a lot of space for his own personality.

[Stripperific](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Stripperific):  (SPOILER) A male example in *The After Years*, his attire is nothing but a cloak around his shoulders and waist, and several bracelets and anklets.

[Summon Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SummonMagic): His [Shadow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CastingAShadow) [Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurDragonsAreDifferent).  (SPOILER) Unfortunately, it seems to have been lost to [Redemption Demotion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedemptionDemotion) when he joins in *The After Years*. Then again, Rydia might have killed it off for good with her [super effective](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElementalRockPaperScissors) Mist Dragon during her [Big Damn Heroes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigDamnHeroes) moment at the Dwarven Castle.

[Taking the Bullet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakingTheBullet): In the battle with  (SPOILER) Cecil's Dark Knight side in *The After Years* , Golbez takes a fatal blow aimed for his brother,  (SPOILER) finally rousing Cecil out of his [Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD). [If Rosa and Ceodore aren't also in the party](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuideDangIt), [he won't survive the battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffForReal).
[Tin Tyrant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TinTyrant): Is clad head to toe in imposing black armor.  (SPOILER) You don't get to see what he looks like underneath until the ending.

[Trauma Conga Line](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TraumaCongaLine): His [Start of Darkness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StartOfDarkness) came about because of a nasty one in the DS remake.  (SPOILER) His father died from injuries at the hands of Earthlings he shared his knowledge of magic with, followed shortly by his mother, likely already weak with grief for her husband, [passing away after the birth of her second son](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathByChildbirth). In both cases, Theodor is helpless to save either of them because [he had failed to master the Cure spell](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HealingMagicIsTheHardest). Then along came [Zemus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCorrupter)...

tropeName: Used to Be a Sweet Child
tropeNotes: [Used to Be a Sweet Child](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UsedToBeASweetChild): Notably, flashbacks to his youth in the 3D versions show  (SPOILER) Theodor assuring his dying father that he was right to teach magic to humans, [even if those very same humans were responsible for his death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UngratefulBastard) .

[Villainous BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousBSOD): Implied to be the reason why he retreated after first fighting Cecil.  (SPOILER) Attacking his little brother and being ordered to finish him off seemingly shook Zemus's control, and Golbez appears to temporarily regain his senses and recognize Cecil before he retreats and lets him live.
[Walking Shirtless Scene](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingShirtlessScene):  (SPOILER) As the Man in Black in *The After Years*.

[Walking Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingSpoiler):
    - He's (SPOILER) Cecil's older brother, Theodor . This twist is one of the most well-spoiled in the franchise, especially since spin-off titles mention it without warning and make it critical to Golbez's character. - In some capacity, Golbez has a presence in *The After Years*., but how is another big reveal that also spoils the above reveal.

[Walking the Earth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingTheEarth): More like Traveling the Galaxy.  (SPOILER) If he survives *The After Years*, he heads out in the Lunar Whale to search for the Red Moon and Fusoya.

[When He Smiles](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhenHeSmiles):  (SPOILER) He's a borderline [Perpetual Frowner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PerpetualFrowner) in *The After Years*, however in the epilogue he smiles warmly to Ceodore before departing the Blue Moon.

tropeName: As Long as There Is Evil
tropeNotes: [As Long as There Is Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AsLongAsThereIsEvil): In [New Game Plus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NewGamePlus) for the DS version of *FFIV* and its ports, their malice lives on in the form of optional [Superboss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Superboss) [Geryon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeartless), a being that appears as [an amalgamation of the Four Archfiends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FusionDance) (Rubicante's head and torso, Cagnazzo's arms, and Scarmiglione's bone growths, with Barbariccia's hair as its "legs") and [has all of their powers at its disposal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllYourPowersCombined).

[Back from the Dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BackFromTheDead): True to form with [the original Four Fiends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyI), they're revived near the end of the game to plague you again. They return a second time in *The After Years*, revived  (SPOILER) on the True Moon  by the Crystals — [though not of their own accord](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwantedRevival).

[Classical Elements Ensemble](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClassicalElementsEnsemble): Scarmiglione is associated with Earth because of his link to the undead (those buried in the ground), though notably he doesn't have any [Dishing Out Dirt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DishingOutDirt) attacks. Cagnazzo is a turtle-like creature associated with Water who uses [Making a Splash](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MakingASplash) attacks, Barbariccia is associated with Wind and has [Blow You Away](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlowYouAway) abilities, like a signature ability to create a wind barrier, and Rubicante is associated with Fire and uses [Playing with Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire) attacks.

[Color-Coded Elements](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColorCodedElements): Earth-themed Scarmiglione = [yellow/brown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YellowEarthGreenEarth), Water-themed Cagnazzo = [blue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WaterIsBlue), Wind-themed Barbariccia = [green](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WindIsGreen), and Fire-themed Rubicante = [red](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FireIsRed)/orange. [Their physical color schemes also generally fall within this guideline.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColorCodedCharacters)
[Death Seeker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathSeeker): In *The After Years*, [they thank the party for defeating them](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GracefulLoser), allowing them to rest in peace once more.

[Dying as Yourself](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DyingAsYourself): Despite [not coming back in one piece](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CameBackWrong) and [being unable to do anything about it](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ICannotSelfTerminate), the Elemental Lords regain their sense of self and agency moments before they're returned to their slumber near the end of *TAY*. They even thank the party for helping restore them to a rightful state of mind, and the Elemental Lords of Wind and Fire go a step further by casting their strongest spells *on themselves* to expedite the task.
[Elite Four](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EliteFour): The quartet ranks among Golbez's strongest monsters and are personally tasked with important jobs throughout the story.

[Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn): The Elemental Lords are far more benign toward the heroes in *The After Years* than they were in the past, and are forced to fight against their will this time around. Words from Rydia and Scarmiglione suggest that the four are not only the living embodiment of their respective elements, but the Blue Planet's [very essences of nature](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NatureSpirit), [implying this was their true personality all along](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodAllAlong).  (SPOILER) Like Golbez, it is likely Zemus's influence [corrupted them](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy) into the characters seen in the original game.

[Legacy Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LegacyCharacter): To the original Four Fiends of *[Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyI)*. They're actually given the same name as the Four Fiends in the Japanese games (see [Four Is Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FourIsDeath)). The English localization for the DS established them as the "Archfiends" to differentiate them from the original *Final Fantasy* Fiends, and it's stuck into references to them in spin-offs like *[Dissidia](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/DissidiaFinalFantasy)*. The *Pixel Remaster*, however, renames them once again as "Elemental Lords".

[Power Echoes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerEchoes): In the DS version. Cagnazzo and Rubicante simply have a reverb effect when they speak while Scarmiglione and Barbariccia go full-on [Voice of the Legion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VoiceOfTheLegion).

[Recurring Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RecurringBoss): Each of the Four Fiends are fought twice in the first game; they're first fought individually as the game progresses, and then all four are fought together in the Giant of Babil.

[Theme Naming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThemeNaming): They're named after the [Malebranches](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malebranche_(Divine_Comedy)) in the 8th Circle of Hell in Dante's *[Divine Comedy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Literature/TheDivineComedy)*. Their "offspring" Geryon is something of an [Odd Name Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OddNameOut), taken from [a different monster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geryon) in the same work.

[Undying Loyalty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UndyingLoyalty): To Golbez  (SPOILER) and Zemus by extension, though not by choice . Their fealty to their former liege remains many years later, as seen when Golbez interacts with the quartet in *TAY*, all of whom are delighted to see him once more.

[Unwanted Revival](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwantedRevival): They're brought back to life in *TAY*, and none of them are pleased about it. Some of them will even damage themselves in an attempt to help you.
