[Villainous Friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousFriendship): Despite the fact that  (SPOILER) they're really underlings of Zemus, not Golbez , the kind regard they show Golbez in the sequel gives the impression that the Elemental Lords enjoyed a genuinely positive relationship with their master. It's unclear if the camaraderie was real from the start of their service or a case of [Becoming the Mask](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BecomingTheMask).

[Villain Teleportation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainTeleportation): Some members, like Rubicante, make a habit of appearing out of nowhere in a whirlwind of their personal element to challenge the party, and all four of them employ this ability when making themselves known at the Giant of Babil for the rematch.

tropeName: Because You Were Nice to Me
tropeNotes: [Because You Were Nice to Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BecauseYouWereNiceToMe): In *The After Years*, he thanks Golbez for having accepted him despite his freakish appearance, implying that this may be the reason why he chose to work with the  (SPOILER) back then brainwashed  Golbez.

[Black Cloak](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackCloak): Hides his deformity with a long brown robe that includes [a hood](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InTheHood). This leaves only [the light of Scarmiglione's eyes visible](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GlowingEyesOfDoom).
[Body Horror](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BodyHorror): As can be clearly seen above, Scarmiglione's ghastly appearance includes hideous protrusions of bone extending from both sides of his torso.

[Deceased and Diseased](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeceasedAndDiseased): He's associated with poison and other status ailments. The [Hyadain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Music/Hyadain) remix notes this, with one line going, "I'm called Scarmiglione of Earth, but I thought I was Scarmiglione of Poison?"

[Dishing Out Dirt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DishingOutDirt): Only in a thematic sense; despite being Elemental Lord of Earth, he doesn't have any earth-elemental attacks. In fact when you fight him throughout the series (including games where he *could* be given Earth attacks), all he ever uses for offensive is physical attacks, status attacks, and Thunder magic.
[Elemental Embodiment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElementalEmbodiment): Of Earth, though as explained above, he doesn't actually have any Earth attacks.

[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy): Although the Elemental Lords in general are a tribute to the [Four Fiends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyI), Scarmiglione is noted as being especially similar to the Lich, both being undead magic users, and fiends of earth, who like thunder spells.

[Freakiness Shame](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FreakinessShame): He gets to be the target of this from Cagnazzo.  (SPOILER) In *The After Years*, he hints that he suffered from this himself, and is grateful to Golbez for accepting him despite his freakish appearance.

[The Friend Nobody Likes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFriendNobodyLikes): The other Elemental Lords look down on him, especially Cagnazzo, due to a slight [Improbable Power Discrepancy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprobablePowerDiscrepancy) and a dislike of his ugly mug.

[Inconsistent Spelling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InconsistentSpelling): "Scarmiglione" was shortened to Milon prior to the *[Dawn of Souls](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/UsefulNotes/GameBoyAdvance)* [port](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VideoGameRemake).
[Kill It with Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KillItWithFire): His weakness is fire, as with all undead.

[Man of Kryptonite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManOfKryptonite): Golbez sends Scarmiglione to impede Cecil's ascent up Mt. Ordeals [because](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExploitedTrope) Dark Knights are ineffective against the undead. What he didn't seem to account for was Cecil having backup in the form of twin mages [Palom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackMage) and [Porom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMage).
[Night of the Living Mooks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NightOfTheLivingMooks): [Brings along some zombies to help.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlunkyBoss)
[Not Quite Dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotQuiteDead): Thought you'd seen the last of him when you killed him the first time? Think again.
[Red Baron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedBaron): The Blighted Despot.
[Shock and Awe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShockAndAwe): His main offense is Thunder. In *The After Years*, he upgrades to Thundaga.
[Sssssnaketalk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Sssssnaketalk): Speaks with a serpentine hiss, oftentimes drawing out his s's.
[Status Effects](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StatusEffects): He inflicts Curse and Poison on the party.

[Trick Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrickBoss): He ambushes your party from behind moments after you defeated his somewhat easy first boss form. Hope that you inverted your party formation and healed, because he's *a lot* tougher the second time around.

[The Undead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUndead): Commands a legion of zombies, and [his true power is unleashed when you kill him and he returns from the grave](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathActivatedSuperpower).
[Bald of Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BaldOfEvil): Hasn't a hair on his bright blue head.
[Elemental Embodiment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElementalEmbodiment): He's the Elemental Lord of Water, and attacks with tidal waves.

[Evil Mentor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilMentor):  (SPOILER) It's implied he's been impersonating the King for a long time, and ordered Cecil and the others to train with the Dark Sword to make them vulnerable to evil influence.

[Fake King](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FakeKing): When the party meets him, he's impersonating the King of Baron.  (SPOILER) He reveals [he killed the real king and took his place](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KillAndReplace) [long before](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadPersonImpersonation) [the game even started](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadAllAlong).
[Inconsistent Spelling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InconsistentSpelling): Cagnazzo, Caignozzio, or Kainazzo.
[Kick the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog):  (SPOILER) Though Cecil was the unwitting gopher boy, *this guy* is the reason Mist suffered such horrific losses.
[Logical Weakness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LogicalWeakness): Being based on a reptilian animal type, once could assume he's cold-blooded, explaining his weakness to ice.
[Making a Splash](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MakingASplash): Fitting for the Elemenalt Lord of Water, he can gather up water to send down as a crashing wave on the party with his Tsunami technique.

[Nice Job Fixing It, Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceJobFixingItVillain):  (SPOILER) Being the one who ordered Cecil and Kain to deliver a certain package to the village of Mist, Cagnazzo sets off the chain of events leading to Cecil's defection from Baron and his quest for atonement. That, in turn, [leads to Cagnazzo's eventual defeat at Cecil's hands](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HoistByHisOwnPetard).
[No Cure for Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoCureForEvil): Averted. He can restore his health once withdrawn into his shell.
[Puppet King](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PuppetKing): Although he plays the role of King of Baron, he's really carrying out the bidding of his nominal subordinate, Golbez.
[Red Baron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedBaron): The Drowned King.

[Slasher Smile](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SlasherSmile): His sprite has one, which gets more monstrous with each graphical upgrade. Even his [Super-Deformed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperDeformed) artwork in *[Theatrhythm](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/TheatrhythmFinalFantasy)* has it.

[Small Role, Big Impact](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmallRoleBigImpact): Though Cagnazzo is a secondary villain with limited screen time, he is personally responsible for  (SPOILER) motivating Cecil's change of allegiances and decision to renounce the ways of the Dark Knight —a fact players don't even learn until right before his [Boss Battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossBattle).

[Taking You with Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakingYouWithMe): In his dying breaths, Cagnazzo collapses the walls of the throne room's antechamber,  (SPOILER) [forcing Palom and Porom to turn themselves to stone in order to save the party](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice) .

[Yellow Eyes of Sneakiness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YellowEyesOfSneakiness): While Cagnazzo's eyes were originally [monochrome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MonochromaticEyes), his updated spritework starting with the PSP version gave him this color instead (as seen above). Very appropriate, seeing as he masquerades as the King of Baron.

[Adaptational Modesty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalModesty): Zig-zagged with the 3D releases. The FMV intro for the remakes shows Barbariccia [wearing a long-sleeved (and possibly sheer) dress and a medium-length skirt](https://finalfantasy.fandom.com/wiki/File:FF4_DS_fiends.png)◊ when seen during a [Team Shot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TeamShot) with Golbez and the remaining Elemental Lords. *In*-game, however, Barbariccia sports her usual bikini with a few cosmetic touch-ups.
[Blow You Away](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlowYouAway): Uses wind attacks like Maelstrom and Tornado.

[Curtains Match the Windows](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CurtainsMatchTheWindows): [Not always](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DependingOnTheArtist), but whenever her hair is depicted as [more of a yellowish-green](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HairColorDissonance), her eyes are the same hue, best seen with her sprites and *Dawn of Souls* artwork.

[Cute Monster Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CuteMonsterGirl): [Technically speaking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumanoidAbomination), yes, she is a monster the same as the other Elemental Lords. She's still very nice to look at.

[Depending on the Artist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DependingOnTheArtist): Her eyes, though usually green, are subject to change colors in various spin-offs and crossovers, including purple (*[Theatrhythm Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/TheatrhythmFinalFantasy)*), [citrine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YellowEyesOfSneakiness) (*Guardian Cross*), and [milky white](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MonochromaticEyes) (*Lord of Vermillion II*). Barbariccia's 3D model in the remakes instead opt for black/brown, straying closer to Amano's original artwork. Her nail color isn't too terribly consistent either, usually green (dark *or* light), purple, or brown.
[Elemental Embodiment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElementalEmbodiment): Of Wind, embodied by her tornado spin and her wind-themed attacks.

[Elemental Hair Colors](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElementalHairColors): Barbariccia's golden tresses are wispy in nature, much like air. When [shielding herself](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpinToDeflectStuff), she whips up her mane into a twister that shrouds every part of her body save for her head.

[Femme Fatalons](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FemmeFatalons): The lady's got some long fingernails. Certain games, like *Theatrhythm* and *Lord of Vermillion II*, go the extra mile and further exaggerate their length.

[Gender Flip](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GenderFlip): The original Barbariccia was a serious and powerful male demon whose name means "curly beard" and is second-in-command of the Malebranche. Here, she's a blond, seductive avatar of wind with long, flowing hair.
[Inconsistent Spelling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InconsistentSpelling): Barbariccia, Valvaliccia, Valvalecia, or Valvalis.

[Load-Bearing Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoadBearingBoss): Her death causes the destruction of the Tower of Zot, which was held aloft in the sky by her great power. (Fans assume [the debris harmlessly fell into the sea](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoEndorHolocaust).) Overlaps with [Taking You with Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakingYouWithMe), as Barbariccia hoped to trap Cecil and his friends in the crumbling edifice.

[Ms. Fanservice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MsFanservice): Aside from Rydia, she's the primary source of eye candy in the two games. The girl's ["attire"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Stripperiffic) consists of little more than a bra and a thong with a [loincloth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Loincloth).

[Prehensile Hair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrehensileHair): In a rare [spin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Pun) on the trope, Barbariccia uses her ability to manipulate her hair exclusively for defensive purposes.
[Red Baron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedBaron): The Empress of the Winds.
[Shock and Awe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShockAndAwe): As an extension of her control over air, the DS remake gives Barbariccia access to the powerful Lightning spell.
[Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut): To both Dante's *[Divine Comedy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Literature/TheDivineComedy)* and *[Barbarella](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Film/Barbarella)*.

[The Smurfette Principle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSmurfettePrinciple): The sole female of the Four Elemental Lords. That said, [she's second only to Rubicante](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NumberTwo) for good reason — she's a literal force of nature *not* to be trifled with in battle.

[Spin to Deflect Stuff](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpinToDeflectStuff): Her primary form of defense is wrapping herself in a tornado that [renders all direct attacks null](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoSell). Unfortunately, it doesn't protect her from attacks coming straight down, and you just joined up with a Dragoon who knows [Jump](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathFromAbove).

[Stripperiffic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Stripperiffic): No shoes. [Minimal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VaporWear) [clothing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChainmailBikini). [You should get the picture.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MsFanservice)
[Taken for Granite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakenForGranite): Has a petrifying Stone Touch.

[The Vamp](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheVamp): A trait that is only lightly emphasized in *FFIV* itself. *Dissidia*'s Summon Compendium describes Barbariccia as ["beguiling,"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SugaryMalice) whereas her CollectaCard in *Theatrhythm* calls to attention to both how she rules the hearts of men and her ["proud cruelty."](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Sadist)

[Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffablyEvil): He doesn't appear to hold any ill-will towards the party, nor does he [gloat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilGloating) at them. In fact, Rubicante is famous as one of the most personable villains of the franchise.

[Almighty Janitor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlmightyJanitor): Despite being Golbez's subordinate, he's actually a stronger boss than him.  (SPOILER) Justified when the Elemental Lords are revived by Zemus, implying they serve *him* and were just helping Golbez on his orders.

[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain):
    - In the first game, Type I. He's obviously working a villainous agenda, but is a personable and honourable character [who despises](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards) [redundant acts of villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForTheEvulz) and [enjoys fights with capable opponents](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpiritedCompetitor). He also has respect for those with courage. - (SPOILER) In *The After Years*, Type IV. He enables Edge and Rydia to use his signature Inferno ability to defeat Ifrit, and is only fought in the final dungeon because, like all the Elemental Lords and other characters resurrected by the Crystals.

[Artificial Stupidity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArtificialStupidity): In the DS remake and PSP port, if you hit him with certain types of attacks (such as summons) while his cloak is closed, he'll cast Blizzara on himself to heal himself. If you use those same types of attacks while his cloak is *open*... he'll still use Blizzara on himself, which will only damage him further. It's very easy to exploit this.

[Badass Cape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassCape): Serves a purpose in battle — ice attacks only hurt him when his cloak is open, when he wraps it around himself they *heal* him instead.
QUOTE ["The frozen winds of hell's ninth circle could not penetrate this cloak of flame I wear."](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBoast)
[Cloak of Defense](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CloakOfDefense): Rubicante is weak to Ice and Water attacks, but wears a cloak which heals him if he is hit by those elements.

[The Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon): While all of the group's members are dutifully subservient to Golbez  (SPOILER) and Zemus , Rubicante is presented as the "main" enforcer—especially once Kain comes back to his senses—due to being [the strongest Elemental Lord and their](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AsskickingLeadsToLeadership) *[de facto](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AsskickingLeadsToLeadership)* [leader](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AsskickingLeadsToLeadership).
[Duel Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DuelBoss): It's optional, but in *The After Years*, you can fight him using only Edge. Doing so wins his cloak as equipment for Edge.
[Elemental Embodiment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElementalEmbodiment): Of [Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire)

[Elemental Rock-Paper-Scissors](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElementalRockPaperScissors): Notable because he goes out of his way to [subvert](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SubvertedTrope) it with [proper equipment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassCape).
[Even Evil Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards): Detests and chastises Dr. Lugae for  (SPOILER) his horrific experiments on Edge's parents .

[Fair-Play Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FairPlayVillain): He heals your party completely before both battles he participates in during the original game. Rubicante believes there's no point fighting weakened opponents.
[Femme Fatalons](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FemmeFatalons): Rare male example, but his are about as long as Barbariccia's.
[Inconsistent Spelling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InconsistentSpelling): Rubicante or Rubicant.

[Kill It with Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KillItWithFire): His strategy. While the other Elemental Lords have at least some versatility in their attacks, Rubicante just bombards you over and over with fire.

[Let's Fight Like Gentlemen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LetsFightLikeGentlemen): Rubicante believes in fairness, and he completely heals your party before you fight him (both times) so you can fight with all your power. In a case of [Gameplay and Story Integration](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStoryIntegration), he does this during the fight, too — casting Fire spells while his cloak is down will heal him, and he'll respond by casting a curative spell on the party.

[Noble Demon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NobleDemon): Portrayed as honorable despite [considering humans inferior](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PunyEarthlings). The scene in which he fully heals the party before they face off serves as the trope's image.

[Not Me This Time](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotMeThisTime): Though he did lay waste to Eblan, Rubicante is quick to correct Edge when accused of  (SPOILER) killing the kingdom's matriarch and patriarch , saying [he had no part to play in Lugae's "perversities."](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards)
[Person of Mass Destruction](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PersonOfMassDestruction): Personally responsible for the destruction of Eblan, [earning him Edge's wrath](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsPersonal).

[The Power of Friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePowerOfFriendship): In a sense. After being defeated by Cecil & co., Rubicante notices that teamwork with his fellow Elemental Lords is a more viable strategy for besting the heroes than all of them attacking individually. You'd expect a rematch against the entire group, with the quartet whipping out [Combination Attacks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombinationAttack) left and right, but it's really nothing more than an impromptu [Boss Rush](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossRush), mainly due to the fact that the four Elemental Lords are too giant to all fit on the screen at once. They have a modicum of coordination, though: the order they are assembled into means that if an Elemental Lord dies before one of your weakness-hitting attacks connect, the attack will heal (or provoke a counterattack from) the following Fiend.
[Red Baron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedBaron): The Autarch of Flame.
[Spirit Advisor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpiritAdvisor): In *[The After Years](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyIVTheAfterYears)*.

[Villain Respect](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainRespect): Rubicante doesn't just view his foes with respect, he makes sure to show it. Several lines of dialogue (including his last words in the original game) are genuine demonstrations of praise Rubicante has for Cecil and friends.

[Violation of Common Sense](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ViolationOfCommonSense): Strangely, despite being the Autarch of Flame, it's never a bad idea to cast Fire spells on him. If his cloak is down, he'll respond [by healing you](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LetsFightLikeGentlemen). If his cloak (which inverts his elemental resistances and weaknesses) is up, Fire spells harm him.

[Worthy Opponent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent): Sees Edge as such. When Edge challenges him and is downed in one hit, Rubicante just notes he's brave and strong, but not strong enough, and invites him to try again once he's become stronger.

[Animal Motifs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnimalMotifs): Dragons, even more so than the original Kain. His Dragoon armor has scale patterns on it, and in the Lunar Trial  (SPOILER) Dark Kain transforms into Lunar Bahamut .

[Ascended Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedExtra): Dark Kain only took part in a short sidequest exclusive to the *Advance* release, but became a major antagonist as "Kain?" in *The After Years*.
[Black Cloak](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackCloak): How Dark Kain appears in Kain's Lunar Trial.

[Climax Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClimaxBoss):  (SPOILER) The fight with him occurs immediately after [The Reveal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheReveal) that the Hooded Man is Kain and this guy is an impostor.

[Cutscene Power to the Max](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CutscenePowerToTheMax): He makes his introduction to  (SPOILER) Porom  by  (SPOILER) slicing apart an entire pack of enemies in one hit . Immediately after this, he joins the party, and said skill is nowhere to be found.
[Death from Above](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathFromAbove): He retains Kain's Jump attack.

[Depending on the Artist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DependingOnTheArtist): In his CG renders for the PSP release of *The After Years*, he does indeed look exactly like Kain with just minor differences to his armor. In his artwork, however, he wears blue and red armor that looks nothing like anything Kain wears in any of his prior depictions.

[The Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon): To  (SPOILER) the Mysterious Girl . He's also a [Dragon with an Agenda](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DragonWithAnAgenda), as he actively cares nothing about her goals and only helps her because  (SPOILER) she's promised to let him duel Cecil in exchange for retrieving the Crystals for her .
[Duel Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DuelBoss): He and Kain fight one-on-one.  (SPOILER) In both games.
[Enemy Without](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemyWithout): He's Kain's inner darkness made manifest to act out the selfish desires he won't act upon.

[Even Evil Has Loved Ones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasLovedOnes): He retains Kain's love for Rosa. Although far more selfish about it than the real Kain, it's implied his feelings are just as strong (if not as pure); during his fight with her and Edward, any attempts to damage her will always miss, showing that at his core he just doesn't have it in him to hurt her physically.
[Evil Gloating](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilGloating): See his page quote, delivered as he returns to Baron with Rosa to kill Cecil.
[Evil Knockoff](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilKnockoff): The name should be a clue.
[Evil Laugh](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilLaugh): Lets out many when he finally has Rosa in his grasp.

[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy):  (SPOILER) Given [Riku](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/KingdomHearts) is an Expy of Kain, Dark Kain becomes an Expy of [the Riku Replica](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/KingdomHeartsChainOfMemories) in *The After Years*. He's presumed to be the real Kain for most of the story, and acts in the same manner Kain did in the original game but with exaggerated villainy. He even has a similar moment as the Riku Replica upon being defeated, where he lays dying and wonders what will happen to him once he's gone, and is implied to be absorbed back into the original being.
[Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember):  (SPOILER) For Porom's Tale in *The After Years*.

tropeName: I Have You Now, My Pretty
tropeNotes: [I Have You Now, My Pretty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IHaveYouNowMyPretty): [A picture is worth a thousand words.](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/finalfantasy/images/c/c9/FF4PSPDarkKainFMV.jpg/) Not shown in that image is the [Psychotic Smirk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PsychoticSmirk) he flashes a second later.
[In a Single Bound](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InASingleBound): Retains Kain's Jump skill.

[Interface Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InterfaceSpoiler): The game devs seem to have taken some pains to avert this and hide his ultimate status as a temporary character while designing him for  (SPOILER) Porom's  Tale, such as capping his level at 40 (the ordinary cap for temporary characters in the Tales being 20), and giving him MP growths even though he has no Bands or skills to spend MP on.

[Lightning Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightningBruiser): Much like the real thing in *The After Years*, he's got a lot of HP and Strength, and the Speed to make usage of it.  (SPOILER) Porom's Tale slightly emphasizes it — he's going to fill his ATB gauge, attack, and have it fully charged again by the time one of your other party members gets a turn .
[Love Makes You Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoveMakesYouEvil): As evidenced by his reluctance to hurt Rosa, deep down he's still motivated by Kain's love for her.
[Murder the Hypotenuse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MurderTheHypotenuse): His goal is to kill Cecil and claim Rosa for himself.

[Not So Stoic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotSoStoic): When Cecil and/or Rosa are the topics of discussion, [the ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeHam) [comes out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilIsHammy). Just see above under [Evil Gloating](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilGloating).

[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog): He's not *totally* evil, as evidenced when  (SPOILER) he rescues Porom and her party for no benefit to himself, and later tells some brainwashed guards to value their lives in spite of being controlled.
[Purple Is Powerful](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PurpleIsPowerful): In Kain's Lunar Trial, Dark Kain dons a purple version of Kain's armor,  (SPOILER) and Lunar Bahamut is primarily purple .
[The Reveal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheReveal):  (SPOILER) The "Kain" you've been seeing all game in *The After Years* is actually "Kain?", and the real Kain is the Hooded Man.

[Scaled Up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScaledUp): After spending Kain's Lunar Trial framing him for the murders around Baron, when Kain finally confronts him directly, Dark Kain  (SPOILER) transforms into Lunar Bahamut.
[A Sinister Clue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ASinisterClue): He's left-handed like Kain, but is much more evil.
[The Stoic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStoic): Being Kain's dark side, he's just like the real thing in this regard...
[Weredragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Weredragon): In Kain's Lunar Trial,  (SPOILER) [Dark Kain's true form](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel) is that of Lunar Bahamut .
[Adaptation Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationNameChange): His monster form is called "Lugaborg" in the PS1 release, compared to just being called "Dr. Lugae" in other releases.

[Bungling Inventor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BunglingInventor): Lugae's "prized" creation Barnabas isn't exactly a model of engineering. When Lugae orders Barnabas to attack, the thing clobbers Lugae himself before Lugae clarifies that he's supposed to attack Cecil and company. Barnabas also requires a constant supply of oil, or he'll blow up. Not to mention Lugae's bright idea to  (SPOILER) [install a self-destruct function](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SelfDestructMechanism) ...

[Ditzy Genius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DitzyGenius): Aside of his robotics and mechanical engineering prowess, Lugae is capable of [Creating Life](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CreatingLife) in the form of Barnabas and can convert humans, including himself, into fiends (of both the organic and techno-organic varities), suggesting extensive knowledge in the realm of alchemy. Yet, he doesn't seem to understand how his own creations work, as evidenced by  (SPOILER) his outfitting of Barnabas with a self-destruction button —an act he was completely unaware of.

[The Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon): Despite working under Golbez, the story frames Lugae as something of a personal servant to Rubicante, though he only appears to defer to Rubicante as a way to stay in the Elemental Lord's good graces.
[Everything's Deader with Zombies](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EverythingsDeaderWithZombies): His monster form.
[Evilutionary Biologist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilutionaryBiologist): Performs his experiments with the intent to create superpowered monsters.
[Femme Fatalons](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FemmeFatalons): In Amano's artwork.

[Four Eyes, Zero Soul](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FourEyesZeroSoul): His eyes are [completely obscured by his spectacles](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OpaqueLenses) and Lugae just so happens to be a madman whose brand of science disregards all sense of ethics or morality.
[Frankenstein's Monster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FrankensteinsMonster): His creation, Barnabas.

[Fusion Dance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FusionDance): If Barnabas is destroyed before Lugae, and Lugae isn't defeated very soon after, he'll merge with Barnabas to become Barnabas-Z, which is significantly stronger than Lugae or Barnabas alone.

[Inventional Wisdom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InventionalWisdom): He includes a button on Barnabas that he doesn't remember putting on.  (SPOILER)  It's the [Self-Destruct Mechanism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SelfDestructMechanism).
[Labcoat of Science and Medicine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LabcoatOfScienceAndMedicine): He is a doctor, after all.
[Mad Scientist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadScientist): The original example in *Final Fantasy*.

tropeName: My God, What Have I Done?
tropeNotes: [My God, What Have I Done?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGodWhatHaveIDone): It's implied in *The After Years* that after his death, Lugae has begun to regret his terrible misdeeds. It's enough for some party members to [almost feel sorry for him](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SympathyForTheDevil).

[Not-So-Harmless Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotSoHarmlessVillain): He seems like a bumbling comical villain when you fight him. Then you later find out [what he did to Edge's parents](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BodyHorror).
[Professor Guinea Pig](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProfessorGuineaPig): Implied due to the fact that he can turn himself into a cybernetic zombie.
[Sinister Schnoz](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SinisterSchnoz): Has a long, pointed nose.

[Sympathy for the Devil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SympathyForTheDevil): He comes close to getting this in *The After Years*, with  (SPOILER) Golbez  wondering about Lugae's potential if he had taken a different path in life.

[Time-Limit Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TimeLimitBoss): Barnabas requires regular oiling in order to continue functioning. If Lugae is defeated first, then Barnabas has to be defeated within a certain time frame or it'll explode from lack of oiling, heavily damaging the whole party. Downplayed if Barnabas is destroyed first; if Lugae isn't defeated quickly enough after Barnabas' defeat, he merges with his creation to become Barnabas-Z to continue the fight, starting with a new health bar and more powerful attacks. Finally, if neither Lugae or Barnabas are defeated within a certain timeframe, [Lugae presses a button that he doesn't remember installing on Barnabas](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InventionalWisdom)  (SPOILER)  that blows everything up, similar to if Lugae is beaten first.

[What Does This Button Do?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatDoesThisButtonDo): If the battle goes on long enough without defeating either Lugae or Barnabas, Lugae asks this, despite the fact that he *made* Barnabas.  (SPOILER) [It's the self-destruct button.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooDumbToLive)

tropeName: You Could Have Used Your Powers for Good!
tropeNotes: [You Could Have Used Your Powers for Good!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouCouldHaveUsedYourPowersForGood):  (SPOILER) Golbez  wonders whether Lugae could have been a boon to the world rather than a monster if he had put his genius to use elsewhere.
[Bad "Bad Acting"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadBadActing): According to Palom and Porom when they sense something was off about Baigan.
[Cognizant Limbs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CognizantLimbs): Both arms become snakes, which can persist even after his death.
[The Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon): To the King of Baron.
[Eye-Obscuring Hat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EyeObscuringHat): Or [helmet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolHelmet) in the case of the remakes.

[Hat of Authority](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HatOfAuthority): As part of his unique appearance reflecting his station as [The Captain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCaptain) of [the Guard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PraetorianGuard), Baigan wears a fancier than normal goldenrod helmet in the DS version.

[Interface Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InterfaceSpoiler): The party is already at maximum when he "joins." Also, in versions that gives certain characters portraits in their dialogues, he doesn't have one when he talks like other party members.
[The Quisling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheQuisling): Joins Golbez when he takes over Baron.

[Sixth Ranger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SixthRanger): Played with. He declares he shall join Cecil and help him stop Golbez, complete with a message saying he's joined the party and the accompanying fanfare. Then seconds later, [Palom and Porom realize he's a monster and he attacks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SixthRangerTraitor).

[Undying Loyalty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UndyingLoyalty): To the point of snitching to the king that Cecil is beginning to have doubts about Baron's rapid militarization and attacks on otherwise defenseless kingdoms early on in the story.  (SPOILER)  In all likelihood, he had already been turned by Golbez and was serving Cagnazzo in the guise of the king of Baron, as the true king would have not begun said attacks in the first place.
[Voluntary Shapeshifting](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VoluntaryShapeshifting): Assumes a monstrous form to attack Cecil.

[Was Once a Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WasOnceAMan): The return to Baron heavily suggests Baigan was granted the ability to turn into a fiend by Cagnazzo and/or Golbez. Cecil is the only one fooled by his ruse, whereas the other party members comment on [the evil aura surrounding Baron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DetectEvil) while picking apart Baigan's bad acting and [foul stench](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheNoseKnows). Yang muses he might've become just like Baigan had he remained under Baron's brainwashing spell.

[A.I. Is a Crapshoot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AIIsACrapshoot): They malfunction and turn on the party in *The After Years*. May also explain their actions in the original game, too; it's ambiguous if the originals were robots as well.

[Ascended Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedExtra): From a [Giant Space Flea from Nowhere](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GiantSpaceFleaFromNowhere) boss fight in the original name, to party members in *The After Years*.

[Combination Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombinationAttack): Though everyone gets Band abilities in the game, Calca and Brina's Bands specifically rely on them [combining into Calcabrina](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FusionDance).

[Creepy Doll](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CreepyDoll): *Intensely* so. Their design in the original game is very creepy to behold and it's not helped by [their theme music.](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=duXOtF32eV4)
[Dance Battlers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DanceBattler): Calca uses Jive, and Brina uses Dance.

[Giant Space Flea from Nowhere](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GiantSpaceFleaFromNowhere): When the party enters the Crystal Chamber, there's inexplicably a bunch of evil dolls there that attack you on orders from Golbez. The only indication of their existence beforehand is Luca making an offhand reference to her missing dolls.

[Guide Dang It!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuideDangIt): Unless you manage to [obtain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RandomlyDrops) a Mythril Nut, Mythril Bolt, and Mythril Spring from a Quatro Puppet, Luca will be forced to scrap their bodies to repair the Falcon and the two are [Permanently Missable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PermanentlyMissableContent) as party members. Averted in the 3D versions of the game, as the game forces you to collect those items before proceeding.

[Lethal Joke Characters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LethalJokeCharacter): They have horrible abilities, few Band skills, and the worst stats in the game, including the lowest HP growth. *However*, a determined player can farm Phase Equipment from end-game enemies, their exclusive equipment. The Phase Equipment pieces have the best defensive stats in the game, the Phase Cutter weapon has power equal to Cecil's Ragnarok, and between the five pieces, you're looking at +20 to all stats including Speed — and if you want to leave out the Phase Body for the Clown Clothes, you lose their 20 point Stamina boost but get a second 20-point boost to Speed. Hello, [Lightning Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightningBruiser)!

[Magic Dance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicDance): In the sequel, they dance to cast magic. Calca's Jive uses random Blue Magic on the enemy party, while Brina's Dance casts random White Magic on the player party.
[All-Encompassing Mantle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllEncompassingMantle): Zemus' cloak conceals his entire body save for his hands and head.

[And I Must Scream](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndIMustScream): After his plans to eradicate the human race off the face of the Earth was shot down, he was forced into hibernation by Fusoya. Only problem is, Zemus's mental powers were so strong that he couldn't actually sleep, so his only option was to be trapped for countless years in isolation and left to stew in his own hatred until, finally, he found a pawn he could control/influence in Golbez.

tropeName: As Long as There Is Evil
tropeNotes: [As Long as There Is Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AsLongAsThereIsEvil): [Trope Namer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TropeNamers). Zeromus claims that as long as there is darkness in the hearts of man, he will never truly die and can someday return.  (SPOILER) In *The After Years*, it turns out he meant it.
[Back from the Dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BackFromTheDead): In the first game, from Zemus to Zeromus.  (SPOILER) In *The After Years*, he returns as Zeromus' Malice.
[Badass Arm-Fold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassArmFold): He strikes this pose in the 3D games.

[Bait-and-Switch Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BaitAndSwitchBoss): After Zemus is revealed as the villain and the party heads to the core to destroy him, they find Golbez and Fusoya have beaten them there and kill Zemus themselves. Then his corpse starts to move and Zeromus speaks...
[Bald of Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BaldOfEvil): Sports a magnificent chrome dome.
[Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad): He's the real villain of the game, manipulating Golbez to accomplish his goals on Earth.

[Contrasting Sequel Antagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ContrastingSequelAntagonist): Unlike the past main antagonists in the series who are from a world that is or similar to earth, Zemus is an alien from another planet, who wants to destroy mankind so his people can colonize the planet and uses Mind manipulation to control people and turn them into his followers, unlike the past main villains who had followers that willingly followed them or didn’t have any.
[The Corrupter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCorrupter): Turned Golbez to evil. Some translations also imply it was actually Zemus who was controlling Kain, not Golbez.

[Cutscene Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CutsceneBoss): Your party heads down to the center of the moon to help Golbez and Fusoya defeat the Big Bad Zemus, only to arrive just in time to see them easily dispatch the villain. Cue [Zeromus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel), who [proceeds](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SubvertedTrope) to absolutely flatten everyone. Zeromus is no [Cutscene Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CutsceneBoss); it's the [Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss).
[Eldritch Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination): Zeromus is a writhing misshapen mass of pure hatred and evil.

[Evil Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCounterpart): To Fusoya. Both are Lunarians and both are alien sorceror’s that use extremely powerful magic. But while Fusoya believes both humans and Lunarians can coexist together in peace, Zemus wants to destroy humanity for his kind to colonize the planet.
[Evil Sorceror](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilSorceror): Described as one and looks the part, though it never comes into play since the first time you see him, he's busy getting killed.
[Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss): As Zeromus, he is the last opponent of the original game.

[Flat Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlatCharacter): There's not a whole lot to Zemus other than being an evil moon-man controlling Golbez from afar. He's not even mentioned until about 90% of the way through the game and his only appearance is for the final battle. Even then, he barely says anything and doesn't exhibit any personality other than being a [Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss) to fight.

[Greater-Scope Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreaterScopeVillain): He is one to Golbez, since he manipulated him by using his mind manipulation to turn him into his servant, he doesn’t fully take on the [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad) role until his reveal as the true mastermind.
[High Collar of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HighCollarOfDoom): Behold! It's even taller than his head!
[Human Aliens](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumanAliens): As with other Lunarians, he looks like a normal human, sprite proportions not withstanding.
[Kill All Humans](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KillAllHumans): His goal is to do just this, so the Lunarians can seize the Earth.
[Made of Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadeOfEvil): Zeromus is hatred incarnate.
[The Man Behind the Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheManBehindTheMan): The manipulator behind Golbez's schemes.
[Mind Rape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindRape): He did this to Golbez while Golbez was still a child.

[More than Mind Control](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoreThanMindControl): In the DS version, it's implied he wasn't directly controlling Golbez, but instead exploited and cultivated the growth of his negative emotions to turn him evil. It's also hinted that, possibly in addition to this, he impressed his thoughts and goals onto Golbez's mind like they were his own, in a sense *merging* their minds instead of just controlling him.

tropeName: My Death Is Just the Beginning
tropeNotes: [My Death Is Just the Beginning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyDeathIsJustTheBeginning): Says as much to Golbez and Fusoya after they first kill him. And sure enough, his hatred manifests itself as Zeromus mere *moments* after his death.

[One-Winged Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel): He starts as a bald, blue floating guy, changes to an indistinct blue smokey ghost, to a massive, freakish crustacean insect... [thing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BuffySpeak).

[Oni](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Oni): His initial Zeromus form is a ghostly entity with a demonic visage, long horn-like appendages and a mane of wild hair which resembles a classical Oni representation. Furthermore, it is fueled by hatred and grudge, feelings usually associated to Oni in folklore.

[Our Centaurs Are Different](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurCentaursAreDifferent): In the Easy Type version of the game, his [One-Winged Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel) form is an enormous, crustacean-like centaur that wields a sword. This version would be recycled in later versions of the game as [Zeromus EG](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Superboss).

[The Paragon Always Rebels](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheParagonAlwaysRebels): He is said to be the cream of the crop among the Lunarian sages, which is why even after he was forcibly sealed in stasis his mind is awake and (more importantly) dangerous.

[The Power of Hate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePowerOfHate): Zemus's intense hatred for mankind is what transforms him post-mortem into the [Eldritch Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination) Zeromus. There are also a pair of enemy types in the final dungeon that are implied to have been [spawned from his malice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeartless).

[Physical God](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PhysicalGod): As Zeromus his powers skyrocketed to the point where he proclaims himself as Zemus’ hatred and the attacks used by Fusoya and Golbez did nothing to him.
[Psychic Powers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PsychicPowers): His immense mental abilities are how he controls Golbez.

[Puny Earthlings](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PunyEarthlings): He is the last of the radical sect of the Lunarians who believed it was not worth waiting for the inferior humans to evolve to the same level of Lunarians so they might coexist.

[Sealed Evil in a Can](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SealedEvilInACan): His physical body is this for the majority of *IV*. His malice was sealed by the Lunarian crystals after *IV*, then  (SPOILER) set loose by the actions of the Mysterious Girl in *The After Years* .

[Signature Move](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SignatureMove): Big Bang. It deals considerable damage to every member of the party and inflicts the "Sap" status. The Zeromus Esper in the Ivalice games inherits it.
[Superior Species](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperiorSpecies): Part of his entire motivation.
[Voice of the Legion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VoiceOfTheLegion): Zeromus speaks with a lot of echo in the DS version.

tropeName: When All You Have Is a Hammer…
tropeNotes: [When All You Have Is a Hammer…](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhenAllYouHaveIsAHammer): Zeromus' AI script in non-3D versions of the game is very simple; spam his Big Bang attack over and over, occasionally swapping in another Black Magic attack every few turns. Being that Big Bang hits tremendously strong, it's all he needs to do to be formidable.

[Would Hurt a Child](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WouldHurtAChild): Zemus took advantage of Golbez's then-fresh bereavement of both of his parents and rage towards Cecil to bring him [under his thrall](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindRape), all while Golbez was only a child.

tropeName: You Could Have Used Your Powers for Good!
tropeNotes: [You Could Have Used Your Powers for Good!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouCouldHaveUsedYourPowersForGood): Commented on by Fusoya; if Zemus had used his incredible powers for good, he could have been a great man.
[Action Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionGirl): She can hit as hard as people like Cid and Cecil, and she's always up for going on monster patrols.
[Ambiguously Brown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguouslyBrown): She's also the only dwarf whose face isn't obscured by a beard or helmet, showing this skin tone.
[The Apprentice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheApprentice): She's studying airship engineering under Cid.
[Art Evolution](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArtEvolution): Her appearance in the sequel is quite different from the base game.
[Ascended Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedExtra): A minor character in the original game, she is upgraded to a playable character in the sequel.

[Berserk Button](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BerserkButton): Do *not* touch her dolls. Even when they've gone haywire and are attacking her, she gives Rydia an order not to harm them — she'll deal with them alone.

[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy): Of a certain other [Gadgeteer Genius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GadgeteerGenius) named [Lucca](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/ChronoTrigger). Though, this is a bit of an odd example, as Luca appeared in *FFIV* before *Chrono Trigger* existed, but had little personality and no combat abilities until *The After Years*.
[Gadgeteer Genius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GadgeteerGenius): According to Cid, Luca is even more proficient with machines than he is — and consider all he does for you in the base game!
[Goggles Do Nothing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GogglesDoNothing): She has a pair hanging around her neck, likely for protection when doing mechanical work.
[Hopeless Suitor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HopelessSuitor): For Palom. She adores him thanks to him flirting with her as a kid, but he's grown to the point he's just put off by her advances.
[Mighty Glacier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MightyGlacier): She's very slow, but has a lot of power.

[Odd Friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OddFriendship): In The After Years, the [Wrench Wench](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WrenchWench) princess of the dwarves forms a [Platonic Life-Partners](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlatonicLifePartners) dynamic with Rydia, the summoner from Mist.

tropeName: Our Dwarves Are All the Same
tropeNotes: [Our Dwarves Are All the Same](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurDwarvesAreAllTheSame): Averted, she looks and acts quite different from both the other in-game dwarves and from what fictional dwarves are usually depicted like.
[Pint-Sized Powerhouse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PintSizedPowerhouse): As a dwarf she's smaller than a lot of your party members. She still hits harder than many of them.

[Rebellious Princess](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RebelliousPrincess): Of a sort. Giott seems to have no problem with her choice of life path, but it's a far cry from the typical royal upbringing he would have chosen for her himself. She may be a Princess, but she kicks a lot of ass.
[Royals Who Actually Do Something](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalsWhoActuallyDoSomething): Like a lot of your party.
[Stone Wall](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StoneWall): Slow but very tanky. It's not uncommon to see her take 1 HP of damage.

[Throwing Your Sword Always Works](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThrowingYourSwordAlwaysWorks): Big Throw involves throwing her hammer at an opponent. Some of her weapons are thrown normally, like the Tomahawk.
[Wrench Wench](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WrenchWench): She's a master mechanic and airship pilot, and also creates and maintains her robotic dolls.

[All There in the Manual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual): The Japanese-exclusive novelizations of *Final Fantasy IV* give him the name "Minwu" (referencing the character of the same name from *[Final Fantasy II](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyII)*).
[Big Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigGood): Along with Fusoya, he is the major leader of the forces of good in the game.

tropeName: Clap Your Hands If You Believe
tropeNotes: [Clap Your Hands If You Believe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClapYourHandsIfYouBelieve): Leads other characters in a round of hopeful prayer for aid against the villains. Twice. It works both times too.
[Everyone Calls Him "Barkeep"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryoneCallsHimBarkeep): "Elder". Even when he's temporarily playable in *The After Years*, he has no actual name.
[Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember): He is playable for exactly one battle in *The After Years*...
[Parental Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalSubstitute): In lieu of actual parents, he raises Palom and Porom.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): Unlike the other Mysidians who spit at the sight of him, the Elder is willing to hear Cecil out and give him a chance at redemption.  (SPOILER) He's also not so stupid as to instantly believe Cecil is reformed and sends two mages with him to spy on him and make sure he's sincere.
[White Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMage): When he takes the field in *The After Years*, he only knows White Magic.

tropeName: Our Dwarves Are All the Same
tropeNotes: [Our Dwarves Are All the Same](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurDwarvesAreAllTheSame): He's not much different from other dwarves aside from his robes.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): He's instantly accepting that Cecil is here to help, readily aids him however he can, and sends his forces to aid the party in attacking the Tower of Babil.
[Wham Line](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhamLine): When Golbez seizes the last Crystal, Giott claims they're all doomed.  (SPOILER) Unless the legend of the Lunar Whale comes true.
[Action Mom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionMom): When forced into action, that is.
[All There in the Manual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual): Originally, Japanese guides gave her name as "Ursula", which was later given to her daughter.

[Frying Pan of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FryingPanOfDoom): It can keep away a legion of monsters.
    - She gives it to the party in *The After Years* to force Yang to wake up. A ladle is also provided for her daughter.
[Happily Married](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HappilyMarried): Hints of frying-pan related violence aside, she and Yang are happy together.

[Minored in Ass-Kicking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MinoredInAsskicking): She may not be a [Bare-Fisted Monk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BareFistedMonk) like Yang and Ursula, but Sheila can be deadly when the situation calls for it.
[Mundane Utility](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MundaneUtility): She gives the party the strongest thrown weapon in the game: a simple kitchen knife.
[No Name Given](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoNameGiven): In the original game, she was just "Yang's Wife"; it wasn't until *TAY* that she received a proper name.
[Pregnant Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PregnantBadass): She may have already been pregnant with Ursula when she was smashing mooks with her frying pan during the invasion of Fabul.

[Southern Belle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SouthernBelle): She's [given this characterization](http://legendsoflocalization.com/final-fantasy-iv/fabul/#yangwife) in the PSOne, GBA and PSP versions of *FFIV*. This is [a clever way to render the easygoing yet headstrong speech pattern she has in Japanese into English](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AccentAdaptation), but stands out as being very out of place given that she lives in [Fabul](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImperialChina). Appropriately, she doesn't talk this way in any other rendition of the game.

[Anti-Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiHero): He never does anything particularly ambiguous, but Biggs is very hard on Ceodore, and at one point slaps him hard across the face. Downplayed in that he's really being [Cruel to Be Kind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CruelToBeKind).

[Ascended Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedExtra): They are the two soldiers who questioned Cecil about taking the Water Crystal from Mysidia at the beginning of the original game. In *The After Years* they got names and personalities.
[Black Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackMage): Biggs knows several basic Black Magic spells.
[Combination Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombinationAttack): They introduce the concept of Band abilities by showing off their own, Vibra Edge.

[Crutch Characters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrutchCharacter): While they're a much higher level than him, they don't gain XP during Ceodore's initial dungeon; they're just there so the kid doesn't need to fight his way through the dungeon alone.

[Drill Sergeant Nasty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrillSergeantNasty): Biggs, so very much. His [Establishing Character Moment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EstablishingCharacterMoment) is to snap at Ceodore that his royal bloodline is meaningless and he won't be considered a knight until he passes his trial of knighthood, and then to hit Ceodore for *agreeing with him*.

[Foils](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil): Biggs is an aggressive [Drill Sergeant Nasty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrillSergeantNasty) who thinks Ceodore's royal blood is worthless and uses [Black Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackMagic); Wedge is polite and friendly, believes Ceodore's lineage makes him more likely to succeed and uses [White Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMagic).
[Guest Star Party Members](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember): They're only around for the first chapter.
[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice):  (SPOILER) Biggs covers Ceodore when their ship is taken down and uses his last words to order him to return to Baron.

[Magic Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicKnight): Both of them know some basic magic as well as being physical fighters. Wedge is also a [Combat Medic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatMedic) since his spells are curative.

[Mauve Shirt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MauveShirt): Right up until their deaths and long afterwards, they contribute barely anything to the major overreaching plot but prove important to Ceodore's personal [Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment).

[Mentor Archetype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MentorArchetype): To Ceodore, as the commanding officer during his [Rite of Passage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RiteOfPassage) and his [Number Two](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NumberTwo).
[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): Named after the recurring pair of characters in the series. And in true tradition, they don't make it to the credits alive.

[Nature Versus Nurture](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NatureVersusNurture): Biggs tells Ceodore upfront that as far as he's concerned, the prince's royal blood is worthless and he won't be considered a Red Wings soldier until his actions prove him worthy. Wedge, on the other hand, is quick to praise Ceodore, and actually considers him *more* likely to succeed because of his parentage.
[Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy): Wedge is polite, gentle and quick to praise Ceodore.
[Personality Powers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PersonalityPowers): Biggs and Wedge's choices in magic spells are apt indicators of their contrasting personalities outside of gameplay.
[Sensitive Guy and Manly Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SensitiveGuyAndManlyMan): Wedge the Sensitive Guy and Biggs the Manly Man.

[Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut): While their names are part of a [Running Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RunningGag), [guess where they ultimately came from](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/StarWars).
[What the Hell, Hero?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellHero): They are the formerly-unnamed soldiers who objected to taking Mysidia's crystal's in the original game.
[White Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMage): Wedge comes with Cure and Cura.
[Character Catchphrase](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterCatchphrase): "Huh?"
[Childhood Friends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChildhoodFriends): With Ursula, partly because of their fathers' friendship and the fact that Cecil is Ursula's godfather. It doesn't get explored much.
[Combat Medic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatMedic): He's a powerful fighter and also has support and healing spells like Protect, Shell, Haste, and Curaga.
[Deadly Upgrade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadlyUpgrade): After Awaken wears off or after the battle ends, whichever comes first, Ceodore's HP drops to single digits.

[Decoy Protagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DecoyProtagonist):
    - In the game as a while, he is often one of the front runners of the cast, the game starts off with his tale, and is shown prominently in promotional material and the cinematic opening. In the game, he's no less of a [Pinball Protagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PinballProtagonist), and towards the end, it's (SPOILER) Kain, Rydia, and to a lesser extent Cecil who get more of the central focus. - This is true for his chapter as well. His tale itself *seems* like it's about him (which makes it look like he gets two chapters, since the prologue is focused on him as well), but by the end it's clear (SPOILER) that "his" chapter is actually about Kain.
[Determinator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Determinator): Even when it's clear he's outmatched, Ceodore never gives up.

[Heroic Spirit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSpirit): His Awaken ability manifests as this; pushed to the brink of defeat, Ceodore's true potential awakens to restore his health and power up his stats. However, this is only temporary, and once it wears off his HP is left in the single digits.
[Humble Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumbleHero): Just like his parents, he wants no special treatment because of his station and wants to prove himself on his own merits.

[Jack of All Stats](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JackOfAllStats): Ceodore is very balanced with speed, strength, and magic, and has a very large amount of [Bands](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombinationAttack) to choose from as well. This is at the cost of being a [Master of None](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterOfNone) outclassed by more specialised characters, but allows him to fit into just about any party formation.
[Locked Out of the Loop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LockedOutOfTheLoop): The Hooded Man stops him from encountering  (SPOILER) Brainwashed Cecil  in his story to shield him from what's happened to him.

[Misery Builds Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MiseryBuildsCharacter): He seems far more interested in learning from and being instructed by [Biggs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrillSergeantNasty) than [Wedge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy), though he obviously still cares about the latter.
[Modest Royalty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ModestRoyalty): Ceodore insists on being treated like any other soldier would.

[Multi-Melee Master](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MultiMeleeMaster): Like his father Ceodore has a large variety of equipment options despite defauting to swords most of the time. He can also use daggers, staves, bows, axes and unlike Cecil can use spears as well. Unlike Cecil, some of these are potentially worth looking into as Ceodore can be pretty effective with a spear or axe.

[Overshadowed by Awesome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OvershadowedByAwesome): As noted under [Jack of All Stats](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JackOfAllStats), Ceodore is a well-rounded party member who would fit comfortably into any party combination, but more specialised characters who excel at their particular niches get more love than him as a rule because in the end, they wind up being more powerful, most of them were playable in the first game (whereas Ceodore just happened along for the sequel) and for some, their character arcs all get better explanation and more emotional weight than his.

[Pinball Protagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PinballProtagonist): While he goes from place to place and develops in both character and skill, he really has very little effect on the situations he finds himself in.

[Post-Victory Collapse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PostVictoryCollapse): Happens after he defeats the boss in his knighthood trial. Justified because [he has just used his Awaken ability for the first time, and is understandably exhausted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStoryIntegration).
[Rite of Passage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RiteOfPassage): Not literally, but his test of knighthood is treated this way.

[Royals Who Actually Do Something](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalsWhoActuallyDoSomething): He's not content to sit around getting through life due to his heritage; he wants to earn his way in the world.
[Scarf of Asskicking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScarfOfAsskicking): Wears a striped scarf around his neck to contrast his father's cape.

[Self-Made Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SelfMadeMan): Not really, but he sure wants to be. At first, Ceodore wants to be judged by his own merits and accomplishments or lack thereof, and holds little pride in being the son of the king and queen of Baron. As part of his [Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment), Ceodore learns that pride in his heritage and wanting to be his own man are not mutually exclusive, and decides to change his approach, striving to be his own person while acknowledging and respecting his parentage.

[Ship Tease](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShipTease): With [Ursula](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChildhoodFriends), thanks to [a campfire scene](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CampfireCharacterExploration) at the moon, which gives them a [a Band attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombinationAttack).

[Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut): His Cross Slash attack used by slashing the enemy with the help of the Hooded Man was previously used by Crono and Frog in *[Chrono Trigger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/ChronoTrigger)*.
[Sole Survivor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SoleSurvivor): Ceodore is the only person to survive the airship crash after returning from his Knight trial.
[Spin-Offspring](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpinOffspring): The son of the heroes of the original game is the hero of the sequel.

[Supporting Protagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SupportingProtagonist): While advertised as [The Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHero) of the sequel, he plays a much smaller role in the events concerning the Mysterious Girl and the Crystals than the other characters.  (SPOILER) Not helped by Kain, a top contender for the *actual* main protagonist of the sequel, accompanying Ceodore early in the game and being the one to drive most of his actions. Were the game to be told from Kain's perspective rather than Ceodore's, little would change in terms of narrative structure.
[Uneven Hybrid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnevenHybrid): 3/4 human, 1/4 Lunarian via his paternal grandfather.
[Warrior Prince](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WarriorPrince): Wants to prove himself as this.

[White](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMagic) [Magic Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicKnight): More so than Cecil or Kain, since rather than being a paladin or a Holy Dragoon, he's a warrior who also has White Magic, along with his unique [Awaken](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadlyUpgrade) ability.

[All Your Colors Combined](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllYourColorsCombined): Two of their Band abilities: Wheel of Elements, where the four combine together, and Ultimate Art: Advent of Phoenix, where they all combine with Edge. The latter even comes with [a chant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Invocation). However, Wheel of Elements is thematically closer, since it actually consists of the four using their elemental powers in sequence, while Advent of Phoenix just uses fire.
[Ass-Kicking Pose](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AsskickingPose): They all strike one in unison with Edge following Ultimate Art: Advent of Phoenix.

[The Cameo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCameo): Zangetsu and Gekkou appear in the special PSP Interlude chapter assisting Edge as his new recruits, without the other two. Only the senior members appear as the story being set only a year after the original game, Izayoi was still a little girl and Tsukinowa wasn't even born yet.

[Color-Coded Characters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColorCodedCharacters): Gekkou wears [red](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FireIsRed), Izayoi wears [blue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WaterIsBlue), Tsukinowa wears [green](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WindIsGreen), and Zangetsu wears [yellow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YellowLightningBlueLightning) and orange.
[Cool Old Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolOldGuy): Zangetsu is old, but he's still a kickass fighter.
[Death from Above](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathFromAbove): Zangetsu, via [Kite Riding](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KiteRiding).

[Dual Wielding](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DualWielding): Tsukinowa is the only one of the Eblan Four who can Dual Wield just like their master, making ninja swords or boomerangs the best weapon options for him.

[Elemental Powers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElementalPowers): They each have their own set.
    - [Blow You Away](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlowYouAway): Tsukinowa. - [An Ice Person](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnIcePerson): Izayoi - [Making a Splash](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MakingASplash): Izayoi. - [Playing with Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire): Gekkou. - [Shock and Awe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShockAndAwe): Zangetsu.

[Fantastic Fighting Style](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticFightingStyle): Due to [Competitive Balance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CompetitiveBalance), they have varied stats.
    - Izayoi is a [Combat Medic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatMedic), having balanced stats with a focus on healing Ninjutsu. She is also the only one of the four who can wield bows and whips as well as the female-exclusive equipment, and has the most [Band](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombinationAttack) options with other characters. - Tsukinowa is a [Fragile Speedster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FragileSpeedster), with the highest Speed in the game but being very weak otherwise. He is the only one of the four capable of [Dual Wielding](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DualWielding), and can also wield boomerangs. - Zangetsu is a [Magic Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicKnight) with high Intelligence and still respectible Strength and HP. He is the only one of the four who can wield spears. - Gekkou is a [Mighty Glacier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MightyGlacier), boasting high HP and Strength but very low Speed and MP. Fittingly, he is also the only one of the four who can wield axes and hammers.

[Five-Man Band](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FiveManBand): They form one with Edge. He's [The Leader](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLeader), his second-in-command Zangetsu is [The Lancer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLancer), the physically powerful Gekkou is [The Big Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBigGuy), the trickster Tsukinowa is [The Smart Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSmartGuy), and Izayoi is [as the sole woman among them](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSmurfettePrinciple).

[Flat Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlatCharacter): Their individual personalities don't get a lot of time to shine through, as they individually receive equal focus in Edge's Tale, which doesn't last long, and once Edge's Tale is complete, they contribute nothing to the plot save for a scene deep in the final dungeon.
    - Somewhat lampshaded in [The Very Definitely Final Dungeon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheVeryDefinitelyFinalDungeon); if one of them is the 5th party member in the cutscene where Cecil returns to normal and Golbez survives, Cecil has no idea who they are and his only comment on them is that they must be working under Edge. - It happens again during the ["Where Are They Now?" Epilogue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhereAreTheyNowEpilogue) — if they all make it to the end of the game, Edge offers to let them go their separate ways, but they just reassert their loyalty to him because they seem to have no idea what to do with themselves otherwise.

[Invocation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Invocation): As mentioned above, the [Ultimate Art: Advent of Phoenix Band](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ieD6sHI7D8Y) involves the Eblan Four reciting a [Magical Incantation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicalIncantation) alongside Edge before unleashing their ninjutsu spell. QUOTE **Zangetsu:** "Endless night, lit by fiery wings..." **Izayoi:** "Bound by the darting, dancing sword..." **Gekkou:** "Let it slice the encompassing dark..." **Tsukinowa:** "And sound the tolling bell of tomorrow!" **Edge:** "Now! We call forth Eblan's ancient technique..." **All:** ["Advent of Phoenix!"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CallingYourAttacks)

[Killed Off for Real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffForReal): If you let them die during their recon missions. Luckily, these are [Save Scummable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SaveScumming). And also in the 3D versions, they're permanent party members and Gekkou restrains himself from helping the monks at the end of his mission.
[Kite Riding](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KiteRiding): Zangetsu uses this as his special ability, a variant of Kain's Jump.

[Master of Disguise](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterOfDisguise): They each disguise themselves when undercover and no one sees through them. Except for Gekkou, who never disguises himself as a monk despite spending time in Fabul.
[Master of Illusion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterOfIllusion): Izayoi's unique ability is Illusion, which functions like a no MP cost Confusion spell.
[Ninja](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Ninja): Naturally. Izayoi is a kunoichi, and insists on being treated as a ninja, not a woman.

[Personality Powers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PersonalityPowers): Although they get little time to showcase their individual personalities, their powers are intended to line up with their personalities, but in a more nuanced way than usual. Gekkou is a [warm-hearted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy) [Gentle Giant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GentleGiant); Izayoi is [calm](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStoic), [collected](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyOfWar), [efficient and defined by her job](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ConsummateProfessional); Tsukinowa is [quick-witted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WittyBanter), [cunning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSmartGuy) and [restless](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HotBlooded); and Zangetsu is aspiring and spritely.
[Pint-Sized Powerhouse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PintSizedPowerhouse): Despite being pre-pubescent and able to pass for a regular boy, one should never consider Tsukinowa useless.

[Satellite Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SatelliteCharacter): Outside of their mini-quests in Edge's Tale, where being on their own they talk little, all their dialogue is them talking to Edge. This is underlined if they're the fifth character taking part in Cecil's battle with  (SPOILER) the Dark Knight , as Cecil has no idea who they are.
[The Smurfette Principle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSmurfettePrinciple): Izayoi, the lone female member, but just as capable in combat as the men are.

[Theme Naming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThemeNaming): All of their names have something to do with the moon. "Tsukinowa" means "moon halo," "Gekkou" means "moonlight," "Izayoi" means "full moon," and "Zangetsu" means "morning moon." Additionally, Tsukinowa's alias during his recon in Mysidia, "Lapin," means, "[Moon Rabbit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoonRabbit)."
[Video Game Stealing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VideoGameStealing): Tsukinowa's unique ability among the Eblan Four is the Steal ability.
[Younger Mentor, Older Disciple](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YoungerMentorOlderDisciple): Zangetsu is an old man and a student to the much younger Edge.
[Anime Chinese Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnimeChineseGirl): Wears a [qipao](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/UsefulNotes/Qipao), sports odango hair, and is a martial artist. Yep, she fits.

[Attack Its Weak Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AttackItsWeakPoint): Tenketsu may deal an automatic critical hit, or deal elemental damage the target enemy is weak to.
    - Ursula even learns the ability while rendering a supposedly invincible enemy vulnerable. It is this act which finally convinces Yang to teach her.

[Awesome by Analysis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AwesomeByAnalysis): Yang has not officially given her any training when the game begins, but a flashback shows she's been watching him train the other monks in Fabul her entire life and has picked up on a lot of his techniques.
[Bare-Fisted Monk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BareFistedMonk): Her job class is Monk, and like Yang she beats enemies up with martial arts.

[Breakout Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakoutCharacter): After Ceodore, who is [The Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHero), Ursula is the character from *The After Years* most likely to appear in spin-offs like *Record Keeper* and *Opera Omnia*, and in those specific cases is the only character from the sequel besides Ceodore to be included (until Leonora was added in *Opera Omnia*).
[Childhood Friends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChildhoodFriends): With Ceodore. The *-Interlude-* reveals that she's also the older of the two.
[Combat Medic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatMedic): With her Chakra ability she can heal herself and get back to fighting shape, or help an ally off the ground.
[Cute Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CuteBruiser): She's adorable, and she's still a physical brawler trained by one of the most famous Monks in the world.

[Establishing Character Moment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EstablishingCharacterMoment): When she runs off to Mt. Hobs alone, Yang and his Monks go after her, worried she'll be hurt. They find her copying Yang's [Establishing Character Moment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EstablishingCharacterMoment) from the original game, taking out a force of Domovois on her own before Yang and his Monks join with her to fight the Mom Bomb. This princess will *not* be a [Damsel in Distress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DamselInDistress).
[Flowers of Femininity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlowersOfFemininity): She wears a flower in her hair, showing that she still has some poise and femininity despite her hands-on fighting style.

[Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil): To Ceodore. While he attempts to avoid becoming [Generation Xerox](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GenerationXerox) and has to learn to take pride in his parentage rather than rejecting it, Ursula is actively locked out of the family business until Yang finally realizes she's worthy of his time.
[Lady of War](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyOfWar): She's graceful and poised and a total badass.

[Lightning Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightningBruiser): Her standout stat is her Speed, third-highest outranked only by Edge and Tsukinowa. While her physical stats and HP are outranked by most of the dedicated physical fighters, they're still much higher than the mages of the group and she can still deal a good amount of damage even before she gets equipment that makes up the difference.
[Pressure Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PressurePoint): Her Tenketsu ability delivers the [Touch of Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TouchOfDeath) by virtue of this trope.
[Princesses Prefer Pink](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrincessesPreferPink): She wears a pinkish-red dress.

[Rebellious Princess](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RebelliousPrincess): Completely defies Yang's wishes at every turn. since he's so overprotective. He eventually accepts his daughter has to be allowed to have some freedom in her life.

[Royals Who Actually Do Something](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalsWhoActuallyDoSomething): Her character arc is that she *wants* to be this, but Yang doesn't think a princess has a need for combat training. Ursula doesn't listen, and he eventually relents and agrees to take her on as a proper disciple.

[Warrior Monk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WarriorMonk): Becoming this trope is her character arc. Yang fears that Ursula only wants to learn to fight because she wants to be an asskicker just like him, but it's the spirit of the teachings that hold more value than the physical part; you learn the ways of the Monk to protect people and defend yourself, not to hurt others. When Ursula defends her bodyguards from a monster in spite of being outmatched, Yang realizes she has this spirit within her and finally agrees to give her proper training.
