[Wolverine Claws](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WolverineClaws): Like her father she can equip them to give her normal attacks elemental or status properties.
[The Apprentice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheApprentice): She studies Black Magic under Palom.

[Ascended Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedExtra): She was in the first game, it turns out. She's the random NPC girl Palom was boasting to in the ending. When she tells him, [Palom admits he had no idea that was her and that he barely remembers the incident](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButForMeItWasTuesday).

[Beware the Nice Ones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BewareTheNiceOnes): She appears to be your typical shy and kind girl who cannot complete a sentence without stuttering, but get to know her more and she proves that she is a lot more assertive than she lets on. She takes Palom's [Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass) nature in stride when she trains under him, but the moment she hears him insult the Epopts to her face, she's quick to tell him off without a single stutter.
[Black and White Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackAndWhiteMagic): She already knows White Magic, but wants to train in Black Magic.
[Cowardly Lion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CowardlyLion): Despite her nervousness and stuttering, she's just as capable of (and willing to) doing battle as anyone else.

tropeName: Hair of Gold, Heart of Gold
tropeNotes: [Hair of Gold, Heart of Gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HairOfGoldHeartOfGold): She's a kind, humble, and compassionate young woman.
[Inept Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IneptMage): At first. Hell, her first Black Magic spells are even weaker than 1st tier Black Magic (Fire? Blizzard? Thunder?).
[Magic Wand](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicWand): Wields one in her artwork.

[Magikarp Power](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagikarpPower): Taken to the point it's [Awesome, but Impractical](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AwesomeButImpractical). With patience and level grinding, Leonora will be the only end-game party member to learn both schools of magic, and can use Dualcast to boot. The problem is that because of her split focus she learns her spells much slower. She doesn't get Curaga until Level 45 (by which time other White Mages will have Cura*ja*), Holy until Level 70, learns the three "-aga" spells at Levels 78, 80, and 82, and finally gets Flare at *Level 85*. For the record, all other magic-using characters will finish learning all their spells by Level 60, at the latest. The result of this is that by the time you finally put in the effort to grind her up to that high level, you could have just done everything else worth doing in the game with other characters.

[The Red Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheRedMage): She can learn both [White Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMagic) and [Black Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackMagic), but does not learn every [Black Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackMagic) spell.
[Shrinking Violet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShrinkingViolet): In Palom’s tale, she is introduced as a shy, humble and quiet lady.

[Squishy Wizard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SquishyWizard): The squishiest — at Level 99 she's one of only three party members with less than 4,000 HP, and the other two are Calca and Brina. And then, if the random factor in HP gain doesn't like her, she can flat have the worst HP of all.

[Teacher/Student Romance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TeacherStudentRomance): Has a [Ship Tease](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShipTease) with her mentor Palom. She has feelings for him, but she doesn't come forward with them. Not to him, anyway.  (SPOILER) Though in a scene in the Lunar Subterrane, she admits them to Luca, and he overhears her saying it.

[Took a Level in Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInBadass): She stutters a lot and is respectful of Palom initially, despite him being a [Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass). Once he insults the Epopts, though, she's had enough and tells him off, at which point for most of the rest of the game the stuttering stops. This event coincides with the completion of the Tower of Trials, and thus she begins to learn [Black Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackMagic) as she levels up from now on.
[Badass Bookworm](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBookworm): Subverted, in that she *is* well-read, but sadly not worth too much in battle.
[Badass Longcoat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassLongcoat): Her long brown scholar's coat is cool at least.

[Crutch Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrutchCharacter): She's useful enough as an extra sword arm (or whip arm, as it were) during Edward's chapter to help bolster some damage output (especially in the Challenge Dungeon), and her Gil Toss ability is fairly powerful, but once the main heroes all reunite, she's best relegated to the reserves. That said, with specific equipment options she is capable of outdamaging Ceodore.
[Girl Friday](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GirlFriday): Edward's personal secretary and assistant, and able to defend herself (although not well).

[Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths): She eventually reveals she's done a lot of research and knows some comparatively obscure facts about the events in the original game. Edward is surprised to learn this.
    - Further, in an event within the Lunar Subterrane, she reveals that she lost her parents to the conflict in *Final Fantasy IV*, and Edward's music helps her to cope with the loss.
[Hypercompetent Sidekick](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HypercompetentSidekick): Lots of other characters comment that she's really the brains behind Damcyan's governance.

[Item Amplifier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItemAmplifier): Dummied out content indicates she was to have the "Knowledge" ability that would double the effectiveness of healing items, but instead she joins the party with the Economical Ring accessory, which does the same thing.

[Joke Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JokeCharacter): Harley has the dubious honor of being almost entirely useless in battle. Her abilities are practically worthless, her Bands except for Feast of the Land need multiple party members to skip their turn to use, of those Bands one has random effects, two more require specific equipment set ups, and all of them require questionable party configurations to use. If not for Calca and Brina, she would be the flat worst party member in the game, and at least they have equipment to turn them into [Lethal Joke Characters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LethalJokeCharacter); Harley does not.

[The Load](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLoad): Harley's sole major contribution to the plot is to get sick, dragging out gameplay another hour while Edward gets a cure for her. This is after she insists on accompanying him, saying "I'm certain I will be of use". To her credit, she admits it's her own fault and she should have just listened to Edward and stayed behind.
[Money to Throw Away](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoneyToThrowAway): Has the Gil Toss ability, letting her throw money to damage enemies.

[Overshadowed by Awesome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OvershadowedByAwesome): Poor Harley does try to be a helpful member of [La Résistance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaResistance) and has good combat skills for a civilian, but ultimately she's a normal human woman surrounded by a group of mages, knights, monks, ninjas, [and](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndZoidberg) [Edward](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/QuirkyBard). There's only so much she can do to contribute when they all bring something more substantial to the mix.
[Plucky Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PluckyGirl): Bless her, she at least attempts to be helpful and insists on travelling with Edward and his knights.
[Prim and Proper Bun](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrimAndProperBun): Her hairstyle tightly ties her hair into a bun.

[Subordinate Excuse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SubordinateExcuse): She became Edward's secretary because she was uplifted by his music after losses in the family during the events of the [first game](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyIV).
[Weapon Specialization](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeaponSpecialization): Her main weapons are whips, and most of the Band abilities she's involved in call for her to be equipped with one.
[Artificial Human](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArtificialHuman): She turns out to have been created by  (SPOILER) the Creator, as a pawn to gather the Crystals.
[Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad): She sets off the major events of *The After Years* and is the central antagonist.  (SPOILER) Until it turns out she has a boss.

[Bond Villain Stupidity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BondVillainStupidity): Badly. If she actually killed off the heroes when she had the chance, only half of them would have survived to the final tale. However, it's justified from her perspective: In most of her confrontations with the heroes she deals a [Curb-Stomp Battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CurbStompBattle) to them using an Eidolon, so she is fairly correct in viewing them as "inferior species" that pose no serious threat to her. In the later tales when the heroes have proven to be repeated thorns in her side, she gets over this problem.
[Boss Remix](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossRemix): Her character theme is the basis for her battle theme.

[Bullying a Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BullyingADragon): Not more than five minutes after her appearance and she reveals she's forcefully [taken control of Bahamut.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy) Save all the Eidolons later in the game, and it will completely backfire on her. See [Oh, Crap!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap) for more.
[Character Catchhrase](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterCatchhrase): "Incomprehensible."

[Clone Army](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CloneArmy):  (SPOILER) It turns out there are *several* "Mysterious Girls" around, acting independently of each other to gather the Crystals as one, explaining why she's able to appear in every single storyline. If one happens to die, another just picks up where she left off.
[The Dog Bites Back](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDogBitesBack): When  (SPOILER) the Creator  begins to go haywire, she destroys it.
[Emotionless Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EmotionlessGirl): Mostly; arrogance and contempt are there, but that's about it.

[Evil Cannot Comprehend Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCannotComprehendGood): Most of the girl's dialogue is expressing confusion regarding the nature of "inferior species". In a scene with some Fabul monks, she flat-out states that the idea of "honor" is foreign to her, as is the idea they'd fight her because of it knowing she'll kill them for their effort.

[Evil Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCounterpart): Bears a great physical resemblance to Rydia, even being mistaken as her by Cecil initially, and is also able to control Eidolons.  (SPOILER) *-Interlude-* reveals it's because the Creator made the Maenads in Rydia's image after gathering data on her through a Crystal.

[Everyone Calls Him "Barkeep"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryoneCallsHimBarkeep): Justified, as there's no way of knowing her real name until the last five minutes of the game.  (SPOILER) And even then, "Maenad" is just the name given to her race as a whole.
[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): Frequently insults [humans](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PunyEarthlings) and Lunarians as "inferior species."
[Giving Someone the Pointer Finger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GivingSomeoneThePointerFinger): Her battle sprite.
[The Heavy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeavy): She's the only major villain to appear for a long time.
[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice):  (SPOILER) The entire species hold out against the Creator in order to allow the party to escape the True Moon.
[Hive Mind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiveMind): Implied in the Depths,  (SPOILER) complete with [referring to themselves in the plural](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IAmLegion).
[Identical Stranger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IdenticalStranger): Resembles Rydia but bears no other relation to her.

[Invincible Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InvincibleVillain): Appears in a number of Tales  (SPOILER) since there's an army of them , and whenever she does it ends with the protagonists failing to stop her. It's not until the "Lunarian's Tale" where she **FINALLY** suffers a defeat, more than half way through the story  (SPOILER) and almost immediately it's revealed that there's more than one of her.
[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass): Extremely arrogant and condescending to everyone she meets, deeming them "inferior species."

[Lack of Empathy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LackOfEmpathy): Believing all of the Blue Planet's inhabitants to be beneath her, she cares nothing for who she hurts, kills, or enslaves to get what she wants.

[Last of His Kind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastOfHisKind):  (SPOILER) A young Maenad, later named Cuore, is entrusted to the party for safekeeping as the remaining Maenads pull a [You Shall Not Pass!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouShallNotPass) on the Creator in order to help the heroes escape the True Moon.
[Light Is Not Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightIsNotGood): Wears a long white dress and evil, cold, and rude.
[Karmic Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmicDeath): Is killed by Odin after using him to try and kill the party.  (SPOILER) The one that controls Bahamut suffers the same fate.

[The Man Behind the Monsters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheManBehindTheMonsters): She controls an army of monsters to take over Baron, and still uses them on occasion after switching over to relying on Baron's military instead.

[No Name Given](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoNameGiven): She is only referred to as the "Mysterious Girl"  (SPOILER) and Maenad is the name of her species. As mass-produced members of a [Hive Mind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiveMind), it's likely that they don't *have* individual identities. Averted for the young Maenad raised by Rydia, who is named Cuore.

[No-Nonsense Nemesis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoNonsenseNemesis): Her only objective is obtaining the Crystals and she focuses all her efforts and attention on doing so, only taking time out to do things like enslave Baron and the Eidolons to more efficiently get the Crystals.  (SPOILER) Much like Golbez, in the end she succeeds and gets all of them, and despite their best efforts the party never had a serious chance at stopping her . She's also relentless in battle, able to use high-level magic and Eidolons to defeat her enemies and using the Eidolons as shields to defend herself.

[Oh, Crap!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap): After an entire game of talking down on and disregarding most of the party as a threat, her composed, high-and-mighty demeanor immediately turns into fear once  (SPOILER) Rydia, Leviathan, and Asura free (a now **very** angry) Bahamut from her control. She tries to cast Reflect to defend herself, but the Dragon King roasts her with Mega Flare before she finishes.
[One-Gender Race](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneGenderRace):  (SPOILER) The Maenads are an all-female species.
[Power Glows](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerGlows): Her battle sprite shows her surrounded by a sky blue aura.

[Pragmatic Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticVillainy): She's after the Crystals only. Unless one of the heroes is directly obstructing her, she doesn't care about them. On the other hand, if they prove themselves useful, she's willing to make deals with them.
[Punch-Clock Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PunchClockVillain):  (SPOILER) The Maenads you find on the True Moon are just standing around waiting for orders.
[Recurring Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RecurringBoss): You fight her several times throughout the game, though some of them are unwinnable.

[Redemption Equals Life](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedemptionEqualsLife): In the case of  (SPOILER) the one Maenad adopted by Rydia (Cuore), the only surviving member of her race. The rest of the race falls victim to [Redemption Equals Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedemptionEqualsDeath) since they die helping the party escape the Creator.
[Summon Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SummonMagic): As part of her status as an [Evil Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCounterpart) to Rydia.
[Supernatural Gold Eyes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SupernaturalGoldEyes): Official art and the 3D version depict her with amber eyes, and she is an exceedingly powerful sorceress.

tropeName: Traveling at the Speed of Plot
tropeNotes: [Traveling at the Speed of Plot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TravelingAtTheSpeedOfPlot): She seems to get around the world *very* fast to feature in multiple tales, sometimes within minutes of each other.  (SPOILER) Turns out this is because there's more than one of her.

[The Worf Effect](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheWorfEffect): To drill in just how powerful  (SPOILER) Golbez and Fusoya  are, when they fight her in the penultimate chapter, they kill her.  (SPOILER) Twice, even.

[You Have Outlived Your Usefulness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouHaveOutlivedYourUsefulness): She uses *those very words* before attempting to kill the party  (SPOILER) after Cecil returns to his senses . Subverted in that the party never helped her do anything.
[Ambiguous Gender](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguousGender): Although the Maenads refer to it as their "father", the Creator's gender is left deliberately ambiguous.
[Apologetic Attacker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ApologeticAttacker): Towards the *whole world*. It's sorry, it really is, but you didn't evolve to its liking and it's time to die.
[Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad): It's the real antagonist of the game.
[Blue-and-Orange Morality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlueAndOrangeMorality): Its mindset and standards are beyond comprehension.
[Clipped-Wing Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClippedWingAngel): The fights against it as the party escapes its lair, in which it hurts itself more than the party and several Maenads also attack it.
[Eldritch Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination): Definitely its last form, and the trope is present to lesser degrees for its other forms too.
[Everyone Calls Him "Barkeep"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryoneCallsHimBarkeep): Somehow, "the Creator" doesn't seem like an actual name.
[Evilutionary Biologist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilutionaryBiologist): It performs its experiments on races in the hopes of understanding the processes of evolution better.

[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy):
    - In an original flavor version, to Zemus, as the true Big Bad revealed near the end of the game to be manipulating the person you thought was the Big Bad into gathering the Crystals for them. - Also one to Garland from *[Final Fantasy IX](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyIX)*, who was himself reminiscent of Zemus, as they both served as keepers of a doomed space-faring race looking for new worlds to inhabit, the difference being the Terrans that Garland belonged to weren't all dead yet. - Also one for the "Firstborn" from the *[2001: A Space Odyssey](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Film/TwoThousandOneASpaceOdyssey)* books, both being [Sufficiently Advanced Aliens](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SufficientlyAdvancedAliens) who seeded planets with life by sending mysterious objects to them. - Also resembles the [Anti-Spiral](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Anime/TengenToppaGurrenLagann), being a god-like being from a failed race that decides to drop a moon on Earth because s/he decides they aren't worthy of evolution. - The outer shell it is encased in resembles [Lavos](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/ChronoTrigger), and both entities were [Evilutionary Biologists](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilutionaryBiologist). - Finally, its final form is an obvious stealth homage to [Neo-Exdeath](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyV).
[Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss): It's the last enemy of the game.

[God Is Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GodIsEvil): More like "God has gone mad", but while it's not exactly a supernatural Creator of the whole universe, it still more or less served the purpose of God of sorts for the worlds of FFIV, and it's long gone off the deep-end of the kill-happy spectrum.

[Go Mad from the Isolation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoMadFromTheIsolation): A leading theory is that the Creator was driven mad by becoming the [Last of His Kind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastOfHisKind).

[Greater-Scope Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreaterScopeVillain): It created the world of FFIV and possibly the Lunarian race as well, so even Zemus was nothing to it.  <sup>note </sup>  Given that it summons monsters from other Final Fantasy games and refers to them as simply creatures from other worlds that it created and destroyed, it's possible to interpret this as the GSV of the entire franchise!
[Last of His Kind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastOfHisKind): All other members of its race are dead.
[Mad Scientist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadScientist): It's much more subdued than other examples, but is clearly not in its right mind anymore.
[The Man Behind the Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheManBehindTheMan): The controlling force of the Maenads.
[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): It created the Crystals, the True Moon, and the Maenads, but as noted above it's probably not the creature's real name.

[Mr. Exposition](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MrExposition): It's a good thing it’s so talkative during its successive fights with the party, because otherwise you'd know nothing about who and what it is, or why it does what it does.

tropeName: My God, What Have I Done?
tropeNotes: [My God, What Have I Done?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGodWhatHaveIDone): It seems to regret its actions in its final moments and thanks the party and the Maenads who attacked it with its last words.

[One-Winged Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel): As the battle against it progresses, it turns into increasingly bizarre forms, with the last vaguely resembling Neo Exdeath from *[Final Fantasy V](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyV)*.

[Omnicidal Maniac](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OmnicidalManiac): Its goal is to destroy the world and all life on it. Emphasis on "maniac" since it intends to start over but between it's ancient age, it's evident madness and it's tendency to populate and destroy worlds over and over again, it's likely that the extinction of all life everywhere would be a side-effect of it's futile efforts rather than the ultimate goal.
[Physical God](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PhysicalGod): Ironically it’s the being who created the entire universe, it’s also said that it’s powerful enough to destroy the universe and recreate it.
[Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut): Several of the bosses in its lair are from other *Final Fantasy* games, implying they're other monsters it engineered.

[Sufficiently Advanced Aliens](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SufficientlyAdvancedAliens): So advanced it can *create Crystals*. It has dozens of them around the Depths. Those [MacGuffins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MacGuffin) that the *Final Fantasy* franchise centers around? It can casually make them at its whim.
[That's No Moon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThatsNoMoon): The True Moon is the remains of its species' grand space fleet amalgamated into a single craft.

[Time Abyss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TimeAbyss): It performs biological experiments on a *macroevolutionary* timescale, and there's no information volunteered as to exactly how old it is or how long it's been doing all this.
[Walking Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingSpoiler): As you likely noticed above, its entire existence is a giant spoiler for the end of the game.

[Woobie, Destroyer of Worlds](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WoobieDestroyerOfWorlds): The Creator is a more literal example than most; although it's responsible for attempting to destroy the Blue Planet and may have successfully annihilated other worlds it helped evolve, it's also the [Last of Its Kind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastOfHisKind) and a case can be made that [the loneliness drove it mad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoMadFromTheIsolation).
[You Have Failed Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouHaveFailedMe): Its attitude towards the planets it destroys.
